content:
er 8, 2016
												I've been playing this game on and off since the very beginning of the Early Access.  It's one of, if not my favorite game in the Sandbox/Open World/Survival genre.  You should consider this as an early access review since I haven't yet played the release version of the game.What sets this game apart from other games like it is that it has an epic story and feel, and the story mode can be played coop.  It's a "go at your own pace" story where you do quests and/or side quests which usually reward you with gear/recipes. However, you can also skip all the quests and just purchase most of the gear/recipes at the npc shops if you prefer to do it that way.  The scenery is awesome and many locations feel epic.  This is because in story mode the terrain was hand crafted and not randomly generated like other games.  There are plains, deserts, huge forests with giant trees, etc. each with different creatures.  The creatures and vegetation are some of the most unique and alien I have seen in any game.  I believe in the adventure game mode the terrain is randomly generated but I haven't played that mode much yet.The crafting system is very unique and you can build custom weapons, vehicles, boats, helicopters, etc. and the materials you use matter.  NPC "shops" exist where you can buy most of the recipes or if you are patient you can do quests which usually reward you with recipes and/or items.  Once you have discovered a point of interest in the game, you can spend the game's currency (meat) to fast travel between any point of interest, It has a unique mining system where you can scan for ore deposits, and you can put comments on the map, so you can get back to the deposits later. The voxel terrain is destructable, and contains underground caverns to explore.  You mine for ores, cut down trees, hunt beasts, etc. to get materials for crafting.I personally really like the sound track.I can't think of much not to like about this game. I guess bugs were probably the greatest deterrent a while back.  Multiplayer had some syncing issues when I last played it a few months before the release but most of the bugs were tolerable at that time.  I'm guessing they have fixed most of them for full release and I can't wait to do a full play through again now that it is out of early access.The game also has several other game modes.  I haven't tried them so I won't comment on them.  The coop story mode is almost everything I have always wanted in an Open Sorld/Sandbox game.I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 18 of 20 people (90%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								There are many open world sandbox survival games on Steam, a lot of which are still in Early Access / active development, and even though the market is currently saturated, there are some titles that stand out from the crowd due to unique features or simply having enough to do to appeal to a wider audience.Planet Explorers is one of those. It even has voxels.Sure, it has the usual story mode on a hand-crafted map,  and a more open world approach in the way of adventure mode with procedurally generated maps, of which many other games also have. And because it's voxel-based, you can always change the terrain to your liking.The game sports a rather impressive array of flora and fauna, as well as a much larger selection of ores than many other games offer,  for players to utilize in crafting, building, and just as basic currency since most merchants will buy most items or raw materials.Then there's the camera modes - not every game has zoomable third person AND first-person. Though admittedly, this game's first-person feels uncomfortable at best. The third-person view, for me, is far more attractive.Combat is awkward and lacking, players flailing about clumsily as they attempt to strike down creatures and enemies in melee, and desperately trying to see a thin white reticle against a light or white backdrop in ranged combat with a mouse that feels as if the sensitivity has been turned all the way up leads to much frustration.Yet, all that aside, I find myself playing the game more and more. Why? Because it's a huge world, with unbelievable freedom, and though the graphics aren't AAA quality, the overall experience and malleability of the game more than makes up for its flaws. From standard foot travel to motorbikes to cars and trucks to boats to aircraft to actual railways and railcars, even though it does offer a fast travel option, there are far too many better methods of travel and transportation to make good use of.And that's without even mentioning the creation feature. I have yet to see any game that offers the ability to custom-make a weapon or vehicle one subvoxel at a time, add mandatory sub-components like a hilt, handle, engine, tires, propeller or whatever, and simply export it from the creation screen and wait a few seconds for it to pop into your inventory. Go ahead. Name one other game that has this feature.I love this game. I've been killed by bandits, drown while digging my way out of a cave, flipped my fugly cars and bikes while travelling over the unforgiving terrain, murdered by creatures I couldn't even describe without sounding like I was looking at an imaginative child's drawing (it has short hair, like a polar bear, and a horn, and two tentacles flowing from its back, and sharp claws and teeth, and six legs...). And yet, I've also driven my own creations across the various biomes, built towers that loomed over the landscape, climbed said towers, jumped from their apex, and soared across the land on a simple crafted glider.It has flaws, sure, but it more than makes up for those with its features and replayability. If you're looking for a game to play with your kids, or just looking for something that feels like a fresh, modern Minecraft, you won't find many games that can hold up to Planet Explorers. And for the price? I estimate that by the end of the year, I will have spent less than 10 cents per hour of entertainment.To me, that's one hell of a bargain.

content:
31
												It is very difficult to me give a straight Up / Down thumb.If I can I would give it a MEH thumb.The main problem of Planet Explorer is being ambitious but lacking on every aspect of the game, except the crafting system. The developer worked hard to provide a full feature sandbox game: dozens of creatures, materials, terrain types, procedurally generated worlds, game modes including a coop story mode, a super detailed crafting system, quests, dungeons and a loot system integrated with the Steam Workshop.What you get is all these stuff but lacking the right amount of deepness, they feels like still in prototype stage.All served with LOADS of bug, glitches and optimization problems.Once I started a cooperative game with a friend of mine I had a great sense of wonder... we really wanted to get sucked in this game. Sadly that feeling dropped after about 16 hours of gaming.Everything got repetitive and pointless really fast. We found ourself stuck in repetitive tasks  (mostly mining) and playing separated.In fact there is no reason to stick together, and even if you start playing willing to stay together, you'll end very soon wondering and doing tasks alone.Why does it happens?It happens for two reasons: 1) it is hard to find your mates (they are showed on the "big" map but you don't get directional clues on the minimap, so you get lost in no time)2) it is pointless being together because every "quest" is easy enough to be accomplished alone Even Dungeons are best in solo. They are just repetitive corridors fulfilled of monster where you get the loot just running through the enemies (ignoring them) and picking up the the loot crates  (mobs and bosses never drop useful stuffs).There is no real boss fight and when your colony is under siege, all the defensive work is made by the turrets you've placed all around.There is no reason to do real coop. Even the exploration.You can craft huge vehicles to carry all your party members... but ground vehicles are useless (they got stuck in the terrain every 30 meters) and flying vehicles are boring AS HELL.Even when  I found an entertaining way to travel (that is JetPack + glider) the exploration got boring pretty fast. You'll find soon that there is no real danger (you can overrun every creature), no real mystery and not a real rewarding aspect of exploring the world. Even the creatures are always the same. They can change shape and size but the behaviour patterns are the same used over and over.Even death is not a big deal in this game. You can't really die. You just respawn with everything you have. Damn.. at least take out my stuff and make me get it back where I've died.The real fun I got from this game is crafting. The shame is that your creations will be used in this doomed and boring world.Ok maybe this review ended to be too HARSH.Planet Explorer is NOT really THAT BAD, but the lack of deepness and polish in almost every aspect of the game is annoyingly hurting.Planet Explorer has A LOT OF potential but the developer needs to refine it A LOT more, because it still feels like an Early Access game.FINAL WORDSI don't regret buying it, IF it will get improvements.I hope I'll can give it a thumb UP as soon as possible.PS:I suggest the devs to focus on a single aspect of the game and heavily improve that, something that would keep up the desire of playing.My idea is to add some unique creation scripts that you get by EXPLORING the world. You can find it by luck or by acquiring around (NPC shop or dungeon) some sort of clues about how to find them.And creating zones that need a vehicle to be explored.

number of helpful: 20 of 25 people (80%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								I don't usually write reviews because i feel it is unnecessary; But this time i felt i just had too due to the really undeserved bad feedback this game is getting from people who haven't even played it for a couple of hours.Planet Explorer is a free-roam, open-world, voxel-based sci-fi RPG game.You're free to roam and explore a huge procedurally generated world filled with different and colorful flora and fauna, gather resources to survive and have NPC characters join your colonization efforts, and fight off various creatures who'd have you for dinner or as a doormat.The game has a story mode with a really interesting quest-driven plotline in which you explore the world after a crash landing and eventually gather the survivors for a colonization effort, while facing off with an unexcepted native threat.The gameplay is somewhat articulate to grasp and isn't all that easy early on - which is why so many people tend to leave the game in the first hour of playing. However, after you get into the kiting and dodging mindset and start getting confidence with the commands and the somewhat wacky interface the door opens for a whole lot of fun.The game world offers lots of fighting opportunities, but the main treat of the game is undoubtely resource gathering and crafting.Aside from the standard RUST-like crafting system with which you can craft various basic parts, armors or food, players have acces to a voxel-based editor under which you can create your very own weapons and vehicles. This is probably the funniest part of the game and you're given complete freedom over choice of shape, materials, mechanics and so on. The game then calculates the weight in each resource you've created your item/vehicle out of and prepares a crafting recipe.I said resource gathering: The totality of the game world can be harvested, broken, dug, chopped down - thanks to the dynamic voxel engine.Additionally, players can create a colony -think of Terraria NPC hosting mechanics, but much deeper- which will require food, for which you have to hunt or farm, protection, and so on.Overall the gameplay is vast, rich and addicting.The main downside is the uncompleted state of the game, which is however kept under a continous updating regibe my dedicated developers. Aside from that, the animations and graphics are kind of wacky, but the gameplay strongly makes up for it.

content:
7, 2016
												(Meant to edit this and accidently deleted it...)PROS:- Great variety in mobs/animals and plants.- A building system which allows you to place down whole walls at once, and allows you to save a building and then build it somewhere else if you have the resources.- You can build your own guns, swords, shields, vehicles, and turrets.- You can turn this into a Tower Defense game if you want.- Pretty good crafting system.- Excellent hand-held scanner which allows you to search for high-mineral deposits and underground caves.- You have pretty much an in-game workshop in multiplayer, where you can download different things people have built and then use those blueprints (ISOs) in any game mode. Great for those less-creative/new users.- The save system is pretty great, it generates 3 auto-saves over time, and you can also manually save at multiple points. This is useful if you accidently take on the hardest enemy base and then very quickly get killed when you respawn. (Like I did)- Great customer support. I've asked them questions multiple times, and they have always responded within 24 hours, even when I've done so on a weekend. They will tell you what is wrong or will ask for more information if needed, and are very polite in doing so.CONS: - Lots of crashes, though really if you won't play this game because of it, why are you even looking at a game still in development?- Developer Reliability:  The developers have been trying to do the 0.9 update for quite some time. They recently anounced it would be released during November. That doesn't sound so bad, no? Wrong. Looking at their past update history, when they announce that something is going to be released, it'll be another few months past the "expected date". So we'll probably be getting the 0.9 update sometime in February. (EDIT: They seem to be getting more and more consistant with updates, releasing at least one monthly. If they keep this up, then my review will continue to be positive.)- Not a whole lot of variety in quests; most are just, "fight these things," or, "bring me this." This is fine, seeing as story mode is yet to be completed, but I'd like to eventually see more variety.OVERALL/TL, DR:-  I can't recommend this in it's current state. Even though it's fun, and will probably eventually be a full, playable, non-crashing game, that is clearly going to take some time. The developers try to get things implemented for an update, but then in the update logs, say that it wasn't working out well for this version. Updates are inconsistent, and often don't add much content. There needs to be more frequent updates before I view the pros as outweighing the cons; as long as I view no further cons. I'll edit this review as the game gets developed. This is an excellent game, and the developers seem to have learned from their mistakes. They've noticed the dwindling player base and have acknowledged that it is due to their previous infrequent update history. They're improving upon that and have begun monthly updates. They are also very responsive to suggestions and have a great customer support system, should it be needed. I'm looking forward to the future of this game.Still TL, DR: Put it on your wishlist and get it on sale.DATE OF LAST EDIT (Excluding Typo Corrections): 14 November 2015Note: From the date of last edit^ onward, I have not played the game. I have reinstalled it and plan to play it soon. This review will be updated and will reflect the new experiences shortly after I get a good idea of what its become. From a few update notes I've read, I do look forward to playing this.

number of helpful: 43 of 67 people (64%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
er 17, 2016
												This review is based on multiplayer story mode via LAN.Bought an played on 17 Nov.UPDATED 26 NOVI wont explain to you all what the game is about since you most likely have already watched a few videos and read the game's description. If not, take the intiative to do so before reading on.Here I will provide a list of findings from myself and my gaming partner playing through story mode on "LAN" setting.My considered PROs.--------------------------------1) Single player game mode doesn't require an internet connection. 2) Creativity. This needs further clarification. You can design your own gear, and vehicles with a combination of premade 3d parts and voxels (cubes), which includes a somewhat rough ability to colour them as well. Once designing is complete, as long as you have the required materials in your inventory you are able to bring this design into the world as a fully usable/interactable object, as well as it will upload this creation to Steam's workshop.If you aren't the creative sort, you have the ability to download other people's uplaoded creations.3) The world itself is huge to try and fit as many different land types as possible onto a single island.4) As long you wield gear bought from NPCs or crafted from your replicator, combat doesn't last long against almost all opponents you face.My considered UNSURE OFs.--------------------------------------------1) Quests mostly consist of gathering specific items, talking to particular people, moving to a specific location on the map and killing specific critters and buildings. There are singular instances of getting the player to make use of user created content, introductory tool for players to make their own content. 2) Few quests require the construction of objects you do not have access to unless you find other specific NPCs to do their quests as well. When you do gain the object scripts (recipies or crafting papers you learn how to build stuff from) through quests they are useless since you will automatically already know how to produce them. Inventory clutter. 3) There is no inventory limit of any sort. While not a bad thing in of itself (and certainly not an issue unless you are looking for some kind of realism XD), it is rather amusing to be able to just pull a colossal boat / car / tank / flying machine / buidling out of your pocket and when you are finished using it, able to pick it up and put it back into your pocket. If there is a limit, I have yet to reach it.4) There is no levelling at all here to be done. A character's strengths and weaknesses are directly tied to the gear you wear and wield. 5) illnesses exist but are an incredibley rare occurance since they require very specific things to make them happen. A rather pointless addition.My considered CONs.--------------------------------1) LAN requires players to have internet access. ( wtf )2) Quitting a LAN game, PE_Server.exe will continue to run the background which counts as the game still running. Need to manually close it through the windows task manager.3) Syncronization. Cause delays in actions, and animations to not play when they should.4) in LAN game, characters and NPCs ignoring player placed blocks. This will lead to NPCs impossible to interact with should they be several layers under placed flooring. NPCs will also plant crops under player placed blocks should there be any fertilized soil under them.5) Some items created are largely useless. Created swords wont ever be as effective (roughly 1/3 as effective in fact) as those you can buy from NPCs or build from their scripts, uless you are planning on having over-the-top huge anime swords). Vehicles are largely useless except the helicopter, and even then you only need to use it to get to a destination once as fast travel exists.6) To edit any of your custom creations you will need to build an entire new one. You can get back all the materials for your original custom creation by recyling/deconstructing it however, it will need to have 100% durabilty to refund all of its materials used. You can't just add to your custom object without rebuilding the entire thing. I personally understand the reasoning for this choice however it creates the next point below.7) Any kind of recreation of custom item will be put into steam's workshop again. No, this doesn't replace what you've already put onto the workshop.8) Steam workshop clutter from everybody having created something. You'll see a host of copies of the same named thing and no idea how any of them a re different, if at all.9) The controls for creating custom things is not explained in detail anywhere easily.10) Some of the game's missions are very vague. Good thing there are people who will answer how to complete them. There shouldn't be a requirement to look up an outside source to understand what a quest requires a player to do.11) Talking with an NPC does not stop them from wandering off. This doesn't affect conversations, as they can still be finished. Shops, however, close once the NPC moves a certain distance away from the player. The experience is ok as a casual thing. Still there's a lot of room for improvement and from my opinion should still be in early access given the large number of issues present.I paid for this at full price. Developers these days a pretty eager to just shove their product out there regardless how complete and functional it may be. I wouldn't recommend this as it is right now, not until it gets some major fixes. Also it would be wise to change the "LAN" aspect since this isn't LAN at all.I'll try to keep this updated with the help of anyone who kindly informs me of my mistakes or game updates.

31, 2015
Early Access Review
								So my only main concern with this game right now is why did they change how the clustering works with resources you gather. It seems to me that in some patch (while I wasn't playing for idk how long), they decided that resources you gather shouldn't be completely clustered together and should have alot of trash resources, like dirt and stone, in the way. That sense of a realistic touch.. is a bit too much for me. It already took a bit of time and effort to find and gather them. It seems to me as if its take up a rediculous amount more time to gather resources now, making the game undesireable when I feel like I'm spending all day trying to get materials, instead of building the many awesome buildings / vehicles / miscellaneous objects.Take a look at my hours spent in game and you'll know I'm not fibbing. I seriously had a lot of fun up until now. Now it is a serious grind session. I'll not be playing a game if the work to fun ratio is heavily disproportionate. That being said, I currently will not recommend this game. I will check back in months coming to see progress and hopefully change my mind.My suggestion to fix the problem would be to either make resource gathering the way it was (heavily clustered no trash in the way), or give us better gathering tools to mine through resources at a faster (or MUCH faster) rate.You guys would also get extra bonus credit from me if you got rid of the 3ish second 'waiting to stop gathering resources so my character can do something ANYTHING again' wait time. Double bonus credit if you allow me to move while mining.

content:
28, 2015
												I think this game is a  great  concept and has climbed a fairly steep ladder. First let me make a point: Why I got the game I got the game to play with some friends that were playing it and convinced me to purchase it because it looked really interesting and entertaining; ofcourse when I got the game they all suddenly did not feel like playing it, go figure. When I got it I pretty much immidatly found out that this game reaches many SP aspects, but it does not quite feel right in singe player. I wanted to figure it all out and enjoy it but I really started to hate the game, it made no sense and I had felt like I waisted my money. The game was so difficult to understand alone and personally I think videos kind of play the game for you because of how much is just thrown at you and you don't really get to expierience the base game because somone has played it for you. I have to say find a decent community to rock out with befor you get crazy with this game. I say this because at first this is what I thought:  This game sucks  Physics are screwy. Recourses are hard to find and obtain. None of this crap makes sense. So on so forth.......However when I gave it another shot with a little more paitence I have to say   (This is why I had not posted my review yet, I did not feel like I was being in a fair mood. After playing and being paitent...)  Recomonded  The game presents and active chalenge. The devs are  working  on it, they have proved that the money I spent was worth it.(for a short time without any updates I was worried this was a starforge project.) Many creatures and day-to-day monsters or aliens to deal with. can start a civilization or colony of sorts (tad bit buggy, but the core concept is in place) Many creative build options. I love the vehicle creator and wepon creator. Fantastic ideas. Negatives  With the latest updates I have not found anything to mark down as negative. Suggestions?  Maybe some kind of jet option, I understand it is somewhat there but a more plane-like option would be sweet! More PEW PEW options Bananas. I really enjoy this game and I know I was fairly impaitent before but I have gained a better understanding of how game developing works and that it is not a couple month process, it is a multi-year in most cases.

content:
y 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Minecraft and Alpha Centauri bumped into Skyrim and Spore leaving the over-budget rejects club. They all hooked up and had a weird four-parent-baby and named it Planet Explorers.But enough about the game, lets talk about me. I have learned SO MUCH from playing Planet Explorers! I thought I needed friends and family and a life and a job and a future, but now I see those are all optional. All I really need is to mine more copper, find all the survivors, investigate the interference, learn more about the natives, help the earthlings and Martians get along peacefully, and always eat before I get a stomach ache because the ingredients for stomach medicine are so rare.Planet Explorers gameplay is way too fun. I hate to admit it, but they may have finaly made a game that is better than real life. Some of the controls are quirky, and I'm sure that will bother a few at first. For example, RMB is for both moving the camera and stoweing your weapon/tool. So any time you are using your equipment, it gets put away the next time you move the camera. It is most annoying in combat but once you get used to it, it's fine.The graphics in the game are way over-the-top. I have to run it on 'simple' just to get >10fps. I have an old computer though, so I doubt many people will share that experience. But, even on low graphics, the artwork is quite charming. It doesn't look -bad- until you get to the minimum setting.The new content creation features are very well thought and add tremendous depth of freedom to the game. You can design almost anything- armors, weapons, tools, vehichles, buildings, etc. Getting your new designs into the game however is another story, as I have not yet been able to figure out how. Problems- Combat gets interrupted frequently by poorly designed pathfinding and physics interractions. I've watched an animal run circles around a tree trying to get me while I stood still maybe ten paces away. It doesn't happen often, but it is annoying when it does. NPCs will run at trees. They seem to want to get someplace beyond the tree but they can't seem to see it, so they just stick to it and run in place until you chop the tree down. That happens a lot. While fighting, your body will sometimes get tangled up with and enemy's body and you can't do anything until they sepparate. So, you may die a couple times because one monster decided to get freaky with you while the other uses you as a punching bag. That happens way more than it should. In story-mode, you will sometimes encounter invincible enemies. They are invincible because they are part of an event or scene and not supposed to die, but you can't know they are invincible until you try to kill them, at which point they start chasing after you and there is nothing you can do about it, because they are invincible. That is a real pain. The build features (for placing blocks/dirt/etc) has no proper in-game introduction, and unfortunately isn't idiot-proofed. There is a sort of mini-tutorial, but after reviewing it I still had no idea how to use it. I think I am finally figuring most of it out, and now it's fun to use, but it is not intuitively designed. At one point (while trying to build something, though I don't know that is necessarily the cause) the game gave me a 'critical error' and my save-file stopped working, so I had to start the game over.-YOU MUST SAVE REGULARLY AND USE MULTIPLE SAVE FILES-Because you may play for two or three days (seriously, not a game for addicts) and then -CRITICAL ERROR- and all your progres is lost.In conclusion, I happily accept the game's few, though dire flaws, and I'm sure you will as well! =DAnd I feel bad about it really, because I bought maybe a dozen games in the steam winter sale and now the rest may never get touched.

content:
ry 5
												Had this game for a while and finally decided to play through the Story mode again.  I played through the story a couple of years ago and it ended in the middle of the story, so I wanted to see if it went any further since release.  I managed to finish it this time around to the very end.That being said.  Not much was improved since my original playthrough to this recent playthrough.  Yes.  The story can be completed.  The beginning of the story was very interesting, but after a while it just felt like elements of gameplay were thrown on top and the story was rushed.The game had (has?) a lot of potential, but it was thrown away due to the disjointed story pacing coupled with the technical issues that still lurk in the game itself.  Nothing about it seemed smooth and organic.  Things happened so suddenly both story wise and technical wise that the story was barely holding together.That being said.  From what I got of the story, it IS an interesting multi-layered story set in a very beautiful world (most of the time).  The game has a great range of freedom, at the cost of glitchy engine problems.More time could have been spending nailing down these issues.  More time could have been spent on things like underground systems (which when you get down to it, all the underground cavern systems are butt ugly and featureless).  This same blandness flows into the mountains and canyon biomes.  Seems most of the time was spent around building up the initial plains area you start in (which is gorgeous) and just starts going downhill from there.There was a great game being made here.  But it becomes quite obvious as you progress, that a lack of passion and attention petered out at the later stages.

number of helpful: 14 of 16 people (88%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
13, 2016
Early Access Review
								There seems to be a horde of crafting/voxel based/survival games coming out or in early access, so some quick bullet points on how Planet Explorers differentiates itself from the others I've played. The "ISO" system. When crafting guns, armor, swords, shields, vehicles...well, anything really, you have the option to slap down a few base parts and basically design your own 3d model of the item from the materials you choose. Very easy to make basic items of your own, and you can download other peoples creations that they've chosen to share. Someone willing to put in the time and effort can make some very nice looking items. Building a colony. Constructing the buildings, recruiting colonists, handing out jobs and keeping them fed--I found it very satisfying, much moreso than other survival games where the only person you're responsible is yourself. Getting around is quite enjoyable. The maps can be quite large, but they seem much smaller when you have tools like gliders, jet packs, parachutes, grappling hooks...and let's not forget your fighter jet or helicopter (or mech or speeder bike), either. This is a low gravity world, as well, which has its own amusements.As of beta 0.2 the game has come together nicely, and become easily one of my favorites of the genre. All features appear to be working and are of (at least) average quality, with some in the above-average-to-exceptional range. There are still some hiccups (poor documentation on how to do certain things, for instance) but more or less exactly what you would expect from a beta. I have very little experience in multiplayer (aside from snagging some talented player's ISO's) so i can't comment on that.I reccomend this game with no reservations.

content:
y 13, 2015
												Only 18 hours into the game on story mode, If I was able to make a game, it would be something like this. Massive modifications available. So far, it's been low on the resources for my computer as well...Now with over 200 hours of game time...300+ with 0.9x (Alpha)With the voxel sliders, that I have made a short guide for here on Steam, you can hone your weapon long before it reaches the Enhancer a recent sword I made, Submarines, Axes and armor pieces have been added to 0.9. You can now make Axes to go with your swords, shields, bows and guns, design your own armor pieces, add ballist tanks to your boats to make them submarines... And I know I missed several added pieces.Success, when building a colony underground, you can actually save and load underground.I still stay away from the multiplayer aspect, but learned you have to join at least a multiplayer loby in order to even browse the mods and ISOs from other players.System resources still remain low for my Story mode game.... Now I am playing a0.9, Going to see how far the story goes, as they have added some new missions to the play.And I still recomend the game to anyone who is extra creative.-------------------Oct 12,19160.7 (Beta)Had my first experience with Multiplayer option Took a bit to figure out how to set up the router, Now seen and playable with those I know.My attempts to import my blade into the game have failed. with every attempt, even grabbed one from someone else.. Still unable to successfully import the ISO  *THIS HAS BEEN FIXED*-------------------February 17, 2017It's been released some time ago, yes.I had been talking to a friend about this game, they were looking at the current reviews, and seen all the negative reviews, and asked if I still loved the game, I told him yes I do. Then proceeded to share my game with him through steam's share game view.First, hopped into an online game I created, and was hosting, forgetting it was still rather new, so very few items available. He loved the graphics.Next, hopped into Build mode, unlimited supplies. used the jetpack, hang glider, tossed out a motor cycle, high speed tank, VTOL, boat, and used each, got to the boat, noticed it bobbed more than floated, hopped into the creator, fixed it, and tossed the new version into the game to keep it level. And then he said,"You really can make just about anything for the game"Then hopped into an existing single player game, went around, and got him to see the starting area creatures, and using a sword I made in the creator, with an attack of 343, I was swinging once or twice on most of the creatures and slaying them. He plays Monster Hunter as well, and his words are,"This game is a monster hunter's dream!" and "Come monday this game is MINE!"The creator is the most important function for crafting, and can really be a game changer in the long run. If you know how to make swords in Real Life, and use that knowlage to build a sword in the creator, you can really maxamize your damage output in the game, making melee the way to fight in the game. I can make a decent gun, but they aren't anywhere near as good as my swords, but the range is really good on the guns I do make, so that is a bonus.The open world aspect, even in story mode is awesome sauce!recent issue:The problem used to be traveling so fast that the ground would not be there as it resses in (in build mode), causing the vehical you are driving explode as it resurfaced (this could kill you in adventure mode) and made for a good laugh, the problem with the way it's set up now, when you reach that edge, instead of generating in front of you first, it seems to leave it wide open. Pauses your movement, and if you are in a hang glider, well, you just fall, messing up your glide range. My recomendation would be to rez what you can see first, starting in a narrow strip in front of the path you are heading, then out from there to the sides, then under the surface ground area, as needed.If you don't have at least 40 hours in story mode in the game, you really haven't gotten anywhere in the game yet. Story mode can take quite a while to complete. And being an open world, you can do what you want, when you want, there is no rushing through the game, trying to rush it, will only make you miss things, that could be considered as "hastilly put together" because you are jumping pages in the book. The game is not designed to be rushed through.The new tech with Voxels is astounding, it is ground breaking, there have been others that have tried to duplicate what is created here, and have not been even half as successful.I wanted to make my collony under ground, but with the recent changes, that isn't possible, making it so that you can't even live inside a cave opening, All collony items must be placed above ground, meaning, that even an area with an outcropping or overhang will prevent the item from being placed. Totally lame!The game was designed for Win 7, but now with Win 10, it will randomly crash, something needs to be updated to include Win 10.

content:
ber 16, 2015
Early Access Review
Planet Explorers is a super ambitious project that will probably reach most goals. Hopefully. The problem for me is not the game itself, or the direction its going in - its with the current state and the price. This is a HUGE project, and so what do you get for your twenty five bucks, right now? In my opinion, you get an unoptomized sandbox that has a moderate-albeit reasonable for the current developement state-amount of bugs and glitches. I just hope they keep going and get it done in a timely manner.This is an open world, do-whatever-you-want crafting and base building game.Pros:+Huge potential (but then again, so does nearly every other EA game)+Multiplayer could be really really fun in the future, and is even fun now, to a certain extent+The idea of vehicle crafting is awesome+The world is beautifulCons:-Personally, I think this should be first-person-Its glitchy, and in this case, is fairly bothersome (glitching through the world/builds quite frequently)-It is unoptimized. I can run it at full graphics on my gaming rig, but it sweats.-I would bet money that developement will cease before the original vision is completely met (not a bad thing, but this is ambitious)Get it on a sale, and make sure to play the demo first (I think its on their website). Problem is, the open world crafting genre is a super crowded market. You can do better.

ber 30, 2016
												Posted: Mar 26, 2014 @ 8:16pm	Updated: Sep 30, 2016 @ 1:25amUpdated Again: March, 2017EARLY ACCESS REVIEWVery cool builder. Item design system shows promise but needs a lot of polish. The crafting system as a whole takes some time to get used to, and structure building isn't really functional yet - but a damned good start!I'd like to see the updates be more substantial and frequent. Selling an EA title doesn't give the developer permission to never finish.*************************Over two years later...The game is frozen inside of some sort of engine upgrade limbo. The small studio had to outsource most of the coding change over to other studios when moving up to a new game engine. What we now have is an almost incoherent collection of low quality features that Pathea is trying desperately to tie together and smooth out. Many of updates you see are from these contractors patching their shoddy work. It is a shame. I am not sure that it can be salvaged in time for a real game to be playable.Uninstalled.*************************Three years after purchase...I do not think that the game will ever feel completed. A large price drop prior to the official release, a reduction in the frequency of updates, and the developer announcing a newly started project are all signs that this game is about done. Bugs, glitches and poorly exectuted features remain.

content:
y 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I waited and waited to review this game cause I had really high hopes for it. But after the long awaited 0.9 update I can't help but write this review, so that maybe I can save others from the useless expense that this game is.It's new year's day and I'm still on a little hangover so i'll just list what i hate as things come to my mind. Forgive possible mistakes :)- This game is overpriced. Highly overpriced.- Optimization: this game will fry your GPU even at lowest settings. I don't have a monster GPU (Radeon Dual-x R9 380) but I can run almost every game at high settings without problems. Here, at fastest settings my gpu still works 100% at 78° with fan speed over 50%.- Fastest settings will make game unplayable since fonts will become unreadable (really?!?)- Even at fastest settings I'm having random fps drops and stutters.- Character creator is always the same obvious placeholder, which was there 1 year ago or so.- Controls are clunky, would best fit for an mmo in my opinion. By the way combat and object interaction are so bad... to gather materials from plants you have to target the ground under the plant, not the plant itself... really?!?- Bindings are the most unintuitive I've ever seen. Alt+Y to open replicator menu? Really?!? Yes, you can rebind, but seriously?!?- Updates come at a slow pace and seem to just introduce more bugs. They've changed the UI several times, onlyu to deliver another clunky and unintuitive UI.- Music. It's nice for the first 5 minutes, After that you'll want to turn it off, since it's the same super-short song playing over and over again. - A LOT of backtracking, in story mode. At the beginning you won't have a vehicle to ride, but still the first quests need you to go back and forth between points that are miles away from each other. That's boring as hell.- The game, at least in story mode, never seems to demand that you build anything. What's the point of giving us the possibility of creatingour own guns and armor etc. pixel by pixel if I can just use the blueprints I find? Plus, creating object, as fun as it may seem at the beginning, it's super time coinsuming and I really cannot see myself craft more than a couple objects in an entire playthrough.- About creating weapons and such: why should dps of a weapon be based on how much material you use to create it? I mean, why should a gun that uses the same barrel (and so the same bullets, I guess) as another one do more damage just because you've put a lot more wood or anything around the barrel?!?- Monsters: You'll encounter thousands of identical monsters in each area, which makes the world boring and exploration super repetitive. Now I read they've randomized monster size, so you should have a little more diversity but it's just not enough.Is it enough?I really can't see this game getting any better, even in a year or so, plus there are a lot of better exploration and survival games that play, look and feel better than this that I really can't see the point of buying it, so beware...oh and Happy new year to everyone! =) cheers

content:
8, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game promises to be one of my favorites for quite some time.  Not only does it have most of the stuff I look for in a game, but it also allows multiplayer co-op so I can enjoy it with friends!Got this game recently and am rather enjoying it.  It is presently in alpha version a0.8 at the time or writing this, so some of its bugs are bound to work themselves out.It's part RPG, part voxel builder, part engineering CAD developer, part 4X, part tower defense, all exploration and adventure.  I have been utterly absorbed in playing it for the last few days.  I have one beef with it, though.  Companions.Throughout normal gameplay, you get tag-alongs, whether you want them or not.  You cannot control them, and they are basically along for the ride.  They are mostly benign, and will even SOMETIMES help with combat (which is nice because they cannot die like the 'hired' companions can).  There are some issues, though.The first is the pathfinding A.I.  If you are not EXTREMELY careful with where you are going, any following monster bait will get stuck... in a hole, on a tree, in the water, on a herd of turtles.  You can either clear their obstructions so they can get unstuck, or you can build an advanced piece of machinery like a car with spare seats, and HOPE they teleport to the seat.The next issue with these hoodlums is the fast travel system.  Let's say you have a waypoint that happens to be in the direction of your next quest spot(which itself is a 35 minutes walk), or just somewhere else you want to go for supplies.  If you are babysitting, you are not allowed to use this mechanism in the game without automatically aborting the quest which demands their presence.  Often, they don't go back to where you got the quest, either.  Nope.  They park themselves right there and wait.  And then you have to go find them again if you manage to get the quest once more.I'm not saying this makes the game bad or unplayable.  But, if a game developer insists on an underwater escort quest, they had better take some special measure to ensure that you don't have to spend an hour fighting water mechanics to dig out a quest giver stuck in a wall.That's it.  Just the NPCs.  Everything else about the game has drool running out of the corner of my mouth.

But honestly, its really not that important and can be easily modded in.

content:
22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Can't in good conscience recommend this game; it's just too early to say whether it'll be good, but for now it's best left alone.My entire experience in this game comes from the Story mode, so keep that in mind. My experience so far has been of sticky controls, tentative sound effects, and pretty much no combat system to speak of. In the game you can design your own weapons and vehicles (the vehicle creation is reminescent of Spore's, or any number of similar games). The system for building weapons is great, it allows for incredible aesthetic maneuverability; it falls a little bit flat when you import your gun/sword into the game and try it out. The ways the game determines what makes a sword have high damage are difficult to determine. The highest damage I've ever managed to reach came from a sword that was a literal block of metal, as big as the game would let me make it. Personally, I prefer SHARP swords, though this may be a stylistic disagreement.Likewise, my long-barrelled rifle seemed awesome and had great damage, but its accuracy was somewhere between "none" and "none at all". This would contradict the little bit I know about real-life guns, which tells me that a longer barrel = greater accuracy.I have about 19 hours of playtime in the game, and about 12 of those hours I have estimated to be travel time. It's amazing how long it takes you to get from one place to another, then back again when the quests tell you to go back. There are enough monsters on the way to keep a player docile during this transit, and the crafting can eat up a lot of time, too, since it's so detailed. What SHOULD be taking up some time is the scanning for (and mining of) resources, but I've found that to be a very arduous process. The map is huge, so when the main quest demands you make something with, say, petroleum in its schematic, you're pretty much screwed when the NPCs tell you to head west to look for oil (and the oil is southwest). I guess that's what forums are for.Then your scanner tells you the targetted resource is deep underground, and it's a pretty peaceful, Zen-like experience to use the game's terrain shaping to tunnel down into the earth. You get a palpable sense of accomplishment when you look at the big cave that used to not exist before you needed something from under it. Getting back out again is a Stygian nightmare. You will hop, you will slide, you will accidentally click and swing your pickaxe and be unable to make actions until your character is done with his animation. Eventually you will use the game's building mechanics to try to pillar-hop, like in Minecraft, except you will clip into your pillar and slide all the way down it.Then you will write an angry review for a not-nearly-finished game.

content:
er 9, 2016
												I've now played about 60 hours in story mode, most of it on the final build. In that time I've experienced one crash to desktop and three slowdowns so bad I had to quit and restart, but overall I've had a very good technical experience on max settings. The game looks great and the gameplay is fun and varied. Some of the locations are absolutely gorgeous and the design on some of the creatures is very impressive. Creation is a blast, but if you don't enjoy the process (understandable, as it does get rather fiddly) you can just as easily download ISOs or use ingame templates and items. Item creation is not a must to finish story mode, it's just another fun thing to do. The soundtrack is amazing. I'm probably buying the OST too, and that's something I've only ever done for one other game. Combat is pretty basic. Once you get decent weapons, there's not much of a threat. (Tip: almost everything can be circle-strafed to death.) There's enough of a challenge to keep it engaging, but it's not very complex. You've got your attack and defense, ranged or melee, and that's pretty much it. I'd call it elegant rather than simplistic, but YMMV.There's some negatives. The voice acting ranges from bad to atrocious, some plot twists are really awkwardly handled and most of the NPCs spend their days stuck in walls and falling through terrain. This is never gamebreaking, at least not in my case. My character does a lot of clipping through walls and getting stuck on the terrain, but never to the point where I have to reload. Neither me or an NPC have ever gotten irrevocably stuck, but it is annoying. Your own Minecraft-style buildings and vehicles can look jarringly blocky and out of place in the beautiful smooth landscape if you're not willing to spend many, many hours lovingly crafting them. Add it all up and you end up with a game that's very engaging, but not very immersive. Still, the good outweighs the bad by a very large margin, and patches are still being put out. Fan created ISOs are already out there and there's some good stuff. I'd highly recommend this game. If it looks appealing to you, give it a go.

content:
er 10, 2016
												Five and/or seven out of seven, depending on the quantum state of Dr. Allen Carter's interpretation of the afterlife.It ain't a perfect game by any means.  It's very unrefined, even after release; voiceovers of inconsistent quality, text sometimes reading more like a foreign language than English, story left open-ended, performance issues here and there, an end-game cutscene that makes the Uncanny Valley look shallow in comparison, those sorts of things.  Planet Explorers has its trouble spots, to be sure.Underneath that bit of rough, though, is a diamond, raw as it may be.  This game's got good bones.  Unlike most voxel-oriented games (including ones in the public spotlight much later), Planet Explorers offers the ability to build things on a smaller scale than terrain and buildings; vehicles, weapons, and even (to an extent) body armor are all able to be custom-designed by the player, and sharing these custom creations online with other players is an absolute breeze using the in-game workshop.  Both the pre-defined map in "Story Mode" and the procedurally-generated random maps in "Adventure Mode" offer spectacular landscapes.  The wildlife feels both familiar and alien at the same time, and the storyline - while rough in execution in many respects - is believable and engaging.Most importantly, though, is a development team that has demonstrated itself to be committed to working with players to fix problems and continually improve the game.  Communication has been bidirectional and top-notch, and the developers are quick to squish bugs as they're reported (even amid the influx of post-release feedback).All in all, a great game.  Rough around the edges, sure, but shiny and clean is for AAA shops; Planet Explorers is an example of an Early Access game gone right even amid the risk of things going horribly wrong (as tends to be the case for games with even a fraction of the scope offered by Planet Explorers).

content:
, 2016
Early Access Review
								What to say about Planet Explorers?Well, I play it since March /14 (almost in its release date, few days later).I watched some videos, seen some screnshots, and why not, right?Some indie games have a tendency of not completing its development to full release, because of a lot of reasons, but what the hell? I tried and bought it anyway.Of course I do not have a lot of hours, playing since 2014, because I tend to stop playing and watch the development, by the Devs or Youtubers, so I can have more accurate opinion about it and it give me the way to play.So, speaking about the game itself: It is a sandbox, indie, open world, survival crafting adventure (that I love most). I may be exagerating if I say that this is a better Minecraft, but this is my opinion, so yeah.You can craft components, weapons, furniture and ETC, and can build your home / base / castle / whatever. Did I mention that you can CREATE your own weapons? you can use their Voxel Tool to create the most beautiful and weird weapons and shields (weapons: sword, guns), but this doesn't stop there. You actually can create your own vehicle by the same voxel system. You have a limited box of creation, but this does not mean your creations will be limited. You can create small and large ground carriers, you can create aircraft and boats. The adventures with your own creations are so awesome!I must admit that the game have a lot missing, and I don't need to explain what is it, because, the game grow in every update released.Some may think about the update time, that it takes too long to hit Steam. I must agree on some of that, but cannot stop thinking that they are still working. I say that because I tought, long time ago (end 2014 / beginning 2015) that they gave up developing the game, because of the great delays of updates. I had uninstalled the game a lot of times, because of lack of hope, but then, I redownloaded it and played again, with new features that I didn't see it coming.Now I know one thing: they release updates, not too frequent, but when it hit Steam, the updates always come with very good improvements, and I mention bug fixes to new features.So, pleople, don't be afeared of Planet Explorers. They are working, and the game looks beautiful.I have invested in the game and it is showing its potential so far.Obs: If my words seem a little weird, I am not a native of the language, so I apologize, and no, I have nothing to do with Pathea Games.Thank you and support them.

er 7, 2016
												I really tried to like this game, I tried for 7 hours. But I just cant, I tried to look past the optimization issues, the fact that you do EVERYTHING REALLY REALLY SLOWLY, and that you will probably spend more time trying to fix it rather than play it. I thought by launch, the game was going to play well, and that it was going to be fun to play, but its just not. The story is pretty bad, the quests all comprise of "you see that person half way across the entire freaking planet? I want you to go and bring them here at the speed of a crippled snail." or sometimes its just a fetch quest, that also takes place miles away from where it started. But I kept thinking "hey, its in early access, I'll give it a pass for now.", but then  A WEEK LATER  the game came out, in the same state as it was every other time I came back to it.Also it has a horrible memory leak that has been there since I bought the game a year or so ago. Not to mention, if you decide you DONT want to play the story, and just want to screw about on your own planet, that planet that you created takes up LOTS of space on your drive, I'm talking at least 100GB, and if you happen to run out of space because of what you did on that planet, your entire save file gets wiped forever. There's no bringing it back, it just turns into a brick. Also all the font ingame is white text on a sky blue background, because thats how you make sure no one can read anything you put there.However building your own weapons and cars is pretty cool, and it has nice music. Not nice music thats worth $3.99, but it is nice music.

Early Access Review
								PROS:-Beautiful game on High settings.-Living breathing world for you to explore without limit.-Create weapons, armor, and transport, without limit.-A base/colony system.-UI is great.-A nice branching story.-Epic boss fights.-Base attacks and raids by NPCs randomly.-Multiplayer is pretty good.-Structure building is creative and is familiar to games like Minecraft.-Mining and digging.-Character Creation!CONS:-Annoying FPS-drops despite my computer fitting the system requirements.-Technical issues.-Combat system is Action-Based but still needs to be worked on.-Crafting is a bit complex.-No plants/rocks underwater.PREFERENCE:-Derpy/Wierd gather animations.-Shooting system isn't the best.-Movement system is not what I'm used to.OVERALL:This game is great in my opinion for an early access title. The only thing that brings this game down is it's technical issues,EARLY ACCESS VERDICT:7/10PREDICTED FUTURE VERDICT:8/10 - 10/10Once they fix the tech issues and add some stuff to the melee combat system.

								I don't feel the need to really put a fully detailed review here as we're still in alpha, so I will keep this short. Planet Explorers has achieved what Everquest Landmark has tried to achieve in its alpha, and has done it better. I have not had this much fun playing a game like this in a very long time. The building system is very functional and easy to use far better than even Landmark's. The creation system allows for even greater ability and customization.  Reminds me very much of Kerbal Space Program's ship creator, and even has a high level of customization options then that. What this game achieves is bringing all the best parts of Starbound, Minecraft, and Landmark and brings them into one beauitful sandbox. For Sandbox lovers, this is a must buy. I can't wait to see what this game is like in its finished state.

Early Access Review
								I've had PE for quite a while, since about two years ago. It was not very polished then, it had a fair clout of content but it was clearly very early. Years fly by and the game seems to be in development hell. Fortunately for this indie gem, it clawed it's way back thanks to a remarkably dedicated dev team, so kudos to them for that. The game itself has improved in leaps and bounds, since the long awaited v 0.14, to the current 0.4, to become much the same game but so much more polished and rounded. Truly, it has been improved to the point of becoming a good game in its own right, which sets it apart from the rest of the herd (The title screen song is a real masterstroke showing the effort and attention of the devs, again, kudos). Not only becoming a good game but really becoming fun.With a fair bit more polish, optimization, content and general improvements, this game really shows a lot of promise, rocketing past it's slow period. The real only things that let it down are twofold:One downside I can complain about (and complain I most certainly will) is the camera control. Make no mistake, things are definitely getting better, but it's still definitely a pain having to switch control methods just to talk to a character, or having to hold tab to use a cursor. This is the main irritation most of the time, which slows the pace down to a crawl unnecessarily, especially when coupled with infuriatingly limiting keybinds! (TAB REBINDABLE FOR INVENTORY PLEASE!!)The second thing I would like to quibble about is the blizzard of menus and interfaces that all do different things, with different modes of access. At least now they are all in one list but I feel a lot more work needs to be done on the GUI usability before the game will flow appropriately. While gorgeous to look at, the user interface being all over the place is becoming somewhat archaic, especially when compared to more polished/larger budget titles which, if possible, would definitely make interfaces much more enjoyable to use. (Perhaps something more like a single master interface, with tabs for inventory, character, replication, map, etc.)TLDR:This game is FANTASTIC, in so many regards, having crawled out of a period of inactivity to rise to become magnificent. If you can get past the maddening difficult-to-use blizzard of GUI, and the camera controls from the black lagoon, there is a simply stunning game there, and it is meteorically improving.

number of helpful: 10 of 11 people (91%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
er 19, 2016
												I recommend this game but with two VERY BIG caveats.1. Typos and grammatical errors are very noticable. So far while in game this has not yet been a problem though I could not not do the tutorial without a walkthrough. Caveat 1. is: Find a decent walkthrough and don't rely on in-game text to do the tutorial. It was incomprehensible in parts.2. This game has THE WORST audio I have ever experienced outside of sixth form video journalism classes. It's dreadful. But it is also hilarious. Five minutes spent clicking on people to make (clearly dev's best mate from college) say really stupid phrases over and over.Bird sounds are also rubbish, I find it immersion busting to hear magpies and pea♥♥♥♥♥ while on an 'alien' planet.That leads me to Caveat 2: Turn down the music completly and reduce the in game sounds a touch, then crank up Spotify playlist 'Cyberpunk SciFi RPG' and suddenly everything changes! You're in space on an alien planet and you no longer care that you're surrounded by breaking teenage voices. It's magic.I was minutes away from claiming a refund but something kept me playing the singleplayer story mode past the 2-hour cutoff and I'm glad I did. I love the weird story, creativity and so far questing has been pretty variable. It's not just kill seven wolves etc.I'm getting hints of space Minecraft with a bit of Albion thrown in, which was my favourite scifi fantasy game from the 90s.There is much to be improved with this game but devs are continuously updating, which is reassuring, and I do like to support indie gamesmakers.There are, two massive issues that were pushing me towards the refund I chose not to take. I think if you're going to spend £19 on a game you ought to be very aware of them first and be clear on whether you can live with the caveats above.

er 24, 2016
												I finally finished the story mode. I want to say, great job to the devleopers on creating an egaging system that keeps nerds like me wanting to go "just 5 more minutes".The game is well worth the time and money I spent on it.My biggest issues at least for story mode -- The player might need to be given more ISOs ingame to help offset the learning curve behind the creation tool. Theres a big learning curve and a major time sneak into your game as you try to figure things out.- Colony set up. After hours of gameplay and such I would say this is the biggest issue (next to mining/lumber gathering) I have. I think I would rather see the NPCs auto-fill open roles in the colony based on what their skills are. Walls didn't seem to work nor did buildings. as the NPCs just sort of ran through them and I'm sure i kept getting rained on. Along with this is player inventory and colony inventory. I feel that the player should be able to fabrecate items from ether storage location. NPCs should build more things along with what they gather. Complete ISO items, wepaons, armor, defense weapons etc. I would also remove scripts from the store(s) if the player already has it learned.- Missions. There are ton of them which is awesome. Some of them can be very . . . confusing on what to do. Probably need to introduce a more indepth mission/quest log with details of where things can be found (I'm thinking more along the line for the gathering misions). We have a monster wiki in-game, might need to expand that to include the different plants as well.- Mining/Lumbering are pretty easy from the start through out. The Drill and Chainsaw IMO are worthless with the current development behind them. So we get stuck with a space game mining ore with a pickaxe and lumber with an axe. I think, the development team might need to look at taking all the gathering tools and merge them into a single item (like the Matter Manipulator in Starbound)... The current system to me seems half baked and not thought out. We have space traveling humans, I'm sure their ship wasn't crafted by men and women farming ore with pickaxes. Some of this I understand is because they don't want us terraforming the entire planet.Overall, besides my nit picking on development choices. The game was fun and I will return to it often to spend more time... Need to perfect my colony building and location.

content:
er 12, 2016
												The way the character controls and interacts with the environment is clunky, awkard, full of "gotchas" you have to learn to avoid or end up wasting time animation locked as punishment.  Let go of the mouse while digging?  That's punished.  Trying to dig a voxel that's out of range?  That's punished.  Your character will happily spend the rest of eternity producing a dig animation on a target that both you and the game know are out of range, and this happens often since you absolutely cannot move at the same time as digging.  Very fundamental things are tedious.Movement, mining, and some very important UI interactions (the scanner in particular) are extremely poorly designed and suck the fun out of what could otherwise be a game with some unique positives.Extremely disappointed to find the entire year they went silent produced nothing in this area.  I had assumed that would be a main product of an engine rework.

								Planet  Explorers is a great exploration, mining and crafting game. It has many cool features, such as a building tool to create weapons, vehicles and buildings in a 3D modelling type engine, which is easy to use, then allows you to import them in to the game to be used. A gigantic catalog of recipes of things to build, or  buy. And of course the currency, MEAT!!!!

content:
8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Tired of the simplicity of Minecraft and sick of waiting for Starbound?  Sick of Zombies and tired of Bambi killers but still want to survive and thrive?  I know I was, and boy am I glad I stumbled onto this.  I feel like I may have passed it over in the past because of bad reviews but as they had recently taken an upturn I decided to give it a shot.Now I can't speak to the multiplayer aspect (As it's in alpha I can only assume it's sketchy at best, but that's to be expected.) but the single player is excellent, the story (which I'm only a few missions into since I jumped right into adventure mode at the start) has been interesting so far.Here's a few aspects that make me want to play this over minecraft clones:Need creature parts but tired of running around hunting?  Set up some turrets and throw down a creature lure.Tired of running everywhere?  Build a rudimentary vehicle and ride into the sunset.Ten story creature?  Grab allies, outfit them with whatever you can find/buy/create yourself, make turrets, tanks and Take. It. Down.I'm only twelve hours in and have barely done more than get iron weapons, a few turrets, and dug a few really impressive tunnels (Which I was way more proud of than anything I ever built in minecraft.) and made a few rudimentary shelters to keep the rain off my head (which didn't work, it is [or was when I wrote this] an alpha.).  You can also build gods-know-what in the creation engine which is far too daunting for me to even touch at the moment, or if creating from scratch isn't your thing I'm sure you'll be able to download untold numbers of things others have created via steam in the future (Or now sans-steam with a little know-how).All in all you should keep an eye on this one, and if you have the extra cash go ahead and buy it.

ry 20
												I booted this game up again recently and played through the story mode.I really enjoyed it, so it took about 44 hours.Looking forward to more story, but it plays well to this point, with a rich storyline.Graphics are good and gameplay is similar to a mmorpg style control system.Part of the fun of the story was investigating the event that preceeded your arrival to the planet, even outside game I was thinking about what had happend based on the evidence I had at the time.Building your own bikes, cars, aircraft and aquatic vehicles was also great, though I admit mine were mostly just adjustments from the useful templates. I didn't get around to building Cloud's Buster sword, but I'm sure I'll look into later.Run down of the gameplay:I started with a stone knife and leather armor, got a jetpack and enjoyed flight the first, built a small helicopter and got shot down by the locals. Built up a base and then packed it up and moved it to a more defensible location.Built a train track halfway across the map and fought some sea critters becuase why not?All in all, for the pricetag you get an adventure and some fun game mechanics, which, while not perfect, are fun to explore.

number of helpful: 15 of 21 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
19, 2014
												Finally!  A totally open world game which allows infinite possibilities.  This game is delivering upon the potential of the ambitious concept. I cant recommened it highly enough.You want an open world game?.  This game allows you to do almost anything.  You gather resources,   many types of resources.  You can make everything and anything. You can use pre made designs. Download others designed by players or design your own from scratch.   The only limit I found is that I couldnt build the nuclear missiles I wanted.  Battleship? Fine.  Stealth fighter, fine.  Motorbike, Star wars style land speeder, Monster trucks and madcap mash ups all fine.  Works really well.You want base building?  You can do anything.  Thought the style is a little tiny bit limiting it is vast.  It is somewhere between the complexity of Landmark (which most people cant use well) and other games with more simiplified base building such as Ark.  A nice middleground allowing the free use of imagination to create some awesome settlements towns and fortified structures.  Great fun and probably the thing I get most distracted by.  I am crazy about base building in games like this and Ark. You want to explore?  Ok, 2 sides to this.  It is a massive area to explore. You will soon realise you need to develop and get vehicles though nothing stops you wandering on foot.   Hostile alien races and local wildlife abound and the whole thing feels very nicely balanced.  It doesnt feel like a world setup to support your game but a world you literally found yourself in and now you have to survive and thrive.  This works well too. Sound?  I love the title theme loop (now with some beautiful vocals to make it one of the best game themes I can remember) and the in game sounds are all well done.  I think overall the sound effects could havemore attention to atmospherics but it is a small criticism and it was done well enough not to be any sort of problem.   One absolutely stand out moment is the (in my opinion) very beautiful opening title music.  It really sets a nice an atmosphere and is a beautiful piece of music in its own right.   I wish it was a longer track as I like it a lot. Probably the only real criticism I have is the NPCs in the game.  They just seem like props.  This was a lost opportunity.  If they actually went and did more with astmospheric sounds supporting it, settlements would have felt much more alive.   This is not a major issue because of the nature of the game,. later they will be doing stuff at your direction but for a long time they feel less alive.Graphical?  Erm. Interesting one this, It uses nothing in terms of the capability I have, yet somehow, strangely, it is enough. Its not great, it's not bad. Its alright. I should say, that the only relatively limited aspect is character creation but this is not a big deal, though I try to stay in first person.I have been having a smooth experience for a while for the most part but there does seem to be a few serious bugs still in the game but not so many that it stops me playing and miles ahead of many other games. This is a game you will have installed for years and will keep coming back to.  Bang for buck, fun and for the open world nature of the game, I cant recommend this enough to people who like;Open WorldResource GatheringSettlement Building and DevelopmentDesigning Vehicles and EquipmentExplorationLongevity and good value.One of the best games of its type and the best pre release game I ever purchased in terms of meeting all expectations and delivering the game that was promised at the end of it.Overall though, This games development  reminds me of PC gaming pioneers in the days before you just wrote a game to rip people off on Xbox Live.  This is a magnum opus and you should all be very justifiably proud of yourselves.   I dont think I have ever been so effusive in my praise for any game and nor would I be if it did not deserve it.

I simply cannot understand the reviews for Planet Explorers.It is such a brilliant game, and has...🚀 1, the best vehicle, (Air ground, and water, underwater) And weapon building system in any game ever.🚀 2, A real sense of "being on a strange planet."🚀 3, A brilliant story, with missions, and quests.🚀 4, A HUGE play area, open world map.🚀 5, A choice between Story mode. Creative mode, or adventure mode.🚀 6, Beautiful music. 


YouTube™ Video: Planet Explorers Theme with Vocals 

			Views: 3,020		

			Lyrics: I see now a bright horizon A world once beyond the reach of man I reach now for the unknown And set foot down on virgin soil What gemstones hide in your rivers?		

🚀 7, 3rd and 1st person perspective.🚀 8, Lovely graphics.🚀 9, Great in-game foraging (mining / harvesting etc system, to facilitate the design / build you own gear system.🚀 10, Workshop support, where you can download other peoples vehicles, and weapon designs. (in the form of "ISOs.") Planet Explorers,  has a real "oldschool" adventure vibe.In fact the only thing I REALLY wish the devs would add is VR support.But they have said they wont, which is a REAL shame, as it would be utterly Amazing in VR. ⛔But for none VR fans, this is a fantastic game. I have most of the BIG "survival games." (minus horror and zombie titles which I do not like.)And this is one of the very best IMHO. Dont believe all the negative reviews.🌟Really solid game that will give you many hours of "planet exploring" fun, action, and immersion.🌟

								I would like to state I have only played this game for a small amount of time, so I am not the most experienced with this game and have not seen all features.A very interesting concept, space age open world where you can gather rescources and build like minecraft, a somewhat open world like skyrim, and a diversity of species similar to spore.Pros:- A simple crafting system, took a few minutes to figure it out, but easy for anyone to understand- More creatures than you would expect, where else can you be chased by a horde of four-armed baboons then have a bird-like dragon swoop down mid-chase to try and kill you, AND THEN be chased and killed by a wart-hog monster the size of a tree- The graphics are not ground breaking, but it's something you can appreciateCons:- The character customization is almost non-existant: four faces, eight hair styles (some don't connect to the skull fully), and no different body shapes, but you can change your skin and eyes from white to black from green to purple. Of course there will be issues of some nature, but if you're expecting otherwise, don't buy it because you will be dissapointed because you didn't know better.
