Early Access Review
								(Excuse the low hours showing, most of the playing was in offline)I have been on and off playing this for at the time of writing around two and a half years.  Waiting patiently for it to come out.The first thing I would like to point out is although work has been slow, the devs have been open with their plans and realistic in their aims with only occasional lapses in communication - I don't mind waiting in cases like this where a dev is up front and honest.Do I trust them to continue working on this? yes.Second big point is that the real joy of this game is once you get your bearings exploring and finding out about the world, it feels expansive, majestic and just different enough to always feel alien.The Immersion is the selling point for me, I could build a helicopter and fly up a mountain just to park up and watch the sunset and listen to the music.Thirdly, the AI and the building system. Not great at the moment, but I prefer to forge ahead solo in my own creations so in this respect I'd like to point out how generally unobtrusive parts of the game that you have no interest in can be. It doesn't effect my fun.

content:
er 19, 2016
												Planet Explorers is a game full of adventure. The game has your basic 3 playable modes: single player, multiplayer and design modes. I been playing the game for several months and followed the updates.  The main story line is a exploration spaceship crash landing on a "unknown" planet. Your quest is to create your own colony while trying to figure out the reason behind the crash. The story line has several hours of different types of quests. Like other games of the genre, the story line will have quests such as protection, escort, and gathering. What really sets a side planet explorers story mode, is the design of the building system in the sense that you as a member of the crew, that is now scattered through out the continent, are in charge of creating you very own colony. The creation of the colony is not a location specific task, meaning that you create it where you want. That freedom is one of my favorite aspects of the game. You can recruit almost all the members of your crew, even make some of them your companions. The colony system will allow you to manage your colony and colonists according to your desire. While not all the materials are produced at the colony, you are able to assign jobs to your colonists. After creating the appropriate machinery they can farm, train or work at a factory. Certain characters will have perks that will boost some of the tasks, combat and healing. The game features a nice menu with easy navigation making it very easy to manage your colony. You have access to this menu from every location but some of the tasks require you to be within the colony e.i. storing or retrieving items. You can even recruit some of the vendors to your colony giving you easy access to some of the prime materials needed to create whatever you want. The other highlight of the game is the creation system. This is a design system where you can design your very own vehicle. The game allows boats, ground and air vehicles. It also allows the creation of robots, tools and weapons. The creation system allows single or passengers vehicles that will increase in fire power, speed and durability depending on the parts added to the design. A lot of components of the game rely on electric charge and will deplete over time. Some of the more complex designs require a lot of work to create all the parts, but they are some shortcuts like purchasing from vendors. I only have played the single player in exploration and story modes. Exploration is a randomly or pre-generated map where you can play with out the basic main story line. AI still offers quests and AI colonies are generated for both friendly and unfriendly races.  I purchased Planet Explorers as a early access. The game is now in V1.0.3. I can say with confidence that Pathea followed through and I am very pleased with the purchase.  If you are unsure about the game please try the demo. It offers around 2 hours of story and it should give you a good idea if the game is for you.

content:
7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is SO much fun. I've been having a blast playing it in both single player (adventure and story mode) and multiplayer with friends over the past week. REALLY glad I bought this- for an alpha version of the game it's surprisingly polished, and so far I haven't found any bugs at all which is amazing. I've beta tested a TON of games over the past 15 years and I'm always finding bugs to report, but so far, I've found nothing. The dev's are really quick to update it too when something breaks, they're really on their game which is a refreshing change from a lot of the 'early access' games on steam that don't see updates for months at a time. One evening, the animation for chopping trees broke. I went to sleep, and it was fixed the next day! I got this on sale, but I dare say, it's worth the full price for how much time and care thats being put into this. It's like Minecraft and Landmark had a baby with the space adventures of Terraria/Starbound thrown into the mix. All my friends who play Minecraft with me love this game to pieces and we've actually been playing this a lot instead! The ONLY thing I would add is that I wish there was more weapon/armor variety IN the game, BUT with the ability to create stuff out of voxels (called/saved as ISO's) you can make or download a TON of fantastic stuff that have been made by users, so it's not even a big issue really. The game doesn't have some decor you want? Build it, or find it on the workshop! Absolutly amazing. And so far, the community has been VERY friendly and helpful- I really hope it stays that way.

content:
27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pretty fantastic game with interesting alien plant and animal analogues to Earth. The crafting is extensive but might need to be fine-tuned. You can build everything from a wooden shovel to a helicopter. Just exploring is half the fun but watch out for the other hostile alien race also trying to colonize the planet! Even though it has a lot of fine polishing to be done and it's not very easy to figure out how the crafting system works at first, I highly suggest buying the Early Access, as what I've seen and played shows great promise. You can play a story mode (which isn't finished currently) or an adventure mode that gives you more freedom and more than you'll have at the beginning of the story mode. There are also multiplayer servers where you can play Survival Coop, Survival PVP, or just build in peace. You can play using the seed of Planet Maria or a random seed to test your luck and so you have more control over the environment you'll be "living" on. There's a demo, so it doesn't hurt to at least check it out. 4/5 for me, because while the game is crazy-awesome at the moment, it still needs some polish and it will get that in the months to come.

								amazing game!!! probably one of the best games i’ve played in a long time, there is so much you can do. its like minecraft and terraria had a baby, then that baby had a baby with pure awesome. the different game modes are great, story mode gives you a good feel for the game and is pretty fun to play through. but what makes this game amazing is the creative side, loads of items to create/ replicate, but the actual creation mode within the game OMG. pretty much think of something you want to make and bam you can do it. want a sick looking car just make it. theres a bit of a learning curve with it but it doesn’t take long to get the hang of. Could not recommend the game more!! if your into adventure/exploration in open world get it, if your into creating/design get it. loads of fun THANK YOU to the devs you guys have done an insane job on the game so far!!! keep up the good work :)

content:
15, 2014
Early Access Review
								After a couple of less-than-stellar experiences with alpha/early-access/kickstarter games, I was pretty much set in the "never again" camp. A friend told me that I _really_ should check out Planet Explorer, given he knew how much I love sandbox games. This game - even at the alpha stage is, to put it mildly, absolutely amazing. Many, many years ago, an essay was written in the MMO community called "Let me bake bread" - in short, it said a _great_ video game lets the player play as _they_ want: Be that fighting, building, exploring, crafting or socializing. This game has it all (well, maybe not quite the socializing, but I haven't played multiplayer). The visuals are beautiful; The build system is limited only by your imagination and the content in the game - again, even at this early stage - reinforces both the suspension of disbelief and wonder.I could not be more pleased with this game. If you are a sandbox game lover, you will not go wrong with Planet Explorer.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
2014
Early Access Review
								Steam is being flooded by sandbox exploration games right now. Next to starbound, this is one of my favorite. It still needs more work, but even in its current state, it is a lot of time sucking fun. What sets this game apart from others of its kind is that it is NOT 2D (its Voxel shaded...i don't really know what that means...) and the construction system. You can actually build cars and motorcycles in the game (as well as aircraft, eventually). You don't just collect the resources and then put it together at a crafting table, however...you use the in-game design tools to design how your vehicle will look, down to the paintjob and decals. My first vehicle was a model-T looking car with a huge turret, and 6 wheels to support all its weight. In addition to the construction system, you also have a massive and interesting environment, populated by a whole host of strange animals...like 6 armed fire-breathing bears. The music is also quite relaxing. There's a story-mode which makes it all the more interesting, as well.

content:
6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Initially I was unsure about the game. You might be to. The UI is clunky, windows don't stay where you put them, fast travel breaks things, etc etc... welcome to alpha. KEEP GOING ANYWAY. They are making a tremendous effort to voice act the whole game. I found myself actually listening to the quests. I am enjoying a storyline that is becoming increasingly compelling as you not only struggle to rescue stranded colonists but unravel the secrets of this world. It is truely a gem. However in the interest of disclosure I am playing alpha 0.752. So I will list the pros and cons given this version, so that you can decide for yourself if its worth the money.Cons:- Alpha bugs (these will go away but player beware them) Fast travel breaks quests and resets window location. In fact theres a long list of bugs, many specific to a persons game. None of them were game breaking for me personally. Very polished for an alpha imho.-Mining is INCREDIBLY slow. Painfully even if you've ever played minecraft. If you think you are going to change the basic terrain in any meaningful way, you are wrong.-AI is often baffeling. They apear to be nearsighted and terrified of jumping over obsticals. Often I found them on an impossibly vertical surface stuck in place. Time to break out the pickace and carve em off, slowly though, because the pickaxe does nothing quickly. Or just standing around uselessly while I fire away at giant robots getting cut to ribbons by death lasers because they can't see far enough away to be useful. Same goes for turrets, which more often than not get blown up before even firing. Layerback quest is poorly designed as one of the npcs is not invincible and imediately dies unless you bury him in a hole and cover him over. Alpha is alpha.-VTOL (Vertical Take Off and Landing) design has basically nothing to do with reality, and a redesign of the controls for making them in general could use a looksee. You can do it, its just not easy to scale parts, and they don't go bigger than their original size... you'll see what I mean. They fly like they're on rails, and really need tuning up to 'feel' more realistic. See: Battlefield 2142 transport.- Geometry in general. There is no ryhme or reason for running through the base of trees. Accessing the meat from a carcase is an artform not a science. ETC. I'm guessing this is an alpha issue as well but if they don't go back soon and unfrak the situation its going to be a depressing amount of work later for the devs.-Grass... the amount is as staggering as it is GPU shattering. The sensativity of the levels isn't intelligent. Theres basically several options including: none, Too much, holy good god, 1fps, and the all important personal home computer melter level in case ur tired of your pc. I set it at too much. I advise you to do the same, unless you're running a quantum based supercomputer.Pros:-Amzaing story with believable motives, and real characters, which you actually care about because its...-Voice Acted. Hoorah for immersion. Keep it up. Some bits are misssing here, especially when traveling and they randomly talk. I really hope they continue with this effort because everyone who's ever played another MMO has been in a TL;DR accept, kill, turn in kinda mood. This game slows it down, and makes you care, without pulling teeth. Its glorious.-Great Characters. Had to add this on its own. Everyone is believable, at least human-side. Very important to stay away from the classically "I'm evil, because I'm a jerk like that. No reason." *Kicks a puppy*-Build your own: Vehicles ground and air, swords, shields, guns, and more with a voxelbased system that with a little more time and polish will have you wondering: How do I port this to my 3d printer?-Mining, hunting, farming, gathering, crafting, building, sandbox explosion of fun. Some people just wanna horde a million items. Personally I think its a bit in depth, and found myself just buying the finished products... which you can do. So play it how YOU like. Something there for everyone.-Varied quests. Nothing is a grind, everything has a point. None of the go here kill 40 of these because I want their guts for garters crap. If you are gathering, exploring, or killing its for a reason. IE: learning to craft something new, saving a colonist who will sell you some new interesting gear, so on and so forth.-Hang Glider. I know you are wondering, if I've got space copters with lazer beams, why do I need a hang glider? Trust me, once you get this baby and a jetpack, you'll be sold on this game. Soaring through the trees (Which you can't run into don't worry ^.^) you'll notice the terrain is actually quite beautiful.-Fully developed universe. It has history, conflicts, and you get to learn about it all. More than that it effects you, and I found myself going from npc to npc just to find out more about the lore. Tedious reading goodbye. 90% voice acted so the story is 'told' by the characters who its happening to. Immersion is not just important but an expectation these days, and Pathea aims to deliver.-Critters. Mobs. Animals? are varied, interesting, and best of all, capracious. Initially I started with the  run and gun, and getting myself murdered, because they designers clearly favor realism, and I have the suicidal heroistic tendancies of most gamers. Then I found myself cautiously aproaching new life forms. Everything has a power level, and some are over 9000. Descretion is important, almost as much as learning to run like hell. I apreciate this, however some of you would put this in the con group. Some of you can bugger off.Theres more to it, this is a highlights list. I'm telling you I've played enough games to wonder what I'm doing with my life... and I recommend this game, even in its alpha form. Give them your money, and say goodbye to the next week until you come up for air.This is sgmongo, signing off.

content:
19, 2014
Early Access Review
								This has to be one of the best games i've played in a while, Although the game is in Alpha stage and some patches fix things and some break things, It has alot of potential to go forward and become an outstanding game.You have a single player mode where you follow the story line and interact with NPC's to perpare yourself for whats to come.You can build weapons from scratch using the build mode, Providing you have the resources and the same for ground and air transport.The game offers,Single player story line, Mining, resource gathering, mob hunting, base building, designing anything from sword to pistols to 4 barrel guns, how ever you want to design them, the more damage the weapon the better. You can also build Cars, helicopters and so on. Disign it how you want it to look. It also has crafting of items that you will need in the game, from spades to mining tools, lights, food and much more.The game also has Multiplayer, which includes all the above with either Co-op or PvP.Work as a team to build a base and defend it from the many mobs in the game or fight your fellow players in PvP destroying there base and taking it to the wire.It has a great community who are willing to help those who need the help and the game has so much more to add.With patches and improvements adding to the game to improve it, and much more to come.I recommend anyone who understands Alpha phase games to join in and get on board to make this the best open world RPG out there, you will have alot of fun. If you like Minecraft and those types of games. There are bugs as there are with many Alpha games, but this is more polished then most i've played of late. Including some currently on steam.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								You're trying to seed human life on a new world. As you descend, your ship collides with what looks like some sort of magic hover city, destroying both it and your ship. Small life pods eject, sending those who weren't killed in the first explosion down to the surface to try their damndest to survive.That's where you begin.Help your fellow crewmates heal their injuries and collect together, defend against the occasional monster stampede and assemble a fortress to protect those who remain as you struggle to secure life, and begin the existence you intended from the start. Will you make friends with the indingenous sentient species? Can you even survive their outrunners long enough to try? Learn designs to assemble all the things needed to live well and comfortably, from huge laser cannons that rest on top of your most vulerable buildings to eggshell chairs like people loved in the 1970s, you eventually learn it all from your friends and potential new allies.But there is more danger than you might think at first.Beware, explorer, the depths of the forests for they hold creatures I can only refer to as like the Chimeras of S.T.A.L.K.E.R. fame. Oceans, fish that could eat blue whales in 5 bites. The skies conceal huge birds, but a quick wit and a well-maintianed rifle can nearly keep you even from being harmed by them.What will you build? An impenetrable steel fortress with 30 foot walls that stand in mocking defiance of the local beasts? An underground compound filled with laberynthine passages and high-tech facilities? A huge golden tower gleaming in the sun, staring down from a huge mesa or mountainrange?That's for you to decide.The only thing the makers of the game care about, is you enjoy their carefully crafted world of make-believe.

content:
2015
Early Access Review
								Being as I'm a classic science fiction fan, this game immediately jumped out at me.  Of course, I had to get it and it was money well spent.  It has been a long time since a video game has given me such a sense of wonderment, perhaps not since The Dig, way back in the dark ages.  I found the writing to be well done, with an interesting storyline to go along with the fun of exploring an alien world and designing the vehicles in which you explore.  The designs of the various alien animals remind me of the works of sci-fi and wilderness artist Wayne Barlowe.  I would highly recommend Planet Explorers to any sci-fi gamer.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								At a glance, Planet Explorers feels a lot like another MMO.  This is especially true if you play Adventure mode.  Not being all that into MMOs myself, I was at first a little wary.  Soon enough, however, the lovely scenery, interesting aliens, and a crafting system that has a variety of levels of depth, and I was already humming along and happily harvesting plants.The crafting system is excellent.  There is a basic level, where you learn "scrips" and then build objects out of stuff that is in our inventory.  Then there is a deep level, where you can build any 3D object you want and it becomes available in the game.I also really enjoyed the aliens.  Especially at first, you never know what an alien is going to do till it sees you.  Then you learn really quick.  The scale of aliens is also great.  There are beings tiny like us meek humans, and towering giants that either ignore you, or quickly put you out of your alleged mysery.  This game can only go up as it gets more and more polished.  I'm happy to be in somewhere near the ground floor!

content:
15, 2014
Early Access Review
								One of the best Early Access games I've played to date. There is a lot of content here. Offline the single player has a storyline where you take quests and learn the ins and outs of crafting. There is also an Adventure Mode where the world is procedurally generated and you have to explore and survive with only a handful of NPC villagers.Online works as well. You can play on a server for adventure, versus or just building with unlimited resources.You can also create your own buildings in build mode as well as create custom vehicles and weaponry with their in game creation system. It's quite robust, albeit a bit clunky at first.The game still has a way to go, with some UI and camera issues to iron out as well as more character customization options. Like I said, it's one of the best Early Access games you can play now and with content and updates coming regularly it's must have for anyone who enjoys adventure with mixed with crafting.

content:
7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is really rough for how expensive it is. Once you get beyond the nice visuals, you are shocked at how bad it is. Multiplayer is atrocious and not even worth mentioning. Completely broke. Here is a short lisr of complaints in the single player. - Your own turrets target and kill your own followers- Can't take you followers mining, they get stuck in a hole and never get out, end up having to dig a nice smooth ramp up to rescue them.- larger trees have no collision detection, you can walk right into center  and through them completely- No collision detection. While swinging a sword you swing through the mob and end up having to stop and turn around and re-target, because its now behind you. Main attack mode is to swing at air and hope you hit something.- Quest box will not resize to accomidate addl quests- Quest box will not stay in position place indicated, always returns to the default center of screen after any action (ie fast travel)- Quest box will not move to end of screen if you have more than 3 cuurently- NPCS on escort missions are unkillable. Why am I escorting them if they can't be killed?- Hit boxes way to small. Chopping a tree, looting a corpse, picking a flower, all impossible unless you are perfectly positioned, takes multiple positioning attempts  to complete menial tasks like picking herbs.- Beds actually hurt you and not heal, tooltip lies. there is no reason to sleep, except remove darkness.- Food hurts you? Eating food you lose health to regain stamina, you have to eat some food then use a bandage to recoup lost health. - only x and y position mapped, not z, so if I'm underground mining and a monster is on surface, it kills me.- monsters bounce around with no weight to them. I see huge rhinos walking on top of trees effortlessly, consider making larger beasts unable to float.-npcs have blue exclamations over their head and no actual quests for you General - Why is my char able to carry 9999 rock, 9999 stone, 9999 swords, and 9999 suits of armor? Storage is useless since your char can carry every single item in game on them. Nothing in the game has any weight or quantity restriction, besides the 9999 limit- Game is too easy. No penalty for dieing. I can craft 20 revive potions and defeat any monster in game with a wood sword. too be fun it must be a challenge. When I die send me back to a starting point, or penalize me in some way.- Why is ore immediately available for crafting. It should have to be smelted, refined, or processed in some way.-music is annoying, consider more than two 30 seconds tracks on constant loop.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
12, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is a very unique game. While it does come with several short-comings which I will discuss later, the game itself is very well rounded and based on a sound survival tactical idealism that is reminiscient of minecraft, but has dutifully ascended to what Minecraft could never quite achieve; and it's still not complete!Before I dive into what I truly love about Planet Explorers, it would only be fair if I start with a few of it's shortcomings. The first thing is the fact that early game survivability is ridiculously odd, with a botchy combat system and not quite complete progression, this game lacks any motivation to keep on playing past the bad in hopes of reaching something good. Not to mention how ridiculously easy it is to aquire the best gear in the game through the incomplete store function. Sure, while the ability to design your own vehicles and weapons is cool, it's not really something to be all that impressed about, it's very linear about voxel placement and the damage to size ratio is far off to say the least.But putting all of that on the back burner, I would like to now dive in to what I thought was amazing about the game, and the reasons that I kept playing through the faults. The in-game world is beautifully designed, and provides motivation to explore and just admire the scenery. The colony function allows you to find people out in the wildnerness who you can ask to join you and before you know it, you can get a whole group of people following you around. The combat system is great, but part of the problem with it is just how poorly animated it is, but that's very easy to put aside. The animals and aliens in this game are not only well designed, but also are varied in appearance and combat strategy, it will make it difficult to say raid an alien colony without preparation, and it makes your troubles worth it in the end. With a good story mode and great functionality for a game that's still unfinished, it's hard to point out that many faults in it. And even then, to find anything really wrong with the game I had to nitpick.If I was going to rate this game, I'd have to give it at least a 7/10.

content:

Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is a 3D RPG adventure game where you can explore, gather, hunt, harvest, build, and do some questing. It's still in progress, but so far it's rather enjoyable, though I look forward to its further development. This game is fairly fun to play so far, though it could use some FPS optimization. The game has developed nicely thus far, however, and I expect and look forward to quite good things for this game.It has three modes: Story Mode, where you do the main questline & sidequests, Adventure Mode, which plays differently, and allows you to build your own colony with NPCs, and finally, Build Mode, where you can build whatever you'd like, and you receive infinite resources.Nonetheless, it's enjoyable so far, and I think many people will like this game.

content:
15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Scroll Down For older review from March 15 2014.I recently replayed Planet explorers early this year, I was kind of worried about the new changes seeing as in my mind the development for the a0.9 build is going at a snails pace, as expected with a overhaul update however even though I cannot add anything new to the earlier review I made in March 15 2014 I have to retract my statement on underpowered custom weapons, it took me a few hours of just watching other players to realize that the aesthetics of a weapon also effect it's stats... To the people who were swayed away from this game for that earlier statement I must say I am sorry for my Ignorance.Secondly, when I was saying the monsters are overwhelming in my review I was meaning for extremely early game players or people who, at the time, like me, did not know how the custom weapons worked, after about 30 minutes of playing most mobs will be a cake walk to kill if you spent your time in the editor for rifles.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------When I first got this I expected it to be alot like minecraft just with (proper) RPG elements thrown in. What I got was a game that I can say I truly enjoy. [Pros and Cons listed below]Pros-Outstanding musicEngaging storylineConstant updatesOk-great graphicsDiverse mobs and floraColony Systemmassive worldNpc Party System--------------------------------Now for the bad parts.-------------------------------Cons-Construction can be confusing at timesThe creation system is only good for shields and vehicles (underpowered custom weapons)The feeling of being overwhelmed at times by the sheer number of activitiesVoxel based construction makes tunnels a nuisance to build-----------------------------------------Time for the barely noticeable bits.-----------------------------------------Ill noticed Cons-Drunk walking (from time to time the character decides to not walk in a straight line)Anchored Vehicles (the vehicles tend to slam themselves into the ground when moving over terrain) [Choppers not effected] Suicidal Vehicles [Caused By Anchored Vehicles] (vehicles like to damage themselves if not properly suspended from the ground in the creator)Npcs go brain dead from time to time.Ill noticed Pros-Hillarious glitches (In my mind thats a pro)--------------------------------------------------Cons for minecraft fan boys and girls-It takes a while to get resources, this is a game of patience not one that the creators expect you to speed run.Overwhelming enemies, the creators of this game really want you to show caution when playing.--------------------------------------------------Final Judgemenet--------------------------------------------------In the end I'd give this game a 8/10      [NOTE: Review is subject to change as the game progresses through its updates]

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
15, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is HUGE. Massive. The first game to really drop me on an untammed planet and just tell me "Hey, heres some crap you can do, now go do crap." I feel incredibly unrestricted. This game has already more than impressed me, and I havent even managed to do ANYTHING noteworthy. Feels like the beginning of minecraft all over again; So impressed with my dirt box mudhut that I forget how awful I am and truly just enjoy the exploration.Surviving isnt exactly hard. The enemies dont exactly come searching you out, and running from most the land monsters is fairly easy... Until you ♥♥♥♥ off something bigger than you. But you learn to only make that mistake once or twice. You learn very quickly how you SHOULD act to survive. Taking damage is always very serious, and ranged weapons become your new best friend, despite how much fun I would have running around and cutting things to bits with a sick sword, the game gives me a good realistic slap in the face to remind me that these creatures are fundementally stronger than me, and will kill me in a simple swordfight through outright hurting more. Guns and bows give you the good range to distance yourself enough to have a fighting chance, and you can switch to a melee weapon to do more damage when they get there. (Though usually I panic and just jump around like an idiot still trying to shoot them)Building a camp isnt entirely manditory during the early parts of the game. Most of your time is spent running around and exploring. I love that. The game doesnt try to chain you down to a spot, and really enforces the idea of going and exploring. They give you scanners, and maps to help you find your way back, so getting lost isnt a huge worry either, the map has landmarks you can fast travel to and find your footing from there. And the scanner helps you find veins of ore to dig to, so you dont have to search forever to find ore, and then huddle around it thinking its the only one you'll ever find. Even still you can mark locations on your map to remind you where it is. Now you dont HAVE to explore, and it is definitely possible to hide in a small radius, but the game gives you plenty of incentive, and doesnt punish you at all for doing so. Its really all about how you want to play the game.The building system is really cool. It is flawed in places for now, I do feel a bit restricted as I havent found a way to make rigid edges and square corners (However I could have missed that part in the tutorial, which is screens of text with pictures, kind of a scary sight for gamers these days as it has been established that reading is the bane of our existence). That said, it is a sort of lego system, but you can build weapons, shields, guns, vehicles, etc. Though Ive noticed building something cool, like a Katana for example, is somewhat punished because I could never make it as strong as any premade weapon. Same with shields. I did for a while favor the weaker weapon due to the bond I had with it, crying at enemies asking them to die faster because it looked cool (It didnt work :'<  ). In addition, I wish there were some premade vehicles that I could just use until I get the hang of creating my own, while it does make sense for my first vehicle to be a piece of crap that looks like it has less thought put into it than a dune buggy (Basically just a frame since I kept dying in game while using the build menu). All in all the building is a cool idea, and could be better with just a few tweaks here and there. Importing models made from others online would also be INCREDIBLY cool. For example, someone could make themselves some halo vehicles, or a ferarri and share it with friends online.This game is just straight up one of the best sanbox games so far. The only thing they are missing are all the people on the sidewalks in GTA or Saints Row to run over and giggle while they go "thumbapdubabubadump" off the hood of your car. Definite reccoment, as it sits right now, its a 3.5/5 game, but thats as its incomplete form, I can forsee a 4.5 or 5/5 in the future if they keep going at this rate. Cant wait for the planned Mod Support, as you may be able to tell from my icon, I would adore some... Racial mods :3

content:
13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Had this game for months before Steam release (so don't let my playtime fool ya), and I have to say its one of the more fully developed Early Access titles on here. It shares a lot in common with a ton of other games in the same genre, but does a few things a bit differently and does those things incredibly well. The creation system is, hands down, one of the coolest user creation systems I've ever come across. You can, and probably will, spend HOURS building cool things. And these cool things aren't just for decoration..........you will be driving them, flying them, shooting them or swinging them. Wanna make a replica of the Millennium Falcon? Go for it. Wanna create Ecto 1 from Ghostbusters? Have at it. Build a giant race track so you and your friends can race your crazy user built race cars? Ya, its in there. To anyone who ever loved spaceships and Legos........you have found your new favorite game.

content:
13, 2014
Early Access Review
								So if you could not tell, it's minecraft on crack, addicting, fun, a small learning curve, took me only 10 minutes to get a full understanding of controls and the build system, be warned though, it is still very much in alpha, and may be there for quite a while, as the AI, enemys, turrents, and even digging are very bad. I seriously doubt this won't be changes in the future, because it is so bad an ally will walk into the wall for an endless amount the time, same with enemys, turrents will shot into the ground if the enemy entired sight than walked into a lower point then is visable to the turrent. One of my biggest problems is the lack of challange of "explore" mode, all crafting items(weapons, armor, so on) is giving to you off the bat, and you simply have to go out and find the mats. The enemys are randomly spawned, so sometimes a huge monster will spawn right outside the base, and the NPCs seem to kill it without taking any damage, OH and when you first spawn in you fall to your death and respawn on the spot I believe they intend for you to spawn, everytime, dont know if that is just me. For myself, I never played this type of game, and minecraft did not interest me past day 1. But I have to say, this game looks pretty good, but I also see it getting boring after story mode ends, hopefully explore mode gets a little harder. In the end I recommend it for all the things they are throwing at you for $25 and what this game will be once it is completed.Edit 1: You can build a wall(you can build these anytime, anywhere BTW) around a monster and then  delete a single stone and shoot it from a safeISH distance away, I would like to see that fixed but I don't really know how that can be with the free build system, I don't know I suppose it is your game and you can play it how you choose. :/Edit 2: Multiplayer and more on explore mode. So I guess they have a "shop" in the right hand corner in both co-op multiplayer and explore where oh most all the items in the game are for sale. In explore mode you start right by a gold mine site every single time, I learnt this well playing legit over and over, and once I found the shop, if you clear that mine of gold out, you can buy yourself anything from the shop. Same with online co-op so it kinda just feels like easy mode. Also there is a quick travel if you did not realize. Open map and left click on a house icon. In the end this game seems kid/noob friendly. There is no difficult part besides walking from point A to point B until you can quick travel there in story, and unless you force yourself to play the hard way you will never die/ lose a fight after the first hour or so. I still recommend it as I am hopeing for a more challenging mode/option to come out, as it stands you can play the game anyway you choice, thus making it difficult, but if you are playing on co-op I doubt anyone else will be doing the same.

content:
14, 2014
Early Access Review
								I highly recommend this game to anyone that is into voxel based creative games, action games, and to some extent, survival games.The graphics are quite beautiful, I find myself just stopping to enjoy the view quite often. Textures could be better but the overall asthetic is quite nice.This game uses a smooth voxel system meaning terrain is made up of small voxels as opposed to other blocky voxel games that use large single blox voxels. Just like other voxel based games you can dig and build to your hearts content. One thing tha makes this game really unique is the ability to build your own weapons, shields, buildings, and vehicles using their in-game design software.Want to make Cloud's Buster sword? You can do that. Want to make the Master Sword? You can do that too. You can pretty much design and build anything you can think of so long as you have the materials to build it. In Story and Adventure modes you have to gather materials manually in the game where as in Build Mode you are given pretty much unlimited resources to build with, which from what I remember you can load up your designs from Build Mode into Story and Adventure mode, you will still however need to gather all the proper materials and craft components in the game to build your designs.This is one of the absolute best creative survival games available. I find it far more enjoyable than Minecraft ever was and the devs are adding more and more features.If you are on the fence about this game, do yourself a favor and just jump over to Planet Explorers side. You will not regret it.I give Planet Explorers a solid 8.5/10.

content:
17
												Creative Freedom 9/10Adventure 5/10Sandbox 8/10Survival 2/10Longevity 2/10Because of the nature of this game, I have to review it from 2 angles.Creative/Sandbox/BuilderIn this area the game excells.  There are all kinds of things you can make, a colony of NPCs to manage, and you can even design tools, weapons, and vehicles from scratch.  You can construct your own personal fortress populated with NPCs and defended by an arsenal of turrets.... But, to what end?  Other than being able to admire your creation, it serves little purpose.This leads me to the second angleAdventure/Survival/LongevityThe game is really not much of a challenge.  There are no hordes coming to knock down your door.  Most of the vehicles, turrets, and weapons you make are put to little use (outside of a pvp server).  Feels like you are building up an empire for a war that will never happen.  Playing on a server with the skills system will give you a few more hours of enjoyment, as it will take you longer to get to "end game" gear, but the enviornmental opposition is still lacking.  The quests and dungeons are generic and bland.I still recommend this game, but only if:1) You are looking for a freebuild creative mode sandbox to just build and design to your hearts content.2) or if you have a crew of people to PVP with.

content:
6, 2016
Early Access Review
								Planet explorers is fun. Once you progress a little and are able to make jetpacks and gliders, it gets more fun; the freedom of flying is great. The game initially feels kind of like a cheap chinese knockoff, but as you play you'll be quickly disuaded from that idea (at least the cheap and knockoff parts; the dialogue still makes me think non-native speaker). While you need to mine for resources and are capable of building a variety of structures, terraforming the world is NOT the main focus of this game. Instead you primarily spend your resources building equipment, weaponry, and vehicles. These allow you to fight the hostile forces that reside in the sprawling world as you explore. Both the combat and exploration are really well polished, and those aspects alone are worth the fairly low price. The story has been added to throughout early access, and does a good job of providing distant destinations for you to travel to so that you can lose yourself along the way (not literally; you have a map).

content:
er 9, 2016
												I've had this game since 2014, but I haven't been able to play it much due to the sound effects and voice acting being incredibly cringey. I made the incorrect assumption that, when I first heard them, they were just "dev fillers" - developers filling for future voice actors. Boy was I wrong.In 30 years I've never played a game with such demonstrably bad audio. The music is nice, but the voice acting and sound effects are appalling. It's really quite unfortunate, because the rest of the game feels like a lot of work went into it. Performance is good, interface and movement is decent, gameplay and quests are interesting, and there's a lot of depth so far.Here's some examples I've found: Footsteps. Some surfaces don't make any sound. Walking on grass sounds like someone is kicking dirt with each step. Walking on snow sounds like someone banging a wooden spoon against a counter in the distance (wtf?). The footsteps also don't vary much, making them very annoying to listen to after some time. Earth fauna. Several sounds are very clearly from creatures on earth, like eagles, crickets, and other animals. This is especially disconcerting considering the amount of work done to create unique, alien creatures walking around the surface. Jetpack. Very bizzarre here, too. It starts off sounding great, with an "engine fire" kind of sound, and then it devolves into what sounds like a distorted whistle from a teakettle coming to a boil. What? Voice Acting. Whenever an NPC speaks, I'm pulled instantly back into reality that I'm sitting at my computer playing a game. It sounds like the devs chose 10 random people on the street, gave them all $5 USB microphones, then had them record at home. You can easily tell that the voice actors are attempting to do voices that they are incapable of doing. The only voice actor that I've encountered that sounds natural and professional is whomever voices Ava Azniv. That leaves maybe 15 other voices that are terrible. Sometimes the same NPC changes its voice drastically between two sentences, meaning the VO was done separately, with different equipment, and with a different distance from the microphone. 3D sound. The three dimensional sound is based on your character's standing position in 3rd person and not on the player camera, which is opposite of any other game ever made. You ALWAYS play sound relative to the player camera, not to the NPC that the player is controlling in 3rd person. That way the character can shimmy around - strafe, dodge, run, jump, spin around - but the sound from the thing that has the player's attention is static and unmoving while the player camera is looking at it. I've been running forward, looking with the camera to my right, and I'll hear an animal sound to my left. When I spin my camera around to look forward, nothing is there. I need to keep spinning my camera left because the sound came from the NPC's left, not my camera's left.  Randomized animal ambience. Occasionally while playing, a random animal sound will play. Sometimes it's an eagle, sometimes it's a group of crickets that chirp for a few seconds, and sometimes it's a growl from a creature. This is obviously quite disruptive to gameplay since it causes the player to swivel around looking for a nearby predator. But there isn't one. So now I hear a growl and think it's just ambience, but it turns out to be a predator. Ugh.Since like in movies, sound can either make or break the experience, these issues ruin it for me, but I'll keep playing. It's still a well-made game otherwise. I just wouldn't recommend it.

content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
Written as of A0.81 (June 22 2014)My first (~10 hours) hands-on impressions of the game)I didn't read any info about the game before I started it, so I didn't really know what to expect.I started the game, and went into solo-adventurer mode, here I found myself in a camp with some other people (shopkeepers it seemed, some had quests). I bought a shovel, ran out of the camp, and dug a small cave, neat! Then I equipped my dagger (I think it was) and attacked a creature that handed me my genitals on a silver platter. Then I started using some of the materials I dug up when making the cave to make a small hut (creatures are obviously not to be trifled with). About 5min into this I ran out of stamina, and I had no idea how to get it back.So I figured I'd try out the story mode.In story mode I found that there were some questlines to follow, they explained some of the basics, so I no longer want for stamina (or hp).The story mode led me from hub to hub, but I'm still only scratching the surface of this because I was distracted by a looming mountain; "I wonder if I can dig a tunnel through that mountain" *2 hours later* "yeah!". There is a progression in what schematics you have available, which follows the questline. For example, the first schematics for weapons available are wooden ones, then stone, then iron.The quests I did so far were mainly gather x/kill y/escort z ones, which for me would normally be a big "thumbs down", but in this game the backdrop steals the show, and the quests are (imo) mainly there to give you a purpose for why you venture out. I got a quest to gather 20 copper and 5 tin (I think it was) for some guy, and I ended up making a huge underground cave (mining 1000's of copper and tin in the process). I could have finished this quest in 5 minutes, and it would have been a boring gather quest, but because of how the backdrop is made I lost myself in it, and spent literally hours making my very own cave.SummaryMost early access games hold great potential, but Planet explorers, I feel, already has the fundamental basics covered, and this is why I recommend it. It's evident that the people making this know what they are doing, and with the content I've seen so far I don't doubt that they can flesh out the rest.It lacks polish (detailed below), but it has a solid engine. In my first 10 hours of gameplay I haven't had any crashes, and I did stuff like tunnelling through a mountain for fun (this was ~2 hours worth of drilling straight into rock), and then made a big cave where there was a copper deposit.For anyone who can enjoy the simple pleasure it is to shape the world with your mining pick and shovel, there is already a lot of hours worth of gameplay in this game.CaveatI wouldn't recommend it yet to someone who is only/mainly in it for the combat, although this does show promise, it's definitely not balanced - you can build 10 (portable) sentries and wipe out pretty much anything by placing them quickly on the ground near the creature while it's aggressive towards you. It will however cost a lot of bullets having 10 sentry turrets firing away at the same time.Lack of polish examples- not all game modes are quite ready, I recommend you start in story mode, this seems to be the most polished- some of the models lack the detail some other models have (people are very low-poly, but some of the creatures are gorgeous)- there is a help/tutorial system, but it's not very detailed, especially for some of the complex things you can do, like making your own craftable ISOs (blueprints)- a basic tutorial for how to "live" is needed (how to regain hp/stamina), there is a quest that explains some of it in story mode, but if you start out in adventurer mode you will be out of luck when you run out of stamina and don't know what to do (sleeping in a bed currently doesn't give stamina, I think it's intended to though)- a few features are not enabled yet- melee combat feels clunkyThe help/tutorial system will likely be lackluster till much later in the developement. It doesn't make much sense to create elaborate explanations of how to do stuff when it is likely to be changed.

content:
24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'll keep it short as it's a game in Early Access, with lots of stuff that has to be done yet.The game shows *a lot* of potential, with MMORPG-like feeling mixed together with third-person shooter and crafting game mechanics. I haven't personally looked much at the building section of the game, which looks absolutely intriguing and fascinating.If you want to compare it to other sandbox games like Minecraft, Terraria or Starbound, the biggest changes are that this set in a huge life-like breathing world rendered in "real" 3D (no more pixel graphics!) that you can modify and make yours to the same degree that the aformentioned titles allow you to.Another big bonus is the fact that there is a single player story mode, something that very few games of this genre offer; however, it definitely feels like a game that is meant to be played cooperatively, so bear this in mind if you want to play in single player only.Trying to wrap it up: if you like crafting/sandboxing games, and if you like exploring vast, fantastic territories... give this game a shot, you'll probably like it.My vote: 7/10 (current game state), 9.5/10 (potential)

content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
Written as of A0.81 (June 22 2014)My first (~10 hours) hands-on impressions of the game)I didn't read any info about the game before I started it, so I didn't really know what to expect.I started the game, and went into solo-adventurer mode, here I found myself in a camp with some other people (shopkeepers it seemed, some had quests). I bought a shovel, ran out of the camp, and dug a small cave, neat! Then I equipped my dagger (I think it was) and attacked a creature that handed me my genitals on a silver platter. Then I started using some of the materials I dug up when making the cave to make a small hut (creatures are obviously not to be trifled with). About 5min into this I ran out of stamina, and I had no idea how to get it back.So I figured I'd try out the story mode.In story mode I found that there were some questlines to follow, they explained some of the basics, so I no longer want for stamina (or hp).The story mode led me from hub to hub, but I'm still only scratching the surface of this because I was distracted by a looming mountain; "I wonder if I can dig a tunnel through that mountain" *2 hours later* "yeah!". There is a progression in what schematics you have available, which follows the questline. For example, the first schematics for weapons available are wooden ones, then stone, then iron.The quests I did so far were mainly gather x/kill y/escort z ones, which for me would normally be a big "thumbs down", but in this game the backdrop steals the show, and the quests are (imo) mainly there to give you a purpose for why you venture out. I got a quest to gather 20 copper and 5 tin (I think it was) for some guy, and I ended up making a huge underground cave (mining 1000's of copper and tin in the process). I could have finished this quest in 5 minutes, and it would have been a boring gather quest, but because of how the backdrop is made I lost myself in it, and spent literally hours making my very own cave.SummaryMost early access games hold great potential, but Planet explorers, I feel, already has the fundamental basics covered, and this is why I recommend it. It's evident that the people making this know what they are doing, and with the content I've seen so far I don't doubt that they can flesh out the rest.It lacks polish (detailed below), but it has a solid engine. In my first 10 hours of gameplay I haven't had any crashes, and I did stuff like tunnelling through a mountain for fun (this was ~2 hours worth of drilling straight into rock), and then made a big cave where there was a copper deposit.For anyone who can enjoy the simple pleasure it is to shape the world with your mining pick and shovel, there is already a lot of hours worth of gameplay in this game.CaveatI wouldn't recommend it yet to someone who is only/mainly in it for the combat, although this does show promise, it's definitely not balanced - you can build 10 (portable) sentries and wipe out pretty much anything by placing them quickly on the ground near the creature while it's aggressive towards you. It will however cost a lot of bullets having 10 sentry turrets firing away at the same time.Lack of polish examples- not all game modes are quite ready, I recommend you start in story mode, this seems to be the most polished- some of the models lack the detail some other models have (people are very low-poly, but some of the creatures are gorgeous)- there is a help/tutorial system, but it's not very detailed, especially for some of the complex things you can do, like making your own craftable ISOs (blueprints)- a basic tutorial for how to "live" is needed (how to regain hp/stamina), there is a quest that explains some of it in story mode, but if you start out in adventurer mode you will be out of luck when you run out of stamina and don't know what to do (sleeping in a bed currently doesn't give stamina, I think it's intended to though)- a few features are not enabled yet- melee combat feels clunkyThe help/tutorial system will likely be lackluster till much later in the developement. It doesn't make much sense to create elaborate explanations of how to do stuff when it is likely to be changed.

content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
								First time doing a serious review of a game, so please bear with me.NOTE: This review is for version A0.82 so my opinion may change for better or worse over time.With that all over with, let's get to the review.Prologue and Creation/building system 9/10Planet explorers is a voxel based open world building/RPG game with Singleplayer/multiplayer support. The game is very playable for an alpha game, and deserves all the credit possible for that feat alone. It's one of the best games I've played this year, and has lots of replay value through the creation system on its own. The building system in this game is one of its strong points. It improves upon something that games like Minecraft fall short on. It gives you the ability to enter a free cam mode and build as you see fit, with support for curved edges, slopes, ramps, and everything else of the sort. The creation system is fun to use, but really flimsy with its actual usage ingame. So far I've seen little use for ground vehicles, aside from being cool looking sometimes. The weapons are terribly weak and could be improved upon. When my 1000 meat pistol does more damage than 20,000 meat tank, then you have a problem. But all that aside, I've spent a majority of my time on this game making vehicles and weapons. It truly gives the power to the players. With admins stating that they plan to add extensive mod support for this game in later builds, I see it having a very long and prosperous life. Instant classic.Combat 5/10The combat system in Planet Explorers is very clumsy to say the least. You lunge forward with melee weapons and flail around like an idiot hoping you hit something, while the massively overpowered giant monsters make scraps of you. I've used 3+ revival shots on fights that should'nt even need healing. The ranged weapons are bearable, but the Ocarina of Time camera angle it throws you into makes moving and shooting very annoying. In the end I found myself relying on grenades and placing down my Artillary cannons to deal with monsters instead of actually fighting them.Exploration 5/10
The game is not very rewarding for its exploration, with all of the ore veins being deep underground and very scattered, there's no reason to use your scanner unless you know exactly where the veins are. I havn't played adventure mode much to know about how bad the ore veins are in there, but the ore veins in story are massive and widely spread apart. Its taken my 10+ minutes just to get a petrol vein I needed, and another 20+ minutes to try and make sense of how to dig to it.

Mining 7/10 (4/10 without guides.)
This is the only game where I've only wanted to get 20 copper out of a vein, but came out with 3000. For some reason the mining in this game is awefully enrapturing. But my poiny from before remains clear, the process of getting to the ore is very agonizing, to say the least. Especially when you're not relying on guides to find the ores. Before I knew they were in set locations, I spent an hour or two on finding a silver deposit.

Vehicles 8/10
Vehicles are fun, but clumsy. Ground vehicles are like moving bricks, and take damage from everything. Their weapons are extremelly lacking, and eat through what little power they have like nothing. Aircraft are similar with power problems, but by the point you get Aircraft in the story mode you have a means to refuel them. Aircrafts also have much more versatile weapon systems. I cannot give opinions on boats, I've never used them or needed to use them. Sorry.

Overall Alpha score: 7/10
Presumed Release score: 9/10
Personal scoring: 8/10 (Meaning how much I enjoy the game as a whole, not just getting an average.)

If you came to this game from Minecraft, you are in the wrong place, this game requires a lot more time and effort to get to a reasonable standing, but is much more rewarding.

Sorry if my reviewing skills are undesirable, I just felt the need to review one of my favorite games to date.

												If any of the following appeals to you, then get this game - if any annoys you, then I guess don't get it? - Huge planet to explore with interesting fauna and flora- A story that is interesting (so far, not finished yet) and works with the open world survival crafting game- Vehicles - land, air, sea - and you can very freely create your own from scratch - flying around in your own helicopter is pretty cool- Build colonies and have your slaves... eh, colonists, work for you!- Build monorails across the world that drive along lines you create on a schedule (seriously cool)- Progression á la Minecraft from wooden, over iron, to diamond (really weird but it kinda works)I have Kickstarted this game way back and been skeptical at first since the development took very long and it was very clunky and buggy at first - but it's a great game now and I'm glad to have it.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game definitely has potential, in addition to being fun to play in it's current state. The devs are pretty transparent with their goals and timeline.There's certainly a few things that are lacking (am I the only one who thinks rotocopters should be able to strafe instead of just yaw?) The crafting system (the replicator) works quite well, and the interface is pretty intuitive. There are a few querks with equipping items and where they show up in your inventory (personal opinion, certainly doesn't affect gameplay).The iso creation system is, in my opinion, what really sets this apart from other sandboxes. Not only can you create your own things out of blocks, but you can create your own useable items - vehicles, weapons, objects. The interface is a little intimidating at first, and isn't the most intuitive or user friendly, but once you get the hang of it, you can do some pretty amazing things! I'd like to see more data displayed while in the iso creator, but we're in alpha, and there's lots of development to go.Overall, it's a beautiful game with some very innovative ideas. I can't wait to see where it goes, and I'm having lots of fun playing it as is.

content:
er 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Edit: Updated to the 0.86 update.While this game is early access and there is still a bit the developers are working on the Single Player Story Mode is so well developed, expansive, and completed at this point in time that it seems a lot better than some "completed" games I have played.  The work they have put into it has won me over and I really look forward to seeing them finish the game.Admittedly it is early access and is not perfect.  Some quests are a bit glitchy and followers occasionally get stuck.I have not played multiplayer so do not have feedback on it.  I have played Story mode extensively (lots of solo exploration and have began working on my first settlement) and a bit of adventure mode.Since my original review the developers have worked on the adventure mode world generation as well as added new plants and animals.  The last adventure world I played was gorgeous and really made me want to explore it.Pros:Huge and developed story modeStory mode is a great tutorial on how the game works and all its ins and outsCan build your own vehicles and use them in gameVery playable for an Early access gameActive Development (some of the cons in my original review have been fixed or updated and there have been other additional features)Cons:Minor Bugs (it is Early Access and the bugs usually are minor)Creation UI could be cleanerClothing creation recipies are gender specific so you might end up creating items you can not use if you are not careful

content:
r 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								I've really only scratched the surface with about 20 hours in at this point,  but so far Planet Explorers is one of the best building (voxel) and adventure games I've had the joy of playing.   There are lots of elements of other games in here, and I think this game is going in a great direction.  Before you get into specifics if you're wondering if this game is playable and worth an early access purchase:   YES this game is completely playable,  its fun, it has a lot of stuff for you to do, and is one of the best sandboxes I've ever played.That being said here are some points I've noticed so far.The graphics are pretty good, and it runs like a dream on my (somewhat) aging laptop.  Performace is 25 FPS easy even on high load.  I've only played the adventure mode,  but there are some quests - most of them pretty basic.  Collect and kill mostly.The animals seem to be fairly varied,  as well as the attacks they do.The crafting is really great,  though the creation system could use a slightly better tutorial.  In fact most things could use a better tutorial -- but this is an early access game.  There is probably a lot more I can go into detail about,  though I haven't tried the multiplayer yet, but plan on it soon.  I can't wait for the next update.

Be it a railroad, spaceship, castle, weapon, car, shield. You will be able to create pretty much anything. The game automaticallycalculates the amount of materials needed to build your creation in game. Giving you a pretty much instant access to a gamewhere you can make your own game in. Limited by the engine of course.The futures it has so early in development makes me glad i bought early access. The devs behindthis needs all the cash they can get so they can make one of the most creative sandbox game today.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm impressed. This indie game has accomplished far more and to a much better degree than alot of AAA titles I've played. I suggest picking it up and here's why:The AI pathfinding is wonderful. A follower only got stuck once and that's because I was trying to build the bridge as we were walking over it and I accidently built ontop of him. So chalk that up to my fault.Speaking of building I must say this is one of the nicest system I've seen. My only complaint is that I can't make slopes at any angle that I want, but I haven't fully examined the builder so I could've just missed it.The voxel system creates one of the best mining systems that smoothly change the terrain as you dig and mine for minerals.The item/vehicle creation is very nice and adds your own touch to the game.HOWEVER there are some negative point, but these might be solved as time goes on:The ranged weapons feel inaccurate. Yes you point and shoot and it hits the target, but the pistols feel like the rifles and it all seems the same.Some claim that the melee combat is like Monster Hunter, but I disagree. You can't specifically mess up a monster's leg or wings. On top of that I haven't found a way to dodge yet so it's been a contest of who can hit harder.There's no way to sort through the crafting menu. it's alphabetical, but if you forget that what you want is the "portible medkit" and not the "small medkit"(which I don't think there is one) then you can make the mistake of thinking you can't craft any small healing itemsDespite these complaints I like this game as is and the proposed additions can hopefully only make it better.EDIT: Upon review in the upper center of the replicator menu there is a way to sort out scripts. I found that it isn't a user friendly as other sorting systems, butit does exist and makes things simpler to a degree. Thank you to Thariorn for pointing this out to me.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
25, 2014
Early Access Review
								Absolutely an amazing game. So much to do. It is a sandbox game meaning you can do practically anything you want with out following a story line. However, there is a story and it is a good one. You crash on a new planet with a few other scattered survivors. As in real life you have to survive and try to get off planet or at least hook up with others.  In order to do this you mine materials, grow food, build habitations,forts,base camps,even villages.You create tools,weapons,machines,ATVs, aircraft etc. You hunt animals for meat which is also a currency, and harvest plants for mediciane. You scan the earth for minable resources.Some of the local fauna are passive some aggressive and you need to be alert and armed where ever you go. This adds a feeling of danger and realness to the game. As it would be in real life you learn about the planet through exploration, about its creatures through study and careful approach. All have there own biorythms.  Determine the hostile ones in time and you might survive. Some attack solo, others in packs. How cool is that?The world has many biomes, sea ,grasslands ,desert, forests and canyons. All beautifully constructed.The musical score is wonderful and is still being added to as is other game content.As is I am 50 hours into the game and have experienced no bugs. It is a joy to play.The characters are well animated and you can create your own at start. It appears that more features will be added to the character creation in the future.This game seems to have a little of everything, survival on a strange and beautiful world, a mysterios alien race, ruins, hostile tribals, discord within your own ranks between the earthlings and martian components.With more content coming every month I can't wait to see what is up next. You could spend hours just in the creation section building and awesome tank or helicopter to meet your own design standards.  Later import it in game and have your character climb on board and travel in style to any point in the game,The game doesen't hand hold you so you get to learn and explore and create as in a real world experience. There are small tutorials that give you the basics and fire the imagination,There is even a map that you can mark your building sites on, or locations of minerals you have located etc.There are tools for every job, shovels, picks, axes, swords, shields, guns, bows, laser guns, armour. This means you canplay the game as a medieval warrior or as a highly specialized space traveller with all the gadgets or somewhere in between.This game IMO was the best buy I have made in years.  A masterpice of fun and imagination.Hats off to the developers for such a polished and entertaining product.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
23, 2014
Early Access Review
								Definitely a good game.  It has held my attention for the most part.  As it stands right now there's obvious issues as it's an alpha.  The current issues I've ran into so far are as follows:The AI has some pretty bad pathfinding.  They can get stuck on something as small as a mound of dirt.  Which makes you have to keep an eye on them during escort missions where you've ran for 10-15 mins only to realize when you get to your destination that the person you're escorting got stuck half way back.  You're able to have two companions where if they get too far behind they'll teleport next to you.  This needs to happen to escorted NPCs as well.There's many different ways to travel, however I've only made a car.  While fun and all, they damage very easily.  This may be because it's a starting car I made but the damage accumulated way too fast.  I was only able to drive for 2 mins tops in the forest area before the car blew up.  Every small mound I went over made the car take damage.  Also I found that the cars handling needs a fair amount of tweaking.I've only just got past the kill the layerback (whetever they're called) mission.  That's where I hit my first roadblock as the quest was either unintentionally unfair or bugged as you're supposed to escort 2 survivors  to kill the layerbacks.  The one guard NPC always rushes in to melee them only to die and fail the mission.  I must have tried the mission literally 30 times, before I just built a wall around him out of harms way and only then could I finish the mission.  They need to certainly fix that as it's more than just a minor annoyance.All in all this game has certain potential to be really good.  If you can deal with it's quirks as alpha goes along, there's definitely a lot of fun to be had.  Also the fact that you can build you're own cars, vtols and weapons with pre made parts then add voxels to add your own touch to it is really cool.  While I don't think in it's alpha state the price is justified, it will be worth it at full release.

content:
17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Some people when seeing this game will immeditely think "Yay... another Minecraft clone... again!" and would be partly right since this game offers a lot more.First : the story mode, which could potentially be considered a big tutorial for the adventure part, is actually worth doing if you are (like myself) an amateur of the "stranded adventures" type, in many occasions I almost expected Captain Janeway beam down and give me a new assignment.Second : the customization possibilities go way beyond what Minecraft can do (coming from the madman who made the casle of Akashi on minecraft-europe server mostly by himself), both in terms of objects AND in vehicules with some really impresive designs you can import in the game just with a drag and drop in the right folder, even while the game is till running.Third : the environments are gorgeous ! I was a bit scared to end up in pretty barren lands like you could see in Anarchy Online but through the visual style (which reminds a lot of Consortium and/or Star Wars - The Old Republic), props and mobs runing around you already have, despite the game being in alpha, the impression of being in a living world. It really is a joy to see a pack of wolf like creature attacking a herbivore in the middle of a forest. Some may argue that the graphics are not "Next-Gen" but as Yathzee Croshaw would say "Golden pixels are detrimental to the quality of all other aspects of the game" yet even though the game is definitely not the absolute best looking you can tell the guys put some serious work in making the environments colourful and interesting to travel in (I had to pick up my jaw on the floor a few times in fact).On the less good parts :- The game currently has some issues with quest in story mode blocking (a character giving a quest that pops up and dissappear right away or conditions not validating being the most common issues), some people apparently didn't had much problems but I'm currently stuck after 12 hours of questing. Probably somethings patching will correct so I don't mind that much.- You can shape the land as you see fit in theory only because it is actually quite difficult to accurately mine things, for example trying to mine a perfectly straight tunnel at an angle can become a nightmare really fast because the character is always sliding on slopes, which brings to the next point.- Controls are a bit cluncky with a big hindrance of the camera not always placing itself in the best angle for the action and the vehicules being a bit difficult to accurately tune in regards to the power/weight ratio and turning angle, meaning a vehicule can have a tendency to do a 180° as slowly as an narcoleptic sloth or beat Sonic the hedgehod to it.The last point is nor good nor bad, it's actually something any off roader knows : there are no roads (that I've seen) on this planet so do not build a low hanging vehicule as the slightest slope will probably damage the vehicule. So unless you manually build roads leading to New Rome you will always travel in bugies !

There you will find basic help in the general section, advanced help in the ISO creation and sharing section, Bug reports (remember this is EARLY ACCESS not even BETA) where you can and PLEASE DO report any bugs or add to any reports of bugs you have so it helps them track down the complex bugs, and simply other unrelated chat as well.
