number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
5, 2014
Early Access Review
								*This review is based off an older version, around .72 alpha buildFirst off. Let me start with performance.I do not lag on this game on any settings and with my computer underclocked. And it still looks wonderful.Let me restate that,.... Space Engineers(on any world older than a day), Minecraft(for most people), 7 days to die, + any other game you can think of that is voxel based..... Planet Explorers not only looks better, but handles better.Nuff said.Music/sound: needs more variety if they are still on the same tracks as the last version I played. But for what they do have, the music is refreshing and fits right in. It is not intrusive at all. Sound had wierd glitches here and there, but stuff that was actively getting fixed and nothing that really stood out.animation/combat: I am clumping these two together for a reason,... they are closely tied for the trouble parts. Overall its pretty good, both the animation and the combat. But something about combat makes me feel more like I am aiming for hit boxes and not an actual entity. I do not like this in the slightest, so even tho I would like to be a melee combatant, I feel forced into ranged combat because of this.*I believe theres been some changes to combat that may effect my opinion on this, I will change my review to reflect more recent versions as I play them*Scenery: Yes, this one warrants its own section. The landscape of Planet Explorers is beautiful. And the variety of foliage(trees, grass, bushes, flowers) is beyond what any other game I have played has attemptedCreatures: Again, something that I might not have commented on in any other game... Planet Explorers creature deserve a mention. The variety and detail put into the creatures is astonishing. And they keep adding more! I did 3 'Main' playthroughs of the storymode for this game before the last version- and EVERY time there was more creatures that I hadnt seen before! Someone in their department is pumping them out, and I am loving it!Story: The story is actually pretty good if you pay attension to what is going on(i.e. dont skip thru text)The presentation certainly is not winning any awards, but as far as I am concerned, it doesn't have to. What is nice here is that in storymode(singleplayer), the story is not shoved down your throat. You are free to pursue the story, or do your own thing.Survival Aspect: This is a survival game after all, and thats what most of us(or at least me) come to do. And I must say that on the version I played, I wasnt as impressed as I hoped. It felt like survival was optional, and that should never be the case in a survival game. I don't know if that makes any sense, but... not hardcore enough for me? maybe.Good news is I heard there is an editor thing planned that from what details I heard, will definately be able to accomidate anything I feel is missing here.Developers: This one is of special note. I have never before PE seen a head of development for a game interact with the community, on a near daily basis. Furthermore, in the time I spent observing and partaking in the forums I have not seen so much straightforwardness and honestly from developers. This is both commendable and heartwarming. I will not provide examples, as they stand on the forums for all to see.Also, it is easy to tell these developers actually care about their game.Summary: It's a great game and only getting better,... I couldn't recommend it more. If still in doubt, try out the demo. I insist! Do the storymode first... the other modes are farther behind and don't accurately represent what the dev's are trying to accomplish.**Note: I will update this review as I play newer versions.... anything here will likely change for the better.

content:
24, 2016
Early Access Review
								Looking at this game from the perspective of a single player sci-fi campaign, it's looking worth the money. Now that the game has had a few iterations in the beta developement phase, the story mode seems far more playable and less buggy. From what they've said in their update notes, I'd venture to say the story mode is more or less finished. May still be a few problems to work out with their Intro/Tutorial though.I have had this game for about a year and I've played a bit in the Multi-Player Adventure mode. In the past there wasn't much progression to the Adventure story, but it seems that they have plans to change that. They had done something with their random terrain generator that created lots of ugly ridges in the landscape, which are very difficult to navigate with wheeled vehicles. I need to take another look at Adventure mode, but I'm waiting on further updates. So at this moment I can't really comment on their random generated Adventure mode.I feel that the interface and control setup takes a bit of getting used to, but once you get the hang of the controls it's pretty easy to play the game. I'm not well skilled at using 3D modeling software tools, but it's really not too difficult to learn the basics of the Creation tool in order to quickly create simple vehicles. Very elaborate designs are possible, and I've seen many examples of player created ISO's for this game. I do expect that there will be some Steam Workshop content available in the future.Altogether I think that Planet Explorers is shaping up as a good buy.

content:
2015
Early Access Review
								This is a very fun game, and feels very complete despite being in Early Access.  A few little bugs here and there don't stop you from having heaps of fun with this one.  Highly recommended if you are into the explore/build/survival genre.The only bad things I can think of is the music score of the grasslands area which can get a little repetitive after a while.  Multiplay is also bit iffy (we could not get our map saved if we both logged off) but I am confident that will be fixed; the devs are quite engaging with the community. (and the music, you can turn off :p)Now the good things, I can think of many.  You can explore some gorgeous locations, the main story line is quite engaging and breadcrumbs your way nicely through the world, the crafting/building is really fun; ISO designing can be a little clunky at first until you learn the design tools, once you do you'll never stop as it's that addictive!This is one of those few Early Access games that make the whole Early Access "thing" worth it.

content:
er 14, 2016
												I've had this game for ages now, possibly before steam.  I'm not sure where I got it fist.  Perhaps Desura?Anyway, this is a very interesting game.  I've only ever really played the story mission recently but previously the adventure mode was pretty lacking.  this may have been addressed.Probably the best thing about this game is that it's a fairly unique experience.  I guess if you gave minecraft a plot it would be this game.  It's fun to explore and the creatures are unique and challenging.  Probably what makes it stand apart is that this is a RPG where you build your own town and your own vehicles.  I can imagine a lot of people would go nuts with this but I found it a bit tiring.  Just give me some pre-fab stuff so I can get on with it.  Thankfully this does seem to be the case and I'm sure there are mods to add some interesting designs without needing to sink time into their design.That's not to say that it doesn't have any flaws.  The inventory management seems to be completely absent so as a result you hae limitless slots and no weight limit.  So you just keep everything you find, which is a lot.  I think I'm carrying around about 5k dirt blocks atm which are about 1 meter cube each. As you can probably imagine this throws the economy into disarray.  Meat is the currency (I guess because it's a survival game?) but it never goes off and is quite plentiful.  There is no levelling or experience so quests just seem to keep the plot rolling along.  Yeah, there are rewards but you can just buy them for meat from the NPC as soon as you meet, so these feel largely pointless.  The more I think about it it just seems that this game is ment to be played in sandbox mode because the plot, while interesting seems fairly tacked on.Combat feels a bit cluinky and relies on what feels like aut-targetting for melee and using a ranged weapon puts you into an locked in over the shoulder mode ala Resident Evil.  They're not terribe, but it's not revolutionary either.While these sound fairly critical I still had fun with it and I suspect that the sandbox mode is the more interesting mode over the story.

y 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Problem with the Linux client, in case your character instantly dies when entering the world, and instantly dies again after revive, put this in startup options (without the quotes):"LC_ALL=en_US.utf8 %command%"It turns out there is no OpenCL hardware support for Mac and Linux Ubuntu(*), which means really terrible performance unfortunately.(*) Apparently due to broken nvidia 331 proprietary driver. In order to fix this, you might have some luck with this approach (in the order mentioned below):- apt-get install nvidia-cuda-toolkit- apt-get install ocl-icd-opencl-dev- reboot- revert to "legacy 304 proprietary driver" from nvidia- rebootUse at your own risk, the driver is outdated and might break other games, your cat might choke and the antichrist make his appearance. If it does work and none of the above happens, it does run very well.Kinda on the fence with this one due to the many hoops I had to jump to get it to run properly, still thumbs up, as it is a beautiful game and kinda sticks out of the whole sandbox crafting openworld somewhatminecraftish crowd.Now, the terrain (and terrain manipulation) in this one is really well done, is is actually quite fun digging a cave and putting stuff in there.So are the characters, they have a very unique touch to them.The crafting also appears to be a rather unique approach, havent had time to check it out in-depth yet though.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
Early Access Review
								Of all the sandbox early access games on Steam, this seems so far the most promising. And indeed, the most complete ~ *cough* DayZ *cough*I was entirely taken aback by the MMORPG-like feel from the get go, and it initially made me weary. It took exactly five minutes to forget any of that, thanks to the addictive harvesting, mining, building and just generally extremely well-done crafting in this game. This game so far has *the* best customization that I have seen, and knocks Sid Meier's Alpha Centauri and Galactic Civilizations 2 down from their previously shared throne in this aspect IMO.The parallells to Minecraft are also subdued - thankfully.Apart from The Secret World, I don't think I've ever been more immersed in an over-the-shoulder perspective game. Sure, the music is mostly licenseware, the voice acting sounds like a school class project, and some textures are extremely flat; but I find myself ignoring a lot of what would otherwise be real annoyances for me because of the overall charm this game has.Probably the main strength this game has is the authentic-feeling world. Multiplayer has some procedural niggles that I hope will be gone after alpha, but the single player (and selectable in multiplayer) "canon" world quite possibly is the most authentic, immersive "alien looking" world I've seen since The Elder Scrolls III: Morrowind. And to be sure, Planet Explorer's flora and fauna has a lot in common with Morrowind, to the point that it feels like an homage, if a slightly more colourful one.There are a few things left to really fix for me to give this top marks. For example, I feel the multiplayer progression is way too fast compared to the single player, and people will get easily burnt out if they start out with multiplayer first. PLAY SINGLE PLAYER FIRST! The music is repetitive, and I hope a placeholder - but the choice of music, even if it's sparse, at least was a good one. Voice acting is campy and of low technical and artistic quality - which is kind of charming, actually. And I don't think many care in this sort of game. Also, I wish harvesting, woodcutting and mining were a bit more agile. Currently, herbs have too small "pick up zones" where you have to stand realllllllllyyyy close to the center, the woodcutting is tedious because you have to hold down the right mousebutton, sometimes for MINUTES if it's a big tree, and finally the mining animation is slow as heck and hard to abort to precision mine.Lots of minor issues, no major issues - except one:Most of all the dedicated server launcher could use a lot of work, and the parameters the worlds is created from need to be expanded. For example drop rate. Well... ESPECIALLY drop rate. Ha. Current default multiplayer servers will let you get full steel armour and a helicopter within 2 hours. AWFUL. But hey, it's alpha.

								NOTE:  Review will change if they fix things.  However, I'm writing this review because things have been too rough and unfinished for too long.  Especially the game breaking bug for if you have anything plugged in other than keyboard + mouse.------------------------------Extremely, *extremely* buggy, even for an early access title.If you have any controller plugged in, or use vJoy or any head tracking, you have to disable them from the device manager before you load up the game.  There are no options to disable controllers or joysitcks ingame at this time.If you don't disable your peripherals, the camera will bug out and spin around your characters feet, making the game unplayable.If you DO disable them and try to generate a world to play in, the world is very buggy.  Your character can run through objects in the starting village, and can run up and down sheer cliffs.It doesn't feel like a sandbox game like Minecraft or Kerbal Space Program.  It feels like a very, very shoddy MMORPG that you play on your own.  Especially the combat system.

content:
, 2015
Early Access Review
								There's always the impulse to compare it to certain other sandbox games... but I don't know how. Planet Explorers plays like an RPG, crafting game, exploration, adventure, even a 3D modelling program!* It's like Elements: You start with initial resources like plants and minerals, and can craft new technologies & accessories.* It's like an RPG: Beautiful open world, small & large enemies, Obtain missions by talking to NPC's, some of which can join your party and eventually your colony (city)! They will fight with you & you can equip them with weapons, armors, items, or just give them stuff to carry.* It's a sandbox: make tools to help you dig out the world. Search for ore deposits using your 3D scanner then use them to construct just about anything! (not player-designed clothing)* It's 3D modelling software: Construct swords, shields, guns, land/sea/air vehicles, or just decoration objects like stairs, utilities, household, really anything you can think of!Custom models are inserted into the game like this: If you have the resources required to build it, they will automatically be removed from your inventory and the object will appear. You can interact with it or pick it up anytime that you are next to it. An 'approved' build that has been picked up may be reused until it is destroyed; once it's built, it's built.I have spent over 10 hours on Story mode so far and I have only just built my first car. I have leather armor, sword & shield, bow & rifle. My 2 followers have Steel armor & swords; they 'tank' while I shoot. I have barely explored the south-central part of the island. There are videos of immense constructs and firepower, enemies and adventure. I have only barely begun, and I am very much addicted :).

								When I first bought and played Planet Explorers over 2 years ago, I loved it and couldn't wait to see how it evolved.All this time later and the A09 update they have talked baout for so long finally happens, so I give it another 3 weeks and several updates to make sure things are ironed out okay before going back. Its terrible. Single player is worse than it was 2 years ago in some way and only marginally better in other ways, and trying to play any mode with a friend is still the buggy waste of time it was 2 years ago.The newly added co-op story mode I was excited to finally play with a friend was too broken to play too. At this point, there are simply lots of better games to choose from that are actually going somehwere. Planet explorers has taken FAR too long to do far too little, and at this point it shouldnt cost what it does anymore. Its a real shame, but I don't see this game ever being done. if it ever is though, it won't even matter anymore.Too little too late. Its a shame the game still has the misleading mostly positive reviews just because of the great reception it got years ago. Most of those should be negative now but I believe those players that had hope then gave up long ago and never even came back to say so.

content:
ry 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I know this is early access and so I will treat it as such in my review.  Right now I cannot recommend this to all but the most die hard EA players that must try everything before they are released.  I'll be brief as I can.  There are some positives about this game but in a nutshell it's not ready yet for me to give it a full thumbs up.  Wish Steam had a way to give 1 to 5 stars.  If this were a star rating I'd give it a 3 for now. It seems like it has a lot of potential.  The graphics, while a bit simple, are attractive enough, in a cute, and cartoony way.  If that look is something that appeals to you it will fit in just fine.  I don't mind that aspect but just pointing that out.  Which brings me to the first downside.  with the simplified graphics, i don't understand with a very capable gaming computer like I have, why it has stutter, quite frequently.  I would say every 20 to 30 seconds the game stutters for a moment and although it's not game breaking it is quite annoying.  The positives from my prior game plays (where I played quite a bit more time back weeks ago) I like:  the gathering, build mode and craft-heaviness of the game at least early on.  The combat could use some polish along with the gathering aspects.  The tutorial or beginning doesn't tell you much about how to do things and although I don't want hand holding for every little thing, it would be nice for the basics like how to open the replicator.  Basics like this, I know you can find in help but I will venture to guess that most players don't like to spend their early minutes in a game looking up how to do all the basic stuff.  Again, this game could be good once all details are worked out, and I will keep an eye out but for now I cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I played this for a few days as I got completely lost in the awesomely designed world. If you like exploration and get a nice vibe from hard-sci-fi-ish stuff, then this is for you. I like that it has a story and characters and that it's not all procedurally generated.However, there are problems. Why, in a sci-fi game, do we still have to craft wooden pickaxes, axes, shovels, etc, like in Minecraft? The main problems with this game are the hold-overs from the Minecraft formula. They don't find whatsoever in this game. Just give me a laser cutter or something like that. It's just silly crafting wooden, bronze, iron, etc tools. The feeling of mystery was also a bit ruined for me when, while exploring, I ran into a huge fortress with hostile aliens, but upon my return to the camp where the other colonists none of them acknowledged the discovery - immersion breaking. There are some great ideas here and the technical implementation is great. It looks amazing and the voxel engine works very well. I'm pretty sure I could do without the mining and things, however, and there should be some careful constraints on the pacing for the game if there is to be a cohesive story. Overally I recommend it because I had fun playing it, but obviously it still needs a lot of work as it's still in Alpha.

content:
r 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								This was a waste of money. I have liked the idea of this game for quite a long time.  The fact that its still not finished and that i cannot play on a LAN with my friend without an internet connection have made me change my review from a positive to a negative.  Im sick and tired, as a paying customer, to make sacrifices in the name of DRM.  I have a detached garage with no internet access that I use for LAN parties.  The trend is these days is to require internet access so that all players have a valid copy.  I understand the desire to get paid for hard work, however, this only punishes paying customers.  For example, Diablo 3 requires an internet connection for the offline single player campaign.  Horribly intrusive for the paying customer hoping to play on the go, but a hacked version was released on ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ within hours of the release of the game that didn't require an active internet connection.  The pirates actually got MORE playability on this one.  I will not dig a 200 ft trench to install lan cable to my garage, nor will i try to get a stable wireless connection to transmit that far.  I will simply sulk, leave bad reviews and do better research before I buy a game.

content:
r 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Well this game is still a work in progress so it does have the odd bug that shows up and that is pretty much the only problem with it. Report the bugs and the Devs will solve those problems for you very quickly.     Planet Explorers seems to be a group of ideas a Development Team has accumulated and assembled into a fantastic game. Having the ability to build your own vehicle and then import it into the game for your character to use once you have the resources is so easy and fun to do and the creature AI is one that a lot of other games need. Being attacked by a pack of carnivores and then watching the survivors flee once they realise you are hard to kill, or not being attacked until they see you adds a new level to the gameplay. Watching carnivores hunt other animals also adds to it. The are a large number of elements in this game and  they are not all there just to make the game difficult for you to play but they do make for a real adventure.

content:
r 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								Incredible game, just incredible. I am currently as of writing this only six hours into the story mode, but wow. The graphics are great, it is very well optimized(at least SP, again have not tried online at all),the combat isnt amazing but is still fun,there are ALOT of creatures/aliens that all have different behavioral patterns(i.e. there is a stegosaurous looking guy that travels in packs)that mesh very well togther. The colony feature is also something to shout about. It basically allows you to recruit your fellow colonists once you do some quests for them. This makes hunting in single player much more entertaining and immersive, while adding more strategy as your colonists will only have what you equip them with, including healing items and ammo.Last but certainly not least is the crafting system. On its surface, it appears much like anyother survival crafting(using resources harvested from the world) to create things like wood pickaxe,copper pickaxe ect. However, there is a crafting editor where you can make literally anything you want. For example, I saw a guy that made a laser pistol that looked just like a X-wing,again that was a hand held laser pistol. Anything from weapons, armor, robots, vehicles(land, air and sea) and more.Not only that but you can choose any kind of resource to make any of the parts from, changing the stats of whatever for example a gun made from refined steel will probally do more damage than wood or normal steel.So bottom line, if you are looking for a game that offers you the choice between complete freedom or more structured play style, do yourself a favor and pick this up.p.s.- do yourself a favor and watch a youtube video and not the store page ones, they honestly downplay how great this game really is.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								-NOTE: This review is for a game in alpha!Very unique game with tons of creative ideas, but as it is in alpha, these ideas lack a lot of flare, and are very underdeveloped. In fact, all the game's ideas (not to mention the whole game itself) is packed to the brim with bugs and errors. The story mode is something I consider awful. The voice acting for all NPC's and keystory characters is annoying, and really feels like something you'd find at a high school acting club. The missions are all tedious, and rarely go beyond the MMORPG tropes of "kill X of Y" or "Collect X of Y". This is especially disheartening considering this is a singleplayer storyline, and yet it lacks anything to really intrigue me for longer than an hour. The multiplayer is glitchy as hell. Sometimes I'd be able to join a server, but most of the time this wouldn't be the case. Even when hosting my own server, something I've had a lot of experience with, the connection is very unreliable, working around 50% of the time. Now I'm positive this isn't an error on my end, as I actually have a personal server in my home, have hosted private servers for numerous games, and followed the game dev's official server setup instructions to the letter.... twice. Even if I am able to connect to a server, be it my own or someone elses, in multiplayer, there is no way to control where you spawn, meaning you and your friends will be in entirely different villages and required to shlepp around until you find each other making it very, very tedious. The create mode is the true selling point of this game. The create mode is incredibly easy to use, and almost reminds me of a dumbed down version of Solidworks, a 3D modeling program I used to use quite a lot. That being said, it is still very unrefined and lacks a lot of the flare to create anything more than some basic cars or guns without spending hours in it. There are so many tools missing from the overall creation experience, that many things are so complex to create in this 3D modeling software. This is extremely frustrating since I know that I could easily make a lot of this stuff using the vastly more advanced tools of something like Solidworks, or hell, even the Microsoft 3D modeling software. Also, there is no options for zooming besides using a mouse wheel which is annoying since I'm so used to modeling with a trackpad. This game does have a lot of potential for sure, and I will be looking at it again in beta and the final version, but as it stands right now I couldn't reccomend this at all. If I had to give this game a score, which I probably shouldn't given it's not even in beta, I'd have to give it a 4/10. Avoid this game like the expensive plague. Also, a word of advice to all "early release" developers. Please sell your alpha games at a discount. Usually you have to pay people to play such glitchy monstrosities, and it's something I deeply regret that I paid full retail for this junk heap.EDIT: Grammar corrections.

content:
22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is to Space Engineers what Starbound is to Terraria.  More invironments, more things to do, and more work required by the designers.  Both PE and SE have volumetric destructible environments and player-built square blocks everywhere, which can be destroyed easily by enemies.  But PE tries to have a whole Story (actually a series of linked quests), AI enemies and helpers, and a world-based environment as opposed to asteroids.  Planet Explorers also tries to have you build up a colony.  It also channels a bit of the MMO Calypso, but with a colony that is just starting, rather than well underway.Regards A0.7.5.2:It is Alpha, and Unity based.  Highest graphical settings on OpenGL are not recommended, but DirctX is fine so far.  There is little optimisation as yet, and multiplayer parties should stay together as digging info is not correctly remembered by all clients if they are far apart.  But there is a lot of expectation, and a playable game as it stands.  I just hope that when they say the version number, (currently A0.752, or in the game 0.7.5.2) that they don't stop when the second part reaches 10.  Most basics are there, and now they need QA and more additional stuff regards the world size and colonies.

content:
ber 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								UPDATE: I originally reviewed this game in 2014 and that review is below. This game was fantastic. After revisiting the game today I can honestly say it has gotten much much worse over the last two years. To be fair, I did not play the story mode today but the adventure mode which was always my favorite part of the game before is now completely shot. I can't tell you why it's gone wrong, but I can tell you how.1. In-game sound is GONE. There's a random click here and there but ZERO environmental effects or music or anything like that.2. Dialog is AWFUL. Seriously, talking to NPC's in the game is now worse than trying to read a cheap china-made fortune cookie... In chinese.3. Procedural terrain generator is BROKEN. I'm talking completely random giant divots in the ground worse than the potholes on a washed out backcountry road I didn't dare build anything with wheels to try to drive around.4. Framerates have gone straight into the crapper. Somehow, despite adding 12 GB of RAM and upgrading to a much beefier video card since my original review, my framerates are about HALF what they were before.This seems like a classic case of a game being fixed until they broke it. I couldn't even play for an hour before I felt compelled to quit. Any longer and I would probably have gouged my own eyes out. I honestly hope they can fix this game, because it was SO GOOD before. I'll revisit this review at some point in the future and I'd REALLY like to be able to give it a thumbs-up again... But in the current state of the game, I simply can't recommend it. Not anymore. Sorry Pathea... But PLEASE fix this awful mess.Original Review:Get off the fence and buy it. It's totally worth every penny, even now in early access. There are some bugs, but nothing game-breaking, and the playability and amount of content is fantastic. At this point in development it's easy to forget it's still in alpha. Being able to easily create, use, and share equipment and vehicles alone makes it worth it.If you like sandbox games and a sci-fi, survival, or fantasy setting you will love this game. I keep coming back and the dev team keeps impressing me. You can spend hours just hunting creatures, or you can spend hours playing through the story, or you can spend hours designing that next badass sandrail or VTOL. The more you put into the game, the more you'll get out of it. Now buy it and try it. You'll see.One caveat... Read the required system specs before you buy it. They're not BSing. If you can't meet those specs this game will barely run if at all. Not kidding. If you can't get a decent framerate you're going to have a very hard time with this game.

content:
6, 2014
Early Access Review
								The world feels enormous, the NPCs feel like they're made of cardboard.  The animations are chunky, the landscape has white lines in it sometimes, but the sheer number of things you can make is incredible.  Unfortunately, the creator is really tricky to use for the time being.  I'm not sure it would be harder to use 3DSMax at this rate to make my first vehicle.  This is definitely in alpha.  There's no question about it.  A lot of the AI and animations has a lot of polishing left to do, the combat's hilariously clunky, and the 'storyline' isn't terribly well-balanced.  But that said, it's a fantastic start.  There's plenty to do, plenty to build, and lots of frightening spore-creator kinds of creatures to roam about and kill vicariously.  If you want a game that gives you enormous amounts of space and room for creativity, this is it.  All that aside, though, there's a hell of a lot you can do with building up your base and your armaments.  Shields and swords can be custom-designed with the voxel editor.  Buildings can be given lovely cornering and layouts, with plenty of accessories already avaioable for use.  The cars are just that perfect blend of controllable and completely bonkers to drive, making your bouts of ATVing hilarious, wonky, and yet not actually frustrating.  This game picks -way- up once you start getting into vehicles and colony control.  That said, to get the resources needed to get there, you're probably gonna have to look at the wiki.  There are very few veins of certain resources.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a wonderful game and fulfilled all my expectations.  I highly recommend it, because as much fun as I've had with it now, it's only going to get better as the game comes closer and closer to exiting early access.  There are still some bugs to work out, but I wouldn't say they're a major hindrance to enjoying Planet Explorers.I played several hours of the campaign and a bit of the exploration mode.  The mining, crafting, gathering and cooking systems are very solid.  The 3D resource scanner system takes a lot of the guess work out of things, which is very welcome, and the inventory system isn't oppressive with encumberance or backpack limitations.  Upgrading gear between schematics and resource quality was very rewarding and interesting - eventually taking huge chunks of a mountain out at a time felt really good after plinking away at it with a low tier copper pickaxe.The combat has a lot of flexibility and is entirely gear dependent, and if you have the right minerals, you have the best gear.  The follower systems ensures very good balance for most situations.  Multiplayer was a blast, and buildin my own settement was very rewarding.  As was building my own vehicle from a blueprint starting with no template, only key parts.  The game's seeds are not impossibly large, and have a lot going on to the point where you'll never have to trudge for a long distance totally bored, unless you want to just to explore.  Very interesting wildlife designs and behaviors, lots of predator/prey ambient stuff going on that you can watch.  The giant antagonists are rightfully dangerous and intimidating, very challenging but not impossible to overcome with a solid team.I very much enjoy this game.  If I had to complain, I'd say that I wish there was more to the character customization, and some of the storyline quests have some annoying bugs, mostly relating to friendly AI behavior.  The game can be gorgeous in places, but only if you ignore some of the low res, constantly repeating ground textures.  Regardless, I still highly recommend Planet Explorers.

content:
5, 2014
Early Access Review
								Had it for about a week now, and so far the impression is good!First off, the creation system is amazing and to be commended. Honestly it allows for nearly unparalleled design freedom, limited only by the resources available to your character, which to be honest aren't too difficult to obtain. Making vehicles and weapons that you can use in-game without having to mod them in is spectacular, and overall the system is fairly easy to use and understand.The mining is effective, if a bit on the clunky side, as the camera often jumps around or makes it hard to see what you're doing, but it ends up being more a minor annoyance than anything game breaking. If you find it unenjoyable enough you can always skip it by hunting and buying all the resources you need from NPC's with meat.Combat is fun but unfinished, the animations and hit detection aren't the best, especially with melee weapons. It can be hard to tell when you've landed a hit, as the sound effects are placeholder and creatures don't really react much to it. Guns I feel are a lot more effective and fun to use, and hunting is overall a fun part of the game. It just needs work, which apparently it will get in the alpha .8 versions.The controls for the game are all-in-all pretty good. They get the job done, they don't feel too counter-intuitive, and they aren't a big hindrance in most aspects of gameplay. The only negative for me personally when playing was I found it annoying to switch weapons, particularly if you're switching to a sword and shield, because there is no way to scroll through weapons currently you have to assign both to number keys, which means you have to equip both the sword AND shield. With guns it's less of an issue, but it would be nice to be able to scroll through weapons easier, and to be honest if you have a shield it should auto-equip the best one with a sword.The world is definitely one of the best parts of the game, with a HUGE variety in both the flora and fauna, in different parts of each biome, and different biomes. Creatures have basic behaviours, for instance herbivores will form a herd and fend off predators as a group, whereas some predators may hunt in packs. When a creature is wounded it may attempt to run away, and predators will actively hunt prey. They do not eat prey yet, which means you can get free resources if you chase a predator off a carcass, but that may be added in later as well.Each biome also offers different herbs you can collect which have different uses, adding extra incentive to explore (as if the beautiful world with interesting creatures isn't incentive enough), and the various NPC survivors you meet will fill you in on the backstory of the game, including events that happened on earth/mars, and what causes the divide between earthlings and martian settlers.The Quest system is pretty basic; go here, do this, do that, save this person, escort them, collect these resources, etc. Nothing revolutionary, but the rewards make them worth doing I guess, and the backstory is interesting.Build mode (what you use to construct buildings) is overall pretty intuitive and fun, with many different shapes to choose from and ways to place them, you are pretty much limited by your imagination. Want a Dark Tower of Doom? Build it. Want an underwater castle? Build it. Want to live on a mountain, or IN a mountain? Go ahead. The free build mode allows you to place things anywhere you want around your character, which is waaaaay better than the minecraft way of doing things, where you have to move your character everywhere to build things.Crafting is very, very complex and deep, with each component being craftable, and in turn being used to make something even bigger and more complex. You will need to craft the components and have all the resources on you if you are to import a vehicle/weapon from the creation system, which makes perfect sense to me.For an early access game, and especially an alpha, I think it's one of the most polished ones I've played. It's fun, and it has so much potential, I honestly would recommend it if you can see past the few small issues there are and you enjoy exploration, building, hunting, and driving things you design.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
er 4, 2016
												Note: I've only played singleplayerThe game itself is nice, the crafting aspect is deep, almost TOO deep (Not a bad thing, I just haven't gotten the hang of it) The map seems pretty huge. but that's okay, you can build vehicles (flying, land, and sea) to get around.The story is interesting, not like, game of the year "10/10 would bang" good, but it's interesting, you're apart of a group of people who are looking for a new home in the universe and you crash land on this planet, and now you're trying to find everyone, and it goes from there. The voice audio for some of the characters sounds muffled, kinda weird and kills the immersion. I'm assuming they have that on the radar to work on. The combat is cool, although (I could be wrong) but it doesn't seem like headshots matter when fighting creatures. not a big deal, but just something I noticed. You can have followers, that's neat, and they have skills / abilities that differ from follower to follower. You can have them stay put somewhere, follow you, etc. and you can set them to defensive, aggressive, and passive. You have to manage various types of ailments. Infection, injuries, etc. oh, and of course hunger. Don't eat too much though! there's a penalty for that. Pretty cool. Overall I love the game, I kept telling myself that I was going to go play something else, and next thing I knew I had been playing it all day and didn't want to stop so I could build that next thing, or finish this ONE quest, etc. I can't wait to see what they do next for this game, it's neat.

content:
2014
Early Access Review
								Without a doubt the best game I have played of this genre! It manages to captures the essence of frontier planatery exploration while allows for a very playable game. When they say it's a sandbox game, they mean it. You are not restricted in playstyle and can easily play the game in so many different ways. You can play it like a basic action game, running around and hunting monsters. You can play it like minecraft, building elaborate structures. You can play it almost like spore, creating interesting designs. Or you can even play it like a management game. The wealth of possibilties was something that really took me back.What is most important however, is that it is still an early access game, but it doesn't play much like one. The game feels quite robust and has less bugs and problems than in some post-released games. This does not however, mean there is no work to be done, it is not finished and can only really get better. Would definately recommend this game, absolutely amazing.

content:
22, 2014
Early Access Review
								A sandbox single/multiplayer tailored-story-driven or randomly generated RPG action shooter trader vehicular colony-builder farming mining creating exploring game.Basically, it's the "everygame" at long last, and unlike many Early Access games it's not only living up to its promises but far surpassing them!-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------But the reason I really love this game isn't its gameplay, it's the incredible story they're weaving with the single player, one of the greatest science fiction tales I've seen!You are one of many colonists heading to planet Maria, a seeminly perfect "garden" planet. When entering orbit a mysterious manmade looking object collides with the ship leading to you and many other colonists abandoning ship in escape craft and landing on Maria's southern continent, while the ship has crashed on the northern continent. You then spend the game rounding up survivors, unravelling the secrets of Maria, the possible secrets of the crew, the tensions between the colonists from Earth and Mars, and uncovering some INCREDIBLE vistas and revelations.*Update 29/12/15* The 0.9 build was just released and so much has been improved since I last played back at 0.8.- Movement is now fantastically fluid. A couple of animation issues on certain terrain but nothing you wouldn't expect in a sandbox game.- Melee combat is now actually fun.- MONORAILS!- MORE STORY!- Fantastic improvements to the UI. They've really been putting a lot of thought into it.- Probably a ton of other features, I'll let you know when I've played some more!

content:
19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet explorers, in many ways, is silmilar to Everquest Landmark.  But better.  It has a create, story, multiplayer, and adventure mode, depending on what you are looking for.  The Build system for structures is great, maybe even better the EQ.  The planet is filled with minerals and underground cave systems.  The Build system for weapons and vehicals is very good.  I am no artest, but I found it very easy to use, with a little practice, and can see how someone with more skill then me can take it and create awesome things.I paid for a Founders pack with EQ Landmark and I should of just got this game.  EQ is fun, but the MMO part of it really stinks.  The only interaction is to look at others creations, as you run by, and fight for claims and minerals.  I may edit this after Landmark offically comes out, but what I have seen for the last month or so of beta does not impress me much, and this game has everything I was looking for.The only real bugs I've encounterd are falling through the map after a crashing my car and landing upside down, and crashing twice to desktop(with a game pop-up that an error was encountered.).  I'm about 10 hours in and it looks like there is a lot more interesting story to go.  If you like minecraft, but wish there was more story, and were thinking about EQ Landmark, this is the game for you!

Early Access Review
								This game is pretty special and I'm only just scratching the surface of the tutorial.The cliche would be to write something along the lines of "if you like Minecraft, were disappointed with StarForge and play MMOs then you'll be right at home" but there's so much more to this game. You are often dwarfed by the mountains and lakes, the beasts and the plants that characterise the landscape and there's a lot more to gathering and crafting than just digging until you get lucky and throwing it all together.You can design your own weapons and vehicles, dig vast underground bunkers in a way I've not seen since Red Faction and create structures brick by brick, alone or as part of a team.The price may put some people off but this is as good as "value for money" gets. I forsee this being an amazing experience online as the community grows, learns the game and gets creative.

Early Access Review
								Even though it is in early access, it still has many more things in it than other builders do.  You can create vehicles to travel/battle creatures, manage colonies, setup automated defenses and attract monsters to them.  I have been playing this and EQNext.  Neither game is finished, but this game has many more features.  There are some stability issues and it has not been optimized for performance, yet.  So, if you have a low end PC, it may be wise to wait until it releases.Fast forward 2 years, and I'm still hopeful it all comes together.  The crowds are growing turgid with negativity by spewing comments about how much money they have pulled in.  People obviously do not know how much developers and designers cost.  A Jr. Dev, that will work at a much slower pace and produce bugs, starts around $60k/yr.  A Sr. Dev, that should work much quicker and more efficiently has no necessary cap on their costs, but it usually floats around the $100k/yr area.

content:
15, 2016
Early Access Review
								I thought I had reviewed this already... huh. Anyway this game is in development so there are some UI tweaks and bugs to fix but the core thing itself - is a thing of wonder. You start off wondering what the hell just happened and why the blaze you just crashed a spaceship and don't have any weapons other than, quite literally, a small plastic knife. Pretty soon you're collecting plants, digging, chopping trees, running to or from alien animals, doing busy-body work for various NPCs for 'recipes' for new things to make like armour or weapons or circuit boards.Then you find yourself making a cute little house somewhere and you've built yourself a little aircraft in the shape of something not safe for work, realised that doesn't fly well enough to even get off the ground without flipping upside down, so you then attempt to build something that is both hilarious and practical. You can sculpt a bow out of gold while your companions use lasers because arrows are cheap and then you find yourself on the run from bears that shoot actual fireballs until you realise you can totally just build a little tower to stand on like a boss while you plunk at them with arrows.Then you're building up a small colony and assigning jobs because you've been unofficially made Mayor and thus you build yourself the nicest home while your poor colonists get open space living with as many beds as you can cram into one big room and they're doing your farming for you now and fighting various random animals and running into the ocean shooting alien seagulls and every time you think "Okay this is everything now" it keeps getting bigger. So you make another bow in the shape of [censored] that can one shot giant space beetles and realise you haven't even explored the other biomes yet so you make a flying shopping trolley that puts any followers into the baby seat and trolley off to parts unknown. 11/10 would humiliate Rol again.

content:
er 27, 2016
												This is almost a very good game.  It took installing it again to remember why I quit playing it.  So, drawbacks first and then what's so great about it.  Drawbacks:If you're not playing in the equivalent of creative mode, so that you have content, then you have two modes: story and adventure.  In story, there are timesinks as you gradually gain access to scripts that allow you to produce better and better items.  But by the time you have a thriving colony, there's nothing left to work toward except the end of the story.  If you play adventure mode, then you bypass all of the grinding because you begin with all scripts.  However, this renders the majority of scripts useless because you'll skip straight to the best items.  This is the better option for exploring and building a colony.  However, the drawback there is that you only get four NPCs and there's no guarantee that any of them will join your colony.  There are reportedly more NPCs out on the map, in many cases, very far from your starting point.  But the map is not infinite, which means that your progress is still capped.  Once you've built up your colony and recruted all the accessible NPCs on the map, there's nothing to work toward.  How to correct these drawbacks:Literally all it needs is a tech tree for story mode and new NPCs that join the map to be recruited in adventure mode.  The tech tree would allow the player to choose what to access first, rather than wander until NPCs with the necessary scripts are discovered.  It would still be a bit of a timesink, but the player would have more control over how that timesink is progressed through, and could prioritize goals.  As it is, later scripts are often found at the same time as earlier scripts, rendering even the explore-to-advance angle pointless (ie, finding the script for a copper bow at the same time as iron bow and pistol).  Having new NPCs wander onto adventure maps would allow for expansion of colonies to encompass the map, providing a long term, ongoing goal of expansion.  What makes this game great:I hate to use the word "potential" when it's so close to realizing that potential.  Imagine Rimworld with a RPG built on top of it, where you control a single character directly.  Imagine first person play in that game, with the ability to design custom items and structures to use and share with others.   Imagine skill trees for your colonists, vehicles, and diverse challenges on the map.  I'm clicking "Yes" that I recommend this game, but I do so with the wish that we could click a "Maybe" option.  The fact is that this game is very close to being something awesome, and at least where adventure mode is concerned, it would be very simple for the developers to realize its potential.  But as of this review, they haven't.  The result is that a rich game leaves you feeling empty, like it could have been so much more, and the simplicity of what it is missing tacks frustration onto that sentiment.Addendum:It may be possible to put something together in the World Editor that would alleviate the adventure mode problem.  Perhaps, for example, a map with enough NPCs that can be recruited to make it worth playing.  The first problem is, the DPI scaling for the World Editor is so horrendous that on a modern 4k screen, it can't even be used.  The second problem is that even World Editor maps are randomly generated, and editing terrain (along with practically all other functionality in the editor) is non-intuitive, slow, and frustrating.  All the reasons you can think of to use a World Editor, are reasons not to use it in this case.  I still think that this game can realize its potential, but I'm disappointed that it hasn't gotten there yet.  In this case, it appears that the developers begin with the assumption that people want to play the game, when instead they should stop and think about what would motivate people to play in the first place and then build on that.

content:
ry 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've played this game on and off since the original alpha and I have to say the devs have brought this a long way. Still alot of work to be done but they have done so much to bring this into a "stable" early access program. It's way too easy to sink hours into this game. With the first person, it's very immersive and with the vehicle and weapon crafting, dynamic weather and time, music, environments, it's easy to get lost in the world and the story. You want to engage in every dialogue to know more of the story and sometimes the npc's give you something for essentially just listening to them. You can sink hours just in mining to create a weapon all your own design and the reward of creating a master lazer rifle is worth the grind. A good number of bugs, but the devs have been active lately with addressing them and progressing the story. Ive spent hours creating and building a Wrangler Unlimited and vtol passenger carrier, and to watch them work correctly and help to get around the map so much faster is amazing. I never post a review or opinion, but it's worth giving the devs credit. Keep it up Pathea. This is the game a lot of us have been waiting for.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game can be a lot of fun if you like open world crafting type games.  What is particularly unique about it is the cad-cam style crafting interface that theoretically allows you to build anything you want out of your own user-defined shapes and utilizing in-game mechanical and electrical components.  In addition to crafting, there is resource gathering, hunting, enemies to kill, and discovery of new areas on the map.  I would probably play this much more often but as building and harvesting take a lot of time, I have kind of shelved this game until it is a little more updated.  Its a bit of a pain to build something extensive and then have to start over because of patch incompatability.  If you are patient about patches and love these kind of open world survival games, I would recommend this, but I might also suggest waiting for a more complete build.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								First impression is pretty incredible. Glorious 3D environments with vibrant flora and fauna sprawling in all directions greet players first thing out of the gate, complete with a skybox full of planets and stars at night. The spirit of adventure takes center-stage, with a massive open world to explore and several modes of travel with more on the way. System to design custom swords and guns is implemented and looks versatile, but seems to require some getting used to, as with the UI for designing and erecting buildings. Running and jumping animations are somewhat clunky, and character customization is minimal for now, but these things are all minor problems surrounding what looks like a game with vast potential. Worth the price tag even during alpha release.In words closer to my typical format; it's the margarita produced if you shoved Phantasy Star Universe, Monster Hunter, and Starbound into a blender with tequila and a bunch of ice.

												I have followed and played the game through many versions since it first came out. The game has always had some bugs in all versions even its current released state, at least the developers still give updates. Game breaking bugs can still happen such as a npc falling through the floor and being unreachable and unable to further the main quests. It is advised to have multiple save files in case something goes wrong. The game also has a lot of back and forth travel between locations at times which gets tedious I don't know why I can't just phone the npc at times. The map is quite large but the story doesn't use much of it and has the player travel sometimes long distances.A very big issue is that the game pages (kickstarter, their website, steam) didn't tell me at any point that this is not a complete game. When you get the end it plays a short cutscene then "END" pops up, then a "To be continued". That is very disappointing.

												So I see a lot of people complaining so I decided to write my own review.                PROS.1. THIS GAME HAS BEEN OFFICIALLY RELEASED!2. This game has fixed so many errors since these people last played.3. You can create your own colony, and even pick up quests from npcs! (Like starbound)4. It has a full length story mode which is really good btw.5. Seems like the creators are still optimizing the game after release for now.6. 60fps on a gtx 960 graphics card, 0 lag.7. I was to setup my own server in less than 5 min after portforwarding (they even tell you what to portforward in game)8. I have 1.4MB/s download (10mbps) and 0.7MB/s upload (5mbps) and my friend who lives 1000 miles away gets 0 lag on my server!9. The whole world can be edited.10. Story mode editor                             Cons1.Adventure Mode let's you skip all the progression unless you use the skill tree on MP2.When building houses you only have 8 blocks to choose from which to me is very limited compared to other games.3.Pulling out your tools to do something appears to be super slow.4.You have stand inside the tree to chop it down.5.If you skip story mode you will be lost on how to make a vehicle!6. Dungeons feel empty.7. Lack of machinery compared to other games like this.8.Super Long Nights on MP            Remember this game is still being updated after release for now and all the crashes and stuff or bad perfomance have been fixed many times over!

content:
y 14
Product received for free
												I have only played 15 hours and haven't even tried multiplayer, but I wanted to still say what I think of it so far.It's great! It has a plethora of issues but all in all it's really fun to play.It's like Mine Craft or Landmark with actual gameplay. Don't get me wrong, I like both of those games too, but after building my sky castle in Minecraft I just always hit a brick wall. What to do with it? Well Planet Explorers tries to answer that question. It has huge enemies that can attack your settlement. It has quests, characters, weapons, vehicles and all sorts of stuff.I should mention the negative points too though. Well... Everything that I just listed there doesn't work all that great. The game looks like a 10 years old MMO (Star Wars Galaxies comes to mind) and the animations range from ok to horrible. There are many bugs and just weird design choices, can't move while mining? Why?It's really easy to beat pretty much any enemy if you just are patient enough to run in circles and hit them in the back. They are mostly slow and not very smart.Also I recommend you just skip all the parts where the game tries to hold your hand. In the very beginning there is a tutorial that I guess would have gone through everything in excruciating detail. Thankfully there was a door with the word "EXIT" just behind me. I ran straight though it and was eternally grateful I did. The game does a good job teaching you the ropes as you go on, the tutorial was really unnecessary.So there you have it. It feels like an unfinished game that has had a very limited budget made by people who had a huge vision. They had a ton of stuff they wanted to put in and not enough resources to actually succeed.Still, somehow they managed to make a game that is definitely worth your while. And just for making a Mine Craft-like game that actually feels like a complete game rather than a fun tech demo is a feat in and of itself.

content:
er 12, 2016
Product received for free
												So far I'm overall enjoying this game, but it does have problems. I'm unfinished with the storyline, but other reviewers have covered that, so I won't get too into it. I may change this review after I beat the storyline. I apologize for the fact my review seems more negative than positive, but I am enjoying it more than I'm annoyed with the issues.Pros:- The building system could be refined but is overall easy to work with and building nice structures isn't particularly difficult. I also really dig the custom creation, save for the armor--I would have highly preferred there was a base we could paint over, as the creation method is far too blocky to look normal as clothes. I wanted to make some skimpy armor for my guy that matched the female version, but it sure seems impossible with the tools you're given.- Fighting is a strong point--I really like the combat system, shooting bows and guns is fun, and the difficulty is good. Hunting is enjoyable. The turrets are also nice. The swords are not as enjoyable, and I haven't used them much.- Crafting system is solid and pretty damn expansive. No complaint at all here. Very easy to use.- Resource gathering is painless.- The fast travel system is pretty well done, also, but it does make the motorbikes feel pretty useless.-  I looooove the character creation. Probably a minor detail to most people, though.- The world is gigantic and easy to get lost in. I've spent a lot of time so far just wandering and finding different areas.----Cons:- The armor creation system (mentioned above!)- Enemy animations don't line up well sometimes. I do really enjoy fighting, don't get me wrong, but it does tend to hit you when it looks like it shouldn't and not get hit when it should have. In multiplayer, the other character model is often not where it should be, even though you're playing LAN.- The AI is wonky, both for allies and enemies. It just acts really weird sometimes. I've sometimes fought baddies high up only for them to suddenly jump and kill themselves for no obvious reason, or had someone I was bringing somewhere just...run away, only for the quest to fail because they got attacked. This is somewhat unfrequent, but it happens.- The person who got this for me thought it was still in early access. I didn't know it wasn't until I came to review--it feels like it is. It's clearly a good game, and like I said I am overall enjoying it, but it doesn't feel finished. I'm nervous about the reviews that say the story mode ends abruptly. It looks like they are still developing this game, so hopefully it will still reach this stage.- The fact you have to manually close a server you're hosting with task manager is ridiculous. Not that it's hard, but it's annoying and feels very lazy.- Movement does have some issues. The random rolls and oversteps have killed or hurt me a couple times when I was too high. The ground vehicle movement is very weird, though I have yet to try the other vehicle types. (Will update when/if I do.) The camera controls are actually very easy to control, though.- No way to track other players, afaik :( It's really frustrating to open the map when someone is getting attacked and try to figure out how to get to them. I also really wish there were custom markers you could follow like you can with quests.

er 11, 2016
												If the trailer catches your eye, then download the DEMO.   I played the demo and was hooked, I played for 2 days then realized I'm in quite deep so better buy it.   After buying it I expected to re-do what I had already played but no, the old data from the demo goes to your existing game you began with!   Vehicles are a challenge on the rough terrain, but I'm sure that will be relieved when I obtain flight travel.   Game is really fun to play with no frustrations, as long as you stock up on the things that you've already learned.  Nice and large world to adventure through, crafting is of the highest levels in my mind. The game gives you enough crafting on a whole and if you need more then go to crafting.com.   If this game is lacking stuff or has too much stuff, then welcome to the club for people who are looking for the right game for themself.   Again, download the DEMO if you don't want to have to read moronic reviews like this one.    P.S. go through the tutorial and repeat the first 20 minutes of the game if you failed to listen like me.   Cheers! Awesome game devs!

content:
y 2
												Time for the G.B.F. The good! The bad! And the fugly. (The full frontal review, no TL;DR here)So this holiday season, I finally got time to not-adult. You know, subsist on a steady diet of chimichangas and rum spiked egg nog... hellava combo coming back up for an encore. So like any green thing thats avoiding any and all contact with the outside world I decided to dive into indie-land and throw my hard won shiny coins at Steam, thus bringing us, to Planet Explorers. (This is an early release, so, some of the things may be fixed or unfuqed in the future, so I'm burping up salsa and crumbs on what the game is right at this moment. Like right now... at this moment... and stuff.)Okay First, the Good. And seriously folks, I thought about this stuff in the shower, it was that good. Wink wink.Graphically it is spot on great to look at. Well till someone wants to build a mega base of total badassery among the fields and flowers. But hey, progress requires alot of things to die for my needs. The colors are vibrant and stand out pulling you into the world and sharply contrasting the view so the little things stand out. Plus they fixed the blurry font so I didn't need to put on my spectacles to read and then blur the world. This game first off is a visual feast, alien critters (that must all die for my throne of meat) really look strange and for the most part unique. Except for the monkey things that throw poo and have audio like chittering monkeys... It looks and sounds like an alien world with the same ol biomes given a bit of a twist to make them stand out a bit from the norm... Best example would be the mushroom mountains in the grasslands.Character customization is in depth enough to make you look different from other people, although i'm willing to bet in multiplayer it comes down to recognizing someones hair and outfit. Speaking of outfits, BOOYAH! The late game outfits again look and feel futuristic, with glowing lights, weird angles and questionable monotone with flavor color overlay schemes... but still far future.People are ♥♥♥♥♥ + Don't get attached. It's good to see a game with political undertones, because as a green ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, I know humans are great at snubbing one another. Right off the bat (Drumroll) Martians and Earthlings (Ba-Dum-Tiss) don't like one another. See even in the future, humans gotta human. In the Story-mode of the game this plays out fairly well and has a good thread to keep RPGers asking questions, and if the option were available, sides would be picked. And some NPCs (Hailey! My blue haired Martian anime sweetheart!) die. Of course if your totally prepared a *few* can be prevented... But that was an alien invasion to fort Badass II that was not prepared for 250 laser turrets, a fully trained combat squad with top end everything... and me, sipping spiced cider watching a futile invasion. (Although some deaths are purely scripted and try as I may with overwhelming destruction, some deaths can't be prevented.)Now for the bad... The audio, omg the audio! 95% of the time it was immersive and really reeled me in. But there are moments... Looking at you monkey things. That rip you right out of it, or sent me into fits of throwing my headset across the room. The main music track is glorious... till it hits the high notes that make a beagle howl in pain. Some of the settlement items drown out spoken dialogue with their droning and some you wonder if they even work from being too quiet. Turrets will literally make you crap your pants! (I had to wear pull-ups about 20 hours in.) Especially the gatling turrets. Most people are willing to unzip and let a warm stream of truth leave a messy if slightly briney coating all over the spoken dialogue, myself, not really... It's bad... almost on unprofessional levels. You can read along the words in the text box don't match up, some people are faking accents, Some have residual background noise, or were recorded too quietly and had to have the volume cranked up post production, or just failed with getting and using a popper. Still I have heard and cringed at vastly worse... So I'll give Pathea a pass for just trying to coordinate audio, rather than using a central recording studio.(It's tough man.)Usefully useless NPCs. A major facet is colony / resource management. Thus you get people to lord over, and hooboy, do I like commanding weak humans into a pure force of fire wielding death monkeys! And some of them right out of the gate come skilled for such an endeavor. And others make for an exellent fall back crew to be trained up to fill roles highly needed by the legion of "don't you even think of invading alien scum!". The biggest detractor is in storyline mode whereas it's nearly non-existant in adventure mode. You get a guy like Chen who makes for a great first string soldier to train your defense force, but due to quests he's too busy (aka the scripting wont allow it.) Forcing you to train at least one duplicate (who hopefully does not die) to play both primary task and trainer. This happens quite a bit, and super late into the story mode you will have acess to some very skilled individuals who are sorely needed for maximum effect for the colony as a whole, but are nothing more than window dressing after becoming part of your team. Yeah Tank, F-you too buddy... Nice skill set you have there... The farmers could use you man, oh you can't be assigned... And I can't just up and shoot you in the face... crud. (But I'll totally give a pat on the back for adding the Korean girl-child. Having a young person of mid-teen years added immersion to the fact it was a COLONY SHIP and not everyone would be old farts, quite immersive.)Questing is not really rewarding... kinda. Okay again the RPG elements are spot on, I can't dish on that... not even force a slippery wet fart in the general direction of story questing, both Story and adventure modes do a fairly good job of rewarding the player in that aspect. Do mission = unlock more of the adventure to be told with some sugar sprinkles on top... the pretty colored sprinkles like on cup-cakes. But the side missions is where I can definately squidge out a wet fart with the power to break my thunder buckets gravitational pull. Whats the point? Okay in some cases, you may unlock a follower who will be your high maintainence combat buddy... That's cool. But for the most part, the basic filler fetch quests Do X, Craft X, Gift X, yield nothing... Like that chocolate factory guy (NAME COPYRIGHTED) The same one who angrilly exclaims you get nothing. Side missions are a filler for now that mostly give nothing in return. Grumpy Goblin.And to the Fugly... the things that make your toes curl up in terror like waking up next to you best friends dog naked.(Don't ask.)FIRST Whisky Tango Foxtrot Pathea? Adding theme music to Chen?!? (Latest update) Look if it was an April fools update, I would totally understand. But it drowns out dialogue during story missions. Actually drowns out everything. It is so loud and breaks the living hell out of the fun factor I got to the point of trying to lock him in a box filled with live grenades. Pull it out, pull it out now! This is one baby (the theme song) that needs smothered in the crib!The unskippable repeating wonder credits. Okay kudos on the ending and where it leaves us salivating for more... mmm freshly smothered baby meat... Fact is once you hit the credits your new old friend will be Ctrl + Alt + Del. Theres no other way to stop it, and it's on a loop... it just keeps going on and on, like this review.Random gen NPC mutants from planet X. Random generator needs tweeking so everyone doesn't look inbred. Nuff said.Seriously though, Despite my belching. This game is filled to the brim so far with many "oooo neet!" moments, excellent crafting, a intriguing story overall, and reminders that you always need to be prepared. So in closing, Like Survival / Exploration / RPG? Definately Get this game!

content:
er 25, 2016
												Lots of people seem to complain about this game but I have nothing but praise so far.1. Performance was substandard until I made a few changes to graphics and perfomance prefrances then it orked great (I should also add my laptop is certianly not a good laptop.)2. People were complaining about vehicles but so far I have had no problems. (Tho I've only used one.)3. People were saying that the sounds and the graphics were bad But like I said before my laptop is hardly meant for gaming and with a few minor changes to settings the game is visualy and audibly stunning and has an amazing soundtrack.4. people were coplaining about some of th quests but now that I've done a few I realise they blew those way out of preportion and the quests are actually not all that bad (So far at least) 5. people complained about the combat but contrary to what they said it I actualy found it quite smooth and most definately enjoyable. (And I haven't even gotten a single skill yet)6. I can't really say much about crafting yet exept that it takes a little while to figure out but is easy to figure out and use once you do (at least with items, I haven't built athing else yet)7. it is surprisingly realistic with a variety of health factors including desiese, malnutrition and even mental health with different medicins for different things but this systm is well done and I don't see it becoming a chore. (Tho admitedly I havn't gotten all that far)8. character customistion is amazing, so simple a child could could do it yet it is still easy to make your character look the way you want it to (Keep in min tho there are only so many options as far as that goes)9. The game feels right, it feels magical and majestic yet also dangerous at times and is the only game in a long time that has time warped my mind and stolen my day. (Only 3 games capture this spark for me and they are not surprisingly all games that had alot of effort put into their creation, the other two are Fable 2 and The last of us.If there is a downside to this game I'd say it's that you probably need alot of time on your hands to really get into it so if you are an extremely busy person then if you buy it you will probably end upputting it aside until you holidays or something. (of course if you have too much time on your hands this is an upside.)From what I have experienced so far I rate it 10/10

Early Access Review
								Nice balance of exploration and discovery. Decent variety of gorgeous creatures and environments. Crafting system is well balanced and varied. Creation system looks daunting but is very intuitive. Does need fleshing out a bit but devs are well on their way in the right directionProblem is the multiplayer. Netcode is atrocious. The general asshattery you encounter in minecraft is here on a much smaller scale, but theres no tools or resources to manage it yet. Singleplayer 8/10 (Expect the devs to improve to make it 10/10)Multiplayer 4/10 (Truly worried about this aspect as the list of fixes is large)

								Absolutely love this game - even at the lowest graphic settings the world is breathtaking.Once you get the hang of the controls they are fairly intuitive - the build function and ability to make your own custom objects and vehicles is a big plus too.The wide range of biomes and almost complete destructibility of the world increases the 'real feel' of the game, and the crafting system (replicator) is one of the best I've seen yet.Only downside possibly is that it is very graphic intensive - I have a fairly high spec mac and i have the graphics set to their lowest setting. content:
13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Planet Explorers is a great game with amazing potential - much of which has already been realised in spite of the game only being in Alpha, with the ability to create all sorts of gizmos from cars, boats, planes, helicopters, buildings and even the kitchen sink - literally. You really are only confined by the limits of your own imagination.Having been playing the single player mode since Alpha 0.81, there are issues in multiplayer that really need addressing (A0.831 being the latest version at the time of writing). Also given that this is still in Alpha I cannot stress that these are issues that will eventually be resolved in due course.Undoubtedly the biggest issue thus far has been that hosted servers do not always save your progress. You can spend hours upon hours creating things (which luckily you can save as isos to use again at a later date), but if you're unfortunate enough not to be able to do this and your server fails to either save or to appear on the server list, then all your hard work will have been for nought.The game also has a tendency to spawn your character underneath blocks you've already placed, which is no better demonstrated than logging into the game and finding your character face-deep in the dirt under your house. This latter point is obviously an issue regarding optimisation that can easily be resolved, though servers not saving your hard work is a much more serious issue.While single player 'story mode' and multiplayer 'build mode' seem quite stable, multiplayer 'adventure mode' on the other hand seems very buggy by comparison.In spite of all this however, I'm very happy to say that the potential of this game is such that it warrants further and continued interest on my part*, though I may update this review as and when necessary. 4.5/5--------* The game has been so promising that I bought extra copies for my friends.

It's extremely fun, has a good story and it's not too buggy at all.
