content:
28, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you have patience and don't mind waiting for something that will be special, get this game!  I might just buy it for some of my friends anyways!Random thoughts on the game:Game has tons of potential, the horrendously slow development time has been a pain in the butt, but at least they've not given up on it!Compared to the many other voxel games out there, I feel that this one allows you the most creativity and customization, just on a much smaller scale.  You can import your own textures and decals so that alone gives you nearly unlimited design possibilities.You want to make an exact replica of a WW2 Tommy Gun complete with serial numbers etched into the gun, you can!  You want to make an Apache Longbow on a 1:1 scale?  You can!  You want to make a wooden pirate ship?  You can!Trying to make a solid glass material, I accidentally made a block that changes color with the time of day, I call it a happy accident!Downside, no real flying vehicles, the airships may "fly", but they still handle like a car and can't even go over many trees.  Fortunately the hit boxes for the larger trees are ignored and you can go through them.Quests are a little buggy at times, but I am happy to notice that they are usually fixed as the community points them out and ones that aren't fixxable with a patch usually fix themselves after you save your game and reload it.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 24, 2015
Early Access Review
Planet Explorers is certainly one of the best games in Early Access. There are some bugs and a lack of polish, but overall a great buy.Pros Very full featured--By this, I mean it delivers all its core game mechanics with depth. Trading works. Crafting works. Crafting is multi-tiered. Crafting the items isn't hard to mess up. But the ability to build your vehicles and items with such minute detail is incredible and really no bugs to speak of here. The storyline--Typically I don't care much for the story of a game. This one had me reloading saves if I missed anything. I loved the story up to where they have it. Building your own colony--And you get to populate it as well, assign jobs. Essentially micromanage the thing if you wish. You get out of it what you put into it--This game answers the call of your desires. Strategy? Check. Action? Check. Survival? Check. Exploration? Absolutely. The detail--This goes hand in hand with the next bullet point. The creators of the game took great care to make everything in the world make sense. The NPCs are exploring the planet and explain why the planet is the way it is when you land there. Exploration--It is a joy to just fly around and see the sights and discover new things. The game has loads of content.Cons Bugs--There are game breaking bugs. I'm not sure if I finished the storyline up to where it was built or if my quests just bugged out. This game is in alpha. And I can assure you that the majority of the bugs I encountered that left a bad taste in my mouth dealt with the their questing system. There were points where I ran out of memory (I'm running full settings on a great PC). No big deal, reload an autosave. But the questing bugs caused me to lose hours. I request that there be some console mode like Skyrim to assist players in self-help remedial measures when it comes to questing bugs. Lack of Polish--I include this because every aspect of the game can use more polish. Polish is the stuff that makes a B+ into an A. And the developers should hold off on this aspect. The game does not need polish in this state. It is in Early Access.  END OF LIST (for now)I mean that. These are the only cons to me. It plays like a finished game short of the questing bugs. I can excuse this of course. It is in Alpha. And the lack of polish is not a con to me, but I leave it there for a discriminating gamer.Story mode is not where it ends. I wanted to put Adventure Mode in Pros, but because of it being more or less an afterthought, I felt that Adventure Mode could not be justified in the Pro category. Adventure Mode is basically playing a randomized map with all features except the main story. But it needs much more work. But I am encouraged that it is there in the first place and am eager to see the developers flesh out the features of the adventure mode. Therefore, I do not think it qualifies as a Con I would prefer not being given everything (scanner updates and all scripts in the beginning of the Adventure Mode). Instead, I would like this to be an option that I could elect.A previous reviewer gave a thumbs down in saying that the project was so immense that it would never be completed. Gamers have a vote in this. We vote with our wallets and our recommendations. I have done both, and encourage you to purchase this game and play some of it. It is expensive for early access, but the content it delivers is well beyond its price. And then please, when you discover this game's merits, support the devs. Endorse this game that so richly deserves recognition.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
er 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game definitely has some potential, and I think that by the time it has been released, most of my issues with it will be fixed. And if they are, I will definitely rewrite this review and recommend it. So here's why I don't recommend this game at the moment; First, it's an alpha so there's going to be lag and bugs. I expected this and this isn't really a complaint about the game itself, and I'm positive most of it will be fixed but it still made my experience with it worse. Then there's the combat, the combat is terrible and consists of clicking left click and hoping you won't die. While you're slashing your sword you can actually not even move, so pretty much all strategy is taken away here. The hit detection is broken too, I took damage several times when whatever I was fighting clearly did not hit me. If this game got a combat system similar to the one in Monster Hunter, that would be amazing, though that's probably putting my hopes too high. The mining isn't very fun either. In games like Minecraft, Terraria or Starbound, mining is awesome because it's very easy and when you see that diamond or whatever you get really excited. In this game, all you do is mine stone and hope you get something good. It's neither fun or exciting, and pretty awkward. I hope, and think this will be fixed by the time this game is released, and if it is I can see myself playing this a lot, but at the moment I don't feel like I can recommend this game.

You want to make an Apache Longbow on a 1:1 scale?  You can!  You want to make a wooden pirate ship?  You can!Trying to make a solid glass material, I accidentally made a block that changes color with the time of day, I call it a happy accident!Downside, no real flying vehicles, the airships may "fly", but they still handle like a car and can't even go over many trees.  Fortunately the hit boxes for the larger trees are ignored and you can go through them.Quests are a little buggy at times, but I am happy to notice that they are usually fixed as the community points them out and ones that aren't fixxable with a patch usually fix themselves after you save your game and reload it.

content:
2016
Early Access Review
								Planet explorers is the best open world sand box game that I have everr played. The combat is excellent with many different types of weapons to use and a wide variety of animals and aliens to hunt and all of them give some type of resource upon killing them, usually meat or some item that can be sold to vendors for currency. The crafting system is excellent and has many armor pieces that can be crafted out of differnt level resources from wood to diamonds. The crafting system also allows you to design and build custom armor, weapons, and aircraft/vehicles/boats all with their own individual stats based on what material you used and how much of that material is in the design. You can also manage a colony and build many useful buildings in the colony such as replicator, training station, repair facilities and more. You can build a tram in the game world and then ride in that tram. There are many quests to do in the story mode. There is a good farming system once you have a colony set up. There is a lot of things to do in this game. I highly recommend it.

content:
16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Quick summary at bottom of review.ReviewPlanet Explorers is a good game with even greater potential. Yes the game is Early Access and it wont be released/completed for a while yet, but it's certainly worth supporting the developers and watching the game evolve.In it's current state it is playable, though you'll encounter alot of bugs and such. One of the worst examples is the Adventure Mode randomly generated worlds. You choose 1 of 4 biomes to be your main biome to play in, the others you'll practically never see in game. Not only this but the original spawn point and camp is normally on it's own island surrounded by a large crevice on all sides (imagine Avatar's floating islands, except these are connected to the world vertically). Not too much of a problem, just build a make-shift bridge out of dirt or something. But it does cause alot of annoyance.Story Mode seem relatively good, though I have barely touched it as it is at this point a long tutorial which you can get the over all feel and mechanics of the game within an hour.As for custom content, this is where the game shines. You can create a nice variety of items and weapons in game at this time. Here's a quick list of 'functional' things you can create; Swords, Shields, Firearms, Boats, Wheeled Vehicles (any type on land transport), Helicopters and Planes. Now when I say functional I mean things that you can use. You can also create in-animate objects, wether it be a flag or a wall decoration, the option is there.As for the construction mechanic, it works well. Everything is built with blocks and easy to place with good camera controls, and your buildings don't look blocky at all they are smooth. Though the gathering of these resources is very tedious. Just scan for ores and mine them or just stand in one spot and hold LMB and keep mining. That's it. There is a scanner that can tell you the location of ores in the world within a short radius, but I rarely use it as the most needed ore can be found in stone alot of the time.Combat is again, tedious. Simpley hold LMB until it dies. That's it. Would be nice if there would be (in the future) a skill system making you more proficient in either melee or ranged, with usable skills so you have to be more active in combat. The problem you will have is in Adventure Mode, any level creature will spawn anywhere. You could spawn near an alien camp, which would mean aliens would always be close to you and until you have good enough loot you will keep dying. Thing's I'd Like To SeeMore 'functional' items to create. An example: custom bed or lights.Better combat with possibility of skills.Make mining less tedious (no idea how that'd be done though).Make world generation in Adventure mode contain all biomes.A variety of pre-built items for those who can't create things too well. Or at least blueprints for them (Just a simple car and plane etc)SummarySo a quick summary of positive (+) and negative (-) points of the game:+Custom content, create what you want.+Choice of 3 game modes (Story, Adventure and Build)+A good amount of crafting recipes, including armour and utilities such as a jet pack.+A very well thought out game which i#has so far been exectued really well.-Story mode (for me) drags on way to long as a long tutorial, didn't even finish it.-World generation in current build for Adventure Mode is messy. Also limited to one biome in adventure mode.-Tedious mining and combat.-Optimisation (expected to have problems as it is Alpha, not game breaking though)A solid 7/10.

Early Access Review
								ok so after Playing a few hours in this game I LOVE this and Recomend to EVERYONE with an Nvidia 9800GT graphics Card or Higher (for the Open CL codeing) to get this My card is at the low end of this program But still runs well enough.as for the gameplay Customizer is great BUT quite Finnicy to use we should have and Eraser Brush tool not a 4 click WTF thing to cut bits away from our creations. Despite this I got the hang of it in 2 hours and made the Shreadder (copper blade with stone Teeth and holds cut threw it) which can four hit all starting creatures.my last ponit of contention is the Controls the Key Board Controls are great Just like D&D Neverwinter so easy to pick up if you played that one though there are alot of differences. BUT the PC controller section is lacking my only control is forwerd and back none of the buttions respond and theres no rebind option for them or there is and its not working Please fix.But the digging is what I love I spent 4 hours just digging and mining broke 4 wooden picks and 2 wooden shovels. also I love the wide variety of plants I can't wait to do some Gardening with the seeds (once I can Protect them that is) and as for the features yet to be implamented PLESE DEAR GOD give me Fishing, Herding, and Pet Tameing.Lastly for Vehicles Please encorperate all 3 types of Mech (from the over all genre) which are Powered EXO Suits (starcraft Marine or Aliens Loaders) the Virti-Tank (like Mechwarrior) and the Mecha (like Gundums, Power Ranger Zords, etc..) content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is the game that Starforge should have been. If you're tempted to get Starforge, just get this game instead. Things actualy work in this game and there's actually stuff to do. The UI is rather well done, and the block building system includes features like the ability to save a building off as a template to use for further construction. There's also a voxel editor for creating your own item models. Even though the game isn't finished as of the time I'm writing this, it still comes across like a finished game. Also check out Space Engineers, though that one is a bit more technical and more about building vehicles and stuff than this game is.

content:
ry 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have about 75 hours total on this game. Many of them were spent playing when i had no internet, so steam didnt record them. This game is, in a word, alright. While the speculated end result of this game is something very appealing, the game right now just isn't that. It has a clunky UI, weird movement mechanics, dumb AI, and lots of bugs. However, it has an interesting story, an awesome creation sharing system, and a truly destructible world, and an advanced vehicle creator, which make for a fun late game. Once you get used to the mechanics and get used to the weird and clunky UI you'll enjoy the time you spend in this game. It sucks that the map is limited right now, but im sure with time it will improve.

content:

Early Access Review
								I recommend this game because its fun to run around, dig, build, create.  One can experiment with architectural design.  That's enough for me to be satisfied but the game as a story has major problems:Be prepared to be frustrated with bugs in the story line.  I've played this game on and off for a while, seen it go through quite a few versions.  On an earlier version I was able to play through story mode pretty far, as far as the developers had written.  My saves were erased with an upgrade and given the amount of time I had spent crafting a delightful and luxurious base, I became discouraged.  I tried to restart, to plod through the storyline with its many fetch-type quests but with another upgrade those saves got erased too.  Recently I came back to the game and have been having fun with it again.  Strangely, though, I cannot get very far in the story quests.  They are extremely buggy.  The story quests appear to have actually become quite a bit MORE buggy since the last time I'd played it.  I can't get past the first quest (a critical character has irretrievably disappeared, and was just reading about the second quest having a high likelihood of a massive game ending type bug also.It is difficult to program games and I respect the hard work.  That being said, I recommend the developers focus on making the core gameplay stable instead of pursuing shiny, new, additional features with each update. I fear/suspect the game has been dropped as a serious development project and that core bugs will not be fixed.  It appears to be used as a template for experimentation instead.  That's cool but It would be nice to be able to actually play it.

content:

Early Access Review
								I bought this game 6 months ago (pre-steam) thinking it would be an amazing upgrade from minecraft. Graphically it is, but when you get down to it. The controls are so bad. I don't know why a traditional WASD control system couldn't be used. It makes combat agains basic monsters so difficult expect to die after any encoutner The custom design feature is pretty cool with one exception, there in no comprehensible tutorial included in the game. You basically have to know how to use auto-cat programs already or find a youtuber that explains the process well enough. While Minecraft resource gathering is tideous, but in this game you literally have no way of knowing if you are gathering the right plant until seeing it for the 20th time and i hope you find it again. Wanna dig a giant hole in the ground? COOL! Just make sure you have a way out, because the caves in this game give you no hope for survival.If you are trying to build a fort to protect from a monster onslaught good luck because those guys can pretty much fly. If a herd wants you dead, your chance of escape is like 20% tops.Overall this game tries to take a game like Minecraft and add elements of modern gaming, however it lacks in the simplicity that minecraft was able to hand out on a silver platter, and it was done with no instructions.

Environments become a bit bland after a few minutes, and often fail to load.If you even think about using a jetpack or hang glider for any distance you're doomed, as every time I used them I ended up clipping through the ground and getting trapped below the world.Animations are awkward and combat is just boring. Basically, if they would clean up the animations, simplify the menu's and building system, and put some serious time into fixing their landscapes, this could be a really fun game, but it is seriously shackled by these shortcomings.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
er 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								UPDATE:  Well after 1 year, I am eagerly awaiting full release of PE, and Grav, well, I stopped playing that last year.  Toxic community and not much depth.  PE is still amazing and even better now.I don't know about the other reviews, the game is being very actively developed, just check the log.  There is a new beta release about monthly.   It's also Early access, bugs are to be expected and then you give feedback.  I see so many early access reviews complaining about bugs.    Pretty awesome game and it's still in early access.  I also got Grav around the same time and both games are fun but each is different in big ways.  I had debated on which one to get for a while but in the end I got both thanks to my brother and his generosity. Both game are beautiful with  bright and varied environments.  This will not be a review of Grav, I'll just briefly touch on some of the main differences.Planet Explorers Story mode is the single player mode.  It has NPCs, missions and a story line.  I've only been playing Grav solo because the free weekend seems to have brought some griefers into the multiplayer servers and I wasn't about to deal with that, so I can't speak too much to the public multiplay, though I did set up a server for a friend and me to play.  Grav's single player is more just about exploration, but there are some tasks that you get some rewards for.The story in Planet Explorers is pretty in depth so far.  You'll meet a lot of NPCs, with a lot of missions and rewards.  The biggest difference is with the crafting systems.  Planet Explorers is insanely cool when it comes to this.  In Grav you're working with about 10 resources that you'll need to craft pre-designed items, such as a jetpack or monocycle.  You'll have different workbenches for creating different items.  Planet Explorers has a lot more resources for creating things.  And then you'll create a few things to create bigger things, and then there is a custom editor built into the game for designing weapons, cars, planes, etc...There is no pre-made car, you have to build the wheels, cockpit, engine, fuel cell and then build it and export it into your world.  For example when I had to build a car for a mission, I needed wood and rubber for the wheels, steel, iron and motherboard for the enginer, and to make that motherboard I needed plastic and copper wiring.  This may sound tedious, but it isn't because you can click on a component in the crafting window and it will then open that component so you can click on the ingredients and make them and traverse the heirarchy that way.  It's VERY easy to quickly make components and see which components will create which parts.  You then go into the ISO editor (the name for a custom creation is ISO), which is like a modeler if you're familiar with 3D Modeling.  You'll place the 4 wheels, cockpit, engine, fuelcell and then build your car however you want.  If you google Planet Explorer ISOs you'll find websites devoted to models that you can download and play with.  There are turrets and lots of guns, it's amazing what people have done with this.  Grav has been fun so far, it's a different game.. and Planet Explorers is amazing and fun too.TL;DR: Planet Explorers is amazing because you can create a lot of custom content very easily using many parts and resources.  The story mode is very indepth.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Most Potential for an Alpha(written 4/4/2014)Althought this game currently in alpha it already shows a lot of potential for the future. At the moment however their are many different surface level issues with the game. For example the textures seem somewhat bland, the animations for the characters while correct for the movements involved are a bit offputting and somewhat unnatural, difficult camera controls and the currency for multiplayer is way to easy to obtain. However I suspect that these problems will fizz away, not unlike a can of soda after being poured into a glass.This games gameplay is fantastic. Creating unique weapons and vehicles puts this a teir above any competition that does not feature said mechanics. The building is smooth and is easy to master. Combat could be better though, using swords has a bit of an mmo feel to it. The online multiplayer works great too. I love the environments and unique creatures featured in the game, even if some of them don't seem to match up from time to time. Overall, It's a ton of fun, and the concept of this game is what I hoped the next generation of sandbox survival builders to be like. However, I'd like to see improvements.

content:
, 2014
Early Access Review
								Lot's of PotentialThis game has been on my wishlist for a while and I finally picked it up during the Summer Sale. I have been playing in Story mode, so that it was this review will focus on.The graphics are 50/50 for me on this game. On the one hand, you have beautiful ditant scenery that you can actually go to. On the other hand, you'll walk over plants that are flat and seem to follow the camera. The character graphics are fine, but nothing that wowed me.The gameplay is similar to Minecraft (a favorite game of mine) in that you will need to dig for ores and then craft items out of them. The mining aspect is interesteing in that sometimes you'll have to dig out an area. You can't just mine straight through. [Also, if you want to go spelunking, make sure you have a rope gun. Otherwise, if you don't dig a gently sloping tunnel down to the caves, you'll need to dig one to get out or fast travel.]The quest system is what you would expect. Go to an NPC. Talk. Get quest. Complete quest. Get reward. The one area that I would like to see improvement in is the Designing area. The item designer is not user friendly and can be difficult to figure out. The one thing that I think would vastly improve this area is the ability to select and move pieces that you have placed. Additionally, it would be nice for there to be some basic designs available to the player already. Not everyone wants to go in and design a car.If you get the chance, pick this game up. It's got a great foundation of gameplay and should only get better.

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is an absolutely wonderful experience. The 3 different play modes offer a change of pace to the overplayed sandbox genre. Story mode, although, barebones at the moment gives a sense of direction and is a different take on a tutorial. The game, however, isn't user friendly at the start. It will take some time to learn the crafting/resource gathering/ survivng. One playthrough in Story mode offers all these basic knowledge(s) and you are free to wonder the map and do as you will. If following the storyline is what you desire, then it will keep you entertained. Most of the dialouge in the story mode is voice acted. Overall this is was an excellent purchase. The graphics are refreshing, the buildmode is wonderful, and the challenge will keep me entertained for many hours to come.

content:
28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Quite a lot of promise. Lots of tools to craft, materials to mine, and creatures to fight. The creation system is one of the best I've seen in a sandbox game, and the variety of gadgets to play with is outstanding. Just a few missions in, you can use a rope gun and a glider to grapple around like Batman in the Arkham games! And it's still in the Alpha phase!The only downside is that it is not yet optimized. This is a shame because the longer you play, the more fun toys there are to play with, but the slower the game runs, making it harder to enjoy said toys. And it only gets worse underground.I'd be Batmanning it up in the Giant Spider Caves right now if it didn't run at about 13 FPS in my current save file.Still, this is far and away better than your average indie alpha sandbox game. It puts Sir You are Being Hunted, Windforge, StarForge, and Edge of Space to shame. In my opinion, it's worth every penny full price as is, let alone when it's finished.

content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is great however it could use much refining. It is understandable that this game is merely an Alpha which makes it reasonable for flaws to be in the game but, nonetheless, the game is very fun. I enjoy this game a lot in almost every aspect, save for a few, from creating vehicles to collecting resources. There are some issues in the game like how a monster will hit you through walls, which causes stupid deaths, but the issues like that are being resolved with each passing patch.In this game, you can do almost anything you want. You can drive around in completely customized vehicles, creating the vehicles through voxels in the creator, and even build your own colony within the online servers with other players. You can design your own sword, gun, vtol, truck, tank, boats, etc. which allows this game to be completely based on your actions. The ground can be shaped the way you want to make it. All trees can be cut down and even buildings demolished. Anything you want to you in Minecraft, you can do here with much more interraction in a non-block world.I would have to say, despite how much I love this game, the major flaw that ruins it for me would have to be the servers. There are no official servers for multiplayer and, if you wish to have a reliable server, you're pretty much out of luck unless you make your own. Almost all of the servers are locked for groups of friends and the public ones are laggy and, if they go down, everything you did on them is lost. Anything you do on a server is confined to that server. This means that if you gather the best weapons and armor and make a civilization on a server, you cannot take them to a different server. It is recommended that you make your own server so that everything you make is saved.All in all, this game is one of the best games I have played in a long time and I will play it a lot more when more content is added. For an Alpha, I give it a 9/10 but i expect that to hit 10 once the bugs are fixed.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
6, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's alpha. you'll need to reference the wiki to find out what different items do, how to control the game, and what you ought to be doing.But even with that, it's fun. The item/vehicle/weapon creation system is pretty unique amongst this type of game, and is done reasonably well (a part of me ached to have more Blender-like controls, since modifying existing objects is a bit rough at the moment). Combat is decent, though most of the time I tended to lure monsters to a colony so the colonists killed them for me.After an hour or two of resource collection you won't need to do it again, which is good. It's got a great mining system that smoothly deforms the ground as you mine (it's actually the best implementation of that I've ever seen), but the animation is slow and controlling the camera underground is an exercise unto itself.Building a colony is fun, I appreciate that there's finally a minecrafty game that emphasizes that you're not alone, and allows you to recruit NPCs to work at your colony. There do seem to be some bugs with it, but nothing insurmountable. My biggest gripe is how *small* your colony has to be. It's not feasible to build dwellings and houses for your people, because if you put their beds too far away (read: like 50m away) from the colony center, it won't count towards your colony.Overall, it's definitely rough, but I like where it's going. I'd recommend that if you're uneasy about the "early access" pricetag, that you wait 6 months and give it another go - i expect it'll be more fully-featured at that point. If you want something cool to play *right now*, i'd still go for minecraft or starbound. But this is one to keep an eye on.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
8, 2014
Early Access Review
Everything you want in a video game and moreI've only been playing for a dozen hours but so far I'm immensely impressed by the quality and originality of the game. In recent years (due to the success of MineCraft) the game market has become saturated with sandbox survival games, with few titles delivering a compelling experience. Starting off in story mode, the game plays and functions very much like a normal 3d RPG, the fact that you can alter your surroundings in this world hardly ever registers as its quality is similar to that of any MMORPG of around 2008 (WoW, Guild Wars, etc.). Although the visuals don't (currently) feature HD graphics the world of Maria still manages to be brilliantly beautiful and captivating, relying more on ambiance, flora, lighting, and simplistic symmetry to carve out an idyllic image on various unique landscapes.From the moment you crash land on Maria you will be immersed in the whole world and evolving storyline. The game seamlessly blends sci-fi and medieval elements, making you feel as though you are struggling to survive when beginning with nothing. While you may start off running about with a knife, very soon you will upgrade yourself to a sword and shield, and later laser guns. The combat itself is rather simplistic, point and shoot or stand and stab, but there's enough large monsters to keep you on your toes as you frantically attempt to run between camp on the open plains. (Frankly I'm not sure if the dark forest with lurking wolves or the open tundra with giant warbirds is more terrifying).Of course at the stage of development there are some bugs, but the only game breaking one seems to be an issue with NPC "following" which may disrupt certain quests in the storyline, resulting in a little bit of frustration in trying to escort a glitchy zig-zaging NPC stuck in the ground. Most of the other bugs are pretty minor and I've seen a lot worse in games that put out on the market, so it seems like Pathea is dead set on making a high quality game. While it probably won't see as much success as Minecraft, it'll definetley make a great showing and is a fantastic first game for the publisher.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								After putting in a full solid day worth of playing I can say this game did not impress me at first.  I found it incomplete having some quests/ dialog voice acted (poorly I might add) and others not at all as well as sketchy UI and graphics issues.  My original intentions were to buy this game for my kids however I'm changing my mind on that due to the games inherent lack of any type of tutorial system.  Some very basic things are outlined for you but most of it is glossed over with little to no detail.  For example you'll have a quest to obtain certain plant types (or kill certain animals).  The most help you'll receive is an extremely tiny picture (literally maybe 50x50 pixels) of what you need to find.  I found myself having to search the online wiki a few times just to get an idea what the heck I was looking for.  Also from what I can gather there is no way to know what you're looking at - mousing over animals or plants doesn't give you the slightest idea what it is you're looking at.  So all you have to go off of is this tiny picture in the mission UI.After a few hours of play though the game did start to grow on me.  It felt like a mix of Minecraft and a RPG.  The graphics are adequate, the game runs fair at best on my i7 Crossfire rig under max settings.  I think this is in part the game does not run in true full screen mode.   I have a triple monitor setup (non eyefinity) and many times (during battle mostly) found myself clicking off the screen thus pushing the game to the background.  In other words in this alleged full screen mode you can still move the mouse beyond the frame of the game.  Also since this is not true full screen it probably plays a role in why crossfire / SLI can't be fully utilized.  Also let me add the game crashed after several hours of play due to a memory leak.If you are running high resolution (1920x1080 for myself) the UI does not scale proportionally making it difficult to see / read.  To my knowledge you can move the UI around which helps you customize and tailor to you needs but you cannot resize any of it.  This is especially true for the mini map.  Devs if you're listening please make the UI scalable / let us resize as we see fit.   I honestly feel the game has huge potential but in its current state needs work.  It definetely feels like an early access game.  If the developers keep an ear to the ground and resolve some of these basic issues this game will have serious legs.As it stands as of today I'd give this title a 76 out of 100.  If the full screen issue was resolved, the game was fully voice acted, and there were better UI and tutorials it would score in the mid to high 80s for me.I'll continue to play it as I feel I've only scratched the surface of what the game has to offer.  I will update this review in the future if need be.update 9/3/2014Ok I completely underestimated this game.  The amount of depth that has gone into the crafting system is impressive.  You go from wooden swords to laser rifles, gatling turrets for base defence - not to mention custom vehicles and aircraft even!  I'm hooked now.  Again because the dev's are doing some things I haven't seen before in a game (which is a good thing) and the lack luster in game help it was slightly frustrating at first.  I watched a few tutorials on YouTube and finally had that "aha" moment with crafting a vehicle.Even in its current Alpha state I'd now give this game a solid 84 out of 100.  I visited the dev website and checked out their forum.  I was very impressed with what appears to be ears to the ground regarding player feedback.  There are pinned posts with the most common suggestions they've looked at and are considering.  As well as status updates galore.  Keep up the good work Pathea!

content:
21, 2014
Early Access Review
								this game is so far, very nice. graphics are pretty good and controls, though a little bit strange at first (switching between mouse and crosshair controls mid battle because you ran out of 1 type of heals and need to use another can sometimes be fatal), eventually become familiar and you get the hang of what it is you're supposed to do...some things which may or may not be to your taste:-build mode and adventure mode are at the point of goodness where it's almost better to start with one of those and learn how to play rather than learn in story mode-combat with swords seems a bit pointless in almost every situation after you obtain guns, which is fair enough considering they're guns but it'd be nice for there to be a point to these higher tiers of swords and if it is gun-orientated then guns need more tiers. so yeah, using guns is much easier on you and your med packs, just remember to have bullets...-speaking of combat, there's not really much to it, if you use swords you walk in and click like mad until stuff is dead and normally it's you who dies first. theres no blocking or evasion (yet??) so you take every hit, your only chance not to get hit is to hide behind a tree and use guns to kill them while they run into it-for a rpg, apart from quests it has very few traits that one would expect to find in a rpg-i, personally, have found almost no point in actually gathering resources to make things. you can mine and collect stuff yes, but not to make things, only to sell it to npcs so you can buy the thing you were supposed to and save yourself a huge amount of time. however, if mining and collecting is something you enjoy get yourself a nice shovel and dig til your hearts content-if you do choose to do the storyline quests then prepare to spend upwards of 10 minutes running between campsites when you get a quest where you cant fast travel (or you lose the quest)-jumping feels a little bit slow to start, you press the key to jump and it takes a second to actually commence jumping because of crouching. pffft realismlil' bit extra:-i know its completely unrealistic but i think the jetpack should be able to fly me around forever. to hell with realism.-if rpg is one of the ways this game is going, stats, skills and levels may be something to consider??theres a hell of a lot to this game so far and i definitely think it has potential, i haven't yet experienced everything (i played build mode, got a jetpack and just flew around a bit then played some story) but most of what i have has been enjoyable and completely recommendable.not much else to say really, it's pretty simple, if you like sandbox, open world, crafting and understand the phrase "early access" then this game is awesome, it does a very good job of being pretty much what its tags say it is. though if rpg is what you desire most, then lower your expectations a little bit.

content:
5, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has great potential, but it's a blast to play even in alpha.  I would describe it as a cross between Entropia Universe and Minecraft.  But since not many people have played Entropia Universe, you could say it's like Minecraft in space with good graphics.  The story mode is a fixed map with a questline and I believe adventure mode creates a randomly generated map.  The land feels vast, so there is a lot exploration available.  You can mine, chop down trees, and gather plants as resources to craft items.  There is an in game item editor, so you can really create (and import) anything you can imagine.  Of course you can also build structures easily and you don't have to place one block at a time to do so.  All I want to do is play this game all the time.

content:
5, 2014
Early Access Review
								An excellent game. At first, I forgot the game was even Early Access, it was so good, for me, at least. The storyline was interesting, and while at some places it appeared to start getting a little bit boring, other things come along, like those maddeningly-hard 3 giant Warbots that guarded one of the storyline's main objective! While the game was, overall, quite good, there are some things that I can see improvement on- but not nearly as much as I would see in other Early Access games. I've played in all three modes: Story, Adventure, and Build, and mainly play in Story, since you can actually talk to people, look at a map, find people to trade with, etc etc etc. I also like Build because it gives more options in terms of experimenting: without a colony, it can be quite fustrating if you make a Creation, and find out that you did something wrong. However, here are the things that I think could have a bit of touching up on, or reworking: - AI, both in Colonists, and, say, your Followers. It's aggravating to have to go out of your way so that your Followers can actually follow you, and player-made buildings are worthless with Colonists, since they just walk up to a wall, and then appear on the roof. - Mining. I say this because, even at more advanced levels, it's a pain to mine. While sometimes you can just get caught up in seeing the massive amounts of items coming into your inventory, and having plenty of space to do so [Since Minecraft is one-item-per-block, and this is 20-items-for-half-a-block]. Drills might be useful: a mining machine would be much appreciated. Slopes would be helpful as well: the voxel system is awesome, just a pain to go up and down the mines, you know? - Movement. Ever played, say, Red Faction: Armageddon? If you were to introduce a movement system similar to that, I would be so bloody grateful. While everything is very, very nice, such as the running and attacking animations, RF:A has a much more versatile character movement, with lots of running and jumping, and you can change what you're doing mid-action, whether just turning or jumping away. - Colony. I don't know the plans, but I'd see it as very useful if you could have your colonists also work with mines and the like. If the Colony could generate an output, a production, instead of constant need of attention, both in the form of adding military might through turrets to keep the bad guys away, and in keeping everything running.

content:
24, 2014
Early Access Review
								   If the amount of time i spent playing this game from the moment i  installed it is any indication, i'd give this game even in it's current alpha state 5 stars.   The combination of Minecraft style crafting system with an RPSesque story mode to give the rest of it some kind of point creates an experience that makes you actually CARE about delving into the depths for that last chunk of iron or coal. the addition of an integrated creation system that allows you to make anything from a stool to a house to a racetrack and a vehicle to race on it in multiplayer, as well as weapons and almost anything else you can imagine while still being constrained by the resources and items you've gathered in-game makes for an incredibly immersive world experience.   i got sucked in and played 33 hours the first two days i had this game. i am almost dreading the final release as the alphas scope only encompasses a small portion of the world so far an approximate 40km square area that i have as yet not found the end of.   support this game, get the alpha!

								this game is so far, very nice. graphics are pretty good and controls, though a little bit strange at first (switching between mouse and crosshair controls mid battle because you ran out of 1 type of heals and need to use another can sometimes be fatal), eventually become familiar and you get the hang of what it is you're supposed to do...some things which may or may not be to your taste:-build mode and adventure mode are at the point of goodness where it's almost better to start with one of those and learn how to play rather than learn in story mode-combat with swords seems a bit pointless in almost every situation after you obtain guns, which is fair enough considering they're guns but it'd be nice for there to be a point to these higher tiers of swords and if it is gun-orientated then guns need more tiers. so yeah, using guns is much easier on you and your med packs, just remember to have bullets...-speaking of combat, there's not really much to it, if you use swords you walk in and click like mad until stuff is dead and normally it's you who dies first. theres no blocking or evasion (yet??) so you take every hit, your only chance not to get hit is to hide behind a tree and use guns to kill them while they run into it-for a rpg, apart from quests it has very few traits that one would expect to find in a rpg-i, personally, have found almost no point in actually gathering resources to make things. you can mine and collect stuff yes, but not to make things, only to sell it to npcs so you can buy the thing you were supposed to and save yourself a huge amount of time. however, if mining and collecting is something you enjoy get yourself a nice shovel and dig til your hearts content-if you do choose to do the storyline quests then prepare to spend upwards of 10 minutes running between campsites when you get a quest where you cant fast travel (or you lose the quest)-jumping feels a little bit slow to start, you press the key to jump and it takes a second to actually commence jumping because of crouching. pffft realismlil' bit extra:-i know its completely unrealistic but i think the jetpack should be able to fly me around forever. to hell with realism.-if rpg is one of the ways this game is going, stats, skills and levels may be something to consider??theres a hell of a lot to this game so far and i definitely think it has potential, i haven't yet experienced everything (i played build mode, got a jetpack and just flew around a bit then played some story) but most of what i have has been enjoyable and completely recommendable.not much else to say really, it's pretty simple, if you like sandbox, open world, crafting and understand the phrase "early access" then this game is awesome, it does a very good job of being pretty much what its tags say it is. though if rpg is what you desire most, then lower your expectations a little bit.

								Planet Explorers, a game that has lot of potential. I can truly say that this game have lot of stuff and it's not even released yet, you can certainly have fun playing this game. content:
21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is an excellent game, and it is still in alpha. And I am downplaying my recommendation, as I want you to read this:- OpenWorld: You can freely go to any corner of the world. Difficulty is based on geographic location, so you may not be able to reach to other corner though. Almost every part of the world is modificable, and it is a HUGE world. (3D world, up and down also counts)- RPG: The is a gaming mode which I recommend, in were craftable items are adquired as rewards for missions. There is an impressive story (very linear though) which tells the separations of humankind between earth and mars, and how they come to colonize this planet. Also, you can have up to two  companions, and any number if you are on certain missions.- Crafting: There is a common and simple type of crafting, were if you have a recipe, and the items, you can synthetize the item. But what I recommend, is the advanced (or Build) crafting method, in which you can build YOUR OWN ship, boat, car, bike, sword, shield or gun. My first car was a wooden table with wheels, but now I have a TRON-like glider, a boat, and a five seated rover.- Graphics: Are great. I would have recommended the game without impressive graphics, but this game has AWESOME graphics. Granted, it is kind of idylic. But it looks f@#$ing great.- Base/Colony: You can build a colony, and have the NPC to move over. You can assign jobs to them, automatize the farming of vegetables. Put automatic weapons to defend the base and the NPC, etc, etc.Extra bits: - There is a JETPACK :D, and a GLIDER!!!! - Steam workshop allows to share what other people and you build in the advanced crafting interface. There is a ship build like Battlestar Galactica!!!- The Story is awesome. Even though is linear, is still an awesome story.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Craft/sandbox games are popping up everywhere since the success of Mincecraft.Many of them arn't bad, but are nothing more then "meh" MC clones (I have tried alot of them, and most couldn't keep me interested for very long.)Then there is this beauty.You can mine, chop, and dig, but the landscape isn't "cubed" but adapts dynamically.And ofcourseyou can craft a vast amount of items, build tools, houses, bases, vehicles, etc...But wait ! There is more ! you also have a spore-style editor in-game to craft blueprints for your own custom <any item>.When you are finished building your blueprint (in the game called an "ISO") the game calculates what parts and materials you need to build it, and you can create and use it in-game.Exploration is encouraged, and is much more fun then most MC-style games, because the landscape actually is pretty. You spot alien creatures are ripe for the hunting, but carefull, some might just hunt you. Or work in packs.It looks good, it plays good, and it even has story mode ! (also, adventure, build, ...)If you enjoy Crafting/sandbox/survival games, this one is a must-try.

content:
6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Everything Minecraft should have been, and more! For an Alpha game, this already has a ton of content and stuff to do. Building, resource gathering, EQ upgrades, colony establishment and maintenance, INTELLIGENT Colonists, tons of building materials, tons of recipes and more. Add to that very modern, almost state-of-the-art, graphics and this is a game that I know I will play for a very long time. Oh, it has a built-in 3D modeler you can build your own objects, like guns, vehicles and dwellings, and export them to play in your games, or to share online! The creators of Planet Explorers have truly done great work, and like I said, it is in Alpha, so there is so much more to come!10/10

content:
9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Note: At the time of this writing, the game is on Alpha version 0.82.I like that you can download objects from other players from right in the game. I haven't been able to try out the multiplayer yet but I'm looking forward to it. The NPCs in the story do a great job of giving you the scripts you need to build almost everything as long as you do the side quests. It's also nice that I can sell my extra wood and marble to them before buying an item to 'trade' my wood/marble for newer tools.I am enjoying the story missions, when I don't run into a quest stopping bug (Up! Up! Up!). The game has its share of bugs like not locking the mouse into the game window during fullscreen. For dual monitor setups, this means your game will go into window mode every time you click outside of it. I change my setup to single monitor when playing. My game has not crashed at all since the 0.82 update.One of the tricks for a few of the bugs you'll encounter is to save your game often. IF you hit a bug, load up your last save and try again. If you get stuck on a quest ad don't have a save; save, quit, load. I got stuck on a quest to rescue some survivors from a stuck ship and almost gave up after reloading a few times and then it suddenly worked without explanation.tl;dr: It's a great game with a few bugs. The game has great potential. If you like sandbox builders and save often, you'll love this game.

content:
16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Amazing game with a huge, fascinating alien world to explore. A nice break from zombies to focus on survival and crafting in more original circumstances. The editor is fantastic once you get the hang of it. So far you can craft swords, blasters, land vehicles, boats, aircraft, and shields in minute detail, using your own creativity to design whatever strikes your fancy. Finding new creatures and alien civilizations and artifacts is awesome. Adventure mode creates a randomly generated world for you to explore, and you can even bring friends! Just keep in mind, randomly generated worlds also feature randomly scattered creatures, so you can find yourself facing off against an enormous UFO while you're still wearing cloth armor and armed with a wooden sword and shield.I am extremely excited to see where the developers take this game in the future!

content:
5, 2014
Early Access Review
								(40 hours into a0.82) I was very very surprised at how much I liked this game and I look forward to it reaching full release at some point. Compared to my 50 hours of time put into Starbound (100 hours into Terraria), I think PE has a lot more going for it. The only clear negatives right now would be an out-of-memory CTD every 40-80 minutes of playtime, and the obvious, sudden "work in progress" placeholders for the story mode missions about 30-40 hours into the game (but suggests maybe another 10-40 hours of story mode at least). Other rough spots include game balancing and some issues w/ colony (micro)management and crafting/block placement.Those kinda pale in comparison to the sense of awe inspired by exploring the (story mode) landscape though. The graphics tend to be a bit cartoony but not much more so than Starbound/Terraria (but in 3D), but the landscape and views can be pretty breathtaking, and (spoiler alert) you can eventually buy/craft a jetpack and a glider, and along w/ a rope gun which gets some use, it reminds me a lot of the awesome feels coming out of Just Cause 2's parachute and grappling hook. The first time I crafted a simple flyer sled put an easy grin on my face too, and I had the odd but welcome reminder of how I felt when I enchanted some uber gear back in Daggerfall and Morrowind to do silly awesome things in a game, or the rush I felt realizing I could fly the jumbo jets in San Andreas.The game has an MMO-inspired mission progression and exploration/open world feel to it, with action gameplay that feels like Minecraft or Terraria/Starbound, married to gathering/crafting partly inspired by Minecraft, with an object-modeling/crafting system that feels both relatively powerful for a game while also being a bit limited in terms of a 3D modeler (even a partly voxel-based modeler). Most of your time will probably be spent exploring the breadth of the oft-times breathtaking landscape in story mode, and some of your time digging out ores (after finding deposits using your trusty ground-penetrating scanner). Story mode also has pretty nicely-written NPC dialogue that fits the graphical style of the game, scifi-ey with just enough cartoon feel to make it feel kinda epic w/o being too serious.Other (good) comparisons I could think of: Spore's exploration gameplay. Mining/gathering in the game isn't too bad either, but I'm not that into that kind of play, and tunneling isn't too satisfying b/c of the slower animation (but you get multiple resource units per swing). There's also no need-based survival-type management, aside from keeping your inventory stocked w/ hp and stamina consumables and ammo/repair mats, but this is similar to Terraria and Starbound which are still nice games without having Wayward or Don't Starve's emphasis on survival.Enough tangents though, PE is a fun game, as long as you can forgive the CTDs and current balancing issues w/ some of the alien creatures you have to fight from time to time (oh yeah, minimal flashbacks to Monster Hunter, at least seeing the size of some of those beasts, but don't get me wrong, combat is fairly straightforward in PE). I'm still starting out in adventure mode, so I don't know if PE's story mode strengths carry over, but my initial impression is that landscape/map generation could probably use some work.BTW, the map is pretty big, as in it take a while to hoof it from place to place even in one biome. There's Fast Travel to landmarks, but you also eventually get the ability to build cars, boats, or flying vehicles if you like (even making them into gun platforms), or as I said up top, you could jetpack into the sky then switch to glider to take to the skies (plus rope gun if you want to scale mountains w/o burning (camp-rechargeable but also craftable) battery).

The variety of enemies is refreshing, while the combat system can be a tad iffy once in a while.The creation system of weapons, vechicles and the lot is very refreshing and a nice addition to the game. The AI can be a tad daft once in a while, and there are some escort missions. Fortunately AI appears to be invincible, unless they are supposed to die.If you buy it, contact me for co-op. Yet to try it, but it's looking to be very interesting.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								At first, I was mildly excited for a voxel based Minecraft clone, with real combat and a few other advances. To say I have been pleasantly surprised is a gross understatement. I wildly underestimated both the technical expertise of the developers and the coherence and beauty of their vision. BUILDINGTo get a sense of their intent; take Minecraft construction and speed it up a bit, make it take significantly less gathering time, and shrink the scale of any project. In other words, the world of Planet Explorers lends itself to building more things faster, and toward those things feeling like part of a bigger world. (this is not meant as universal praise)TERRAINThe biomes in Planet Explorers (story mode) are gargantuan. You truly feel totally immersed in an alien world, hoofing it across grassy plains. Your character will witness the sun rise and set behind massive mountains that actually sometimes require planning to bypass them to reach your destination quicker or safer! In other words, the terrain achieves relevance AS TERRAIN while at the same time being fully terraformable. WILDLIFEAdding to this are the herds of fauna. In addition to the large number of different types of creatures, there is a huge number of types of AI. You will witness flyers ganging up on prey, troops of monkey creatures fighting off predators, those same predators catching lone monkeys, and many other realistic situations. CRAFTINGSo you take this mix; quick construction, living, breathing fauna, and a gorgeous natural environment, and to it add a heavy layer of crafting. Crafting is very well done, leaning toward recipe trees that make harvesting always fun and profitable, while reducing the actual act of crafting to a minimum (for good or ill). This causes occasional lulls in the frenzied bouts of construction, while allowing one to get back to it after a refreshing harvest period. COMBATCombat is odd. It fufills its function properly; requiring you to watch your back, but not too much, allowing some experimentation and failure without too heavy a penalty, and giving a sense of progress and empowerment over time. The combat itself is fairly clunky at the moment. One's character is required to completely stop moving to perform a combat action (swing, shoot, throw) so it isn't super fast paced action twitch combat. It is however often frenetic and thrilling. My only objection is that healing items are instantly applied and heal for huge amounts, often 70% of your HP. Personally I'd prefer they back off on instant huge heals and, like combat, go for slightly slower action, requiring planning and preparation. SUMMARYOverall, better than I ever imagined I'd get in a game featuring heavy terraforming and construction. To have so many and such varied systems layered atop an already well executed creation game is, frankly, dreamy. PROS & CONS- wildlife view distance is fairly low, leading to some pop-in and unrealistic situations- voxel technology has a ways to go; your creations have a far smaller draw distance than everything else. Again, pop-in.- players who enjoy this type of slower combat don't want to monitor their HP bars for sudden precipitous drops; they want to monitor the RATE of DECREASE of their HP. Conversely, allow movement during combat actions to move toward more action oriented combat.- runs pretty heavily on my SSD, 3+ghz multi-core, decent gfx card system. Not sure if it needs optimization or it's just a heavy game, but either way it wants a beefy system.- texture detail is varied. some are goregous and sharp, others are, hopefully, placeholders.- the humanoid characters look fantastic in terms of animation and graphics. really top notch.- bullets and lasers should really be far faster. - lighting is fantastic both indoors and out. doesn't hog up my FPS, either. (how the hell?!?)- water looks great, needs physics based waves. keeping my fingers crossed.SPECIAL MENTION- billboard grass done right! The view distance on the 3d grass is mind-blowing, and the way they animated it is perfection. Wow.- flowers that bloom at certain times of day! huge boost to immersion- the person behind the "ambience" features in this game is a genius. floating petals and flowery debris is such a subtle but effective addition to the plains biome.

content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I shall tell you a tale. The tale of a man that was minding his own ♥♥♥♥ing buisness. That man was me, I was wondering far and wide in search of many differant minerals. Along my travels I met one of the many inhabitants of this female only occupied planet (planet Lesbiana, quadrant 69bj), and we set off in search of gold, along the way slaying many a beast. Silently laying in wait just out of my render distance sat a great horror one that strikes fear into even the bravest of neckbeards. I roamed closer not any the wiser of what prison shower ♥♥♥♥ scene that was about to take place. When IT it rendered in ,The Giant Space ♥♥♥♥ Robot from Space began to stand, I ran as fast as my skinny futuristic weakling legs would carry me, but it was to late, I and my partner were blown away in a volley of 10 or so rockets and one accurate laser blast. I layed there plotting whether I should call the cops and report ♥♥♥♥ or just go to therapy for a few years.  10/10 would drop the soap and get ♥♥♥♥♥ again.In all honesty it is a great game. All great games have problems at the start , for me the adressable ones are having to leave and rejoin the server in multiplayer and friends not being able to pick you up, in the build servers you need an infinite amount of items not like 1000 items each because if lets say you want to use a model someone made of a jet or one of the bigger models its uses up pretty much all of those items. One thing this game seriously needs very bad is a party system that overlays on to your screen and not just on the map, similar to Arma 3 wastelands party system. With just my short time playing this i enjoyed it alot, but be wary its still in alpha so it will have problems. Great game even in alpha state.

content:
3, 2014
Early Access Review
								Updated Review:After the devs started undertaking an overhall of the game, I tabled it for a while.  I had already completed the story, had my save wiped, and completed it again, so I didn't feel I was missing much.  18 months later, with a0.9 out, i picked it up again... and it's boring.  NOTHING CHANGED!  The view is exactly the same and the graphics don't feel any different.  I looked up a screen shot of my last save, and they look nearly identical, with a few slight differences.  Before the view distances were synced properly, but now the grass can go on forever with no terrain beneath it, making it look like the grass can fly.  There's a weird haze over anything further than ten feet, and the close plants don't appear as vibrant either.  Loading times are longer, and lag spikes are more frequent, but watching my computer performance, not linked to high hardware demands.  So I take it back, it doesn't look the same as before 0.9, it actually looks a bit worse.Sounds now detract from immersion.  Ambient noises like the ocean waves cannot be turned down without turning down sound effects as well.  Voices are hard to hear, and the text font sometimes goes blurry.  The music used to be nice, but after hearing the same thing for hours, it gets monotonous.  The tracks are short and there's little diversity if you're staying in the same area for a long while.  Weapons are put away in the middle of combat because you changed your view angle.  Bows are so weak you might as well be throwing rocks, but you get guns and laser pistols soon enough.  Those also suck until you spend the time upgrading, which I highly recommend.  The turrets are more fond of shooting your own base than any enemy, and there's no quick way to refill them.  Axes won't start hacking at trees unless you have them drawn, not just equiped but drawn.  The interactions to harvest plants are choppy and irritating.  Monsters will despawn while you're still trying to empty their inventory.  Trees magically regain all of their durability if you stop hacking at them for more than a second.The creator tool is still awesome, but at the same time aggravating.  You can create many amazing things, like if you want to spend hours making a sword or carving out a shield, or possibly days on something bigger.  You can change your view angle, and camera locationg, but working intricate designs is extremely difficult.  Even curves are a pain, so most initial designs come out looking like boxes.  I'm not really into moschism, so I just use the scripts or workshop.  I did build my own helicopter though, and let me tell you that's a challenge.  The softest landings damage it, despite tires and iron struts.  That's fine, helicopters are delicate.  So delicate that if you ram into an invisible tree, your creation is dead.  There are also invisible walls marking the edge of the story zone.  No semi-transparent warning, nope, just flaming death.The camps have been changed since I last played though.  Before, the martian camp was decorated with everything they could want or need, which is in line with the story, and I happily stole it all.  Yeah, suck it martians.  I guess the devs didn't like that tactic because now the martians have the same camp, but with skeleton buildings.  No doors, no stairs, no pretty plants, nothing.  And the buildings themselves didn't change to accomodate, they just stripped them bare.The pathing has been improved slightly (very slightly).  Now my followers don't get stuck in a cave, but they do still walk off plateaus, get trapped in rivers ten feet from the beach, get stuck inside buildings, or inside trees, or rarely stuck in an empty field with nothing around.  If you have them assigned to a work station they'll sometimes teleport though, so yay I guess.  Okay, so I ragged on it a bit, but that's mostly due to the devs spending a year getting 0.9 out, and the transition being less than stellar.The price has gone up a bit since I first bought it, but for those that have never played it before, I still recommend the purchase (currently $25).  Yes, it's incomplete and the movements aren't fluid, and mining is slow and painful, but your first dive in will be to an incredible new world with a story that actually makes you curious about why the martians and earthlings hate eachother.  I don't think I ever really found out besides there was a war or something, but I hope there's more (otherwise the backstory sucks and needs some filling out).  Edit:Previous Review, Jun 23, 2014I currently recommend SINGLE PLAYER for this game. While there is a multiplayer function, the lag is terrible on servers of size >6. As for single player story mode.Great game, especially for being in alpha. No major bugs that I found, but at the same time not everything is working yet, which is to be expected. The scanner is the only real pain right now as minerals don't always show up. Combat is as expected, though a first person view would be great for those tighter areas. The story is engaging as I'm trying to solve the internal human problems as well as slowly imagining a history for the alien species. The graphics are amazing, even on low settings, and while there are very different regions, they transition smoothly.

Early Access Review
								Everything Minecraft should have been, and more! For an Alpha game, this already has a ton of content and stuff to do. Building, resource gathering, EQ upgrades, colony establishment and maintenance, INTELLIGENT Colonists, tons of building materials, tons of recipes and more. Add to that very modern, almost state-of-the-art, graphics and this is a game that I know I will play for a very long time. Oh, it has a built-in 3D modeler you can build your own objects, like guns, vehicles and dwellings, and export them to play in your games, or to share online! The creators of Planet Explorers have truly done great work, and like I said, it is in Alpha, so there is so much more to come!10/10

content:
16, 2014
Early Access Review
								Amazing game with a huge, fascinating alien world to explore. A nice break from zombies to focus on survival and crafting in more original circumstances. The editor is fantastic once you get the hang of it. So far you can craft swords, blasters, land vehicles, boats, aircraft, and shields in minute detail, using your own creativity to design whatever strikes your fancy. Finding new creatures and alien civilizations and artifacts is awesome. Adventure mode creates a randomly generated world for you to explore, and you can even bring friends! Just keep in mind, randomly generated worlds also feature randomly scattered creatures, so you can find yourself facing off against an enormous UFO while you're still wearing cloth armor and armed with a wooden sword and shield.I am extremely excited to see where the developers take this game in the future!

content:
y 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've now played more than 40 hours  in story mode, and I like it. A lot. I've just about came to the end of the missions, all that's left is some more monorail track building. That said, it has some problems, so this is mostly a list of things that need to be improved. MiningThis suffers from total confusion, because there is one rule: 3rd person perspective doesn't work with interiors. period. So what really needs to be done here is to implement a first-person view, this would fix that. Pathfinding AIThe NPCs are often jittering around, get stuck on trees or other obstacles, making mission where you have to lead somebody somewhere a chore. Scripted MissionsSometimes you've done something which you shouldn't have, like killed some monster before you get the mission, And then one of the "kill 0/3" monsters is missing. Or you killed the queen of the hive which you were only supposed to distract. What works in these cases is to save and reload, but then all three will reappear, and you need to kill all of them again. UIOn big screens, it's barely readable. There's need for a variable font-size.ColoniesThere are NPCs which can do mining or gathering, but it only works when they're your followers. It should really be possible to assign them this Job in the colonies. Also, it would be nice if it were possible to move around machines/beds in colonies, or remove and replace them without all the colonists loosing their status as colonists.VehiclesI've got difficulties steering them, probably due to some mouse/keyboard confusion on my part. A first-person view might fix this as well. Weight and ISOThere seems to be the problem that everything you create gets incredibly heavy; since everything is supposed to be "full metal" instead of being profiles and tubes. So you easily end up with 20 ton Jeeps. Not sure whether this can be fixed. On the other hand, I've never seen anything like it. I can create everything, from swords and guns to cars, boats and aeroplanes. Wow!CrashesIt does this often, mostly after fast-travel or loading a game (which both seem to use the same logic). But that's a known problem, related to memory consumption and apparently bugs in the Unity-Engine. So you can definitely expect improvements in the future. To sum up: This is around 40 hours of gameplay already, in story mode, and while some things feel weird or are unbalanced, it's definitely playable. Recommended.

content:

Early Access Review
								   If the amount of time i spent playing this game from the moment i  installed it is any indication, i'd give this game even in it's current alpha state 5 stars.   The combination of Minecraft style crafting system with an RPSesque story mode to give the rest of it some kind of point creates an experience that makes you actually CARE about delving into the depths for that last chunk of iron or coal. the addition of an integrated creation system that allows you to make anything from a stool to a house to a racetrack and a vehicle to race on it in multiplayer, as well as weapons and almost anything else you can imagine while still being constrained by the resources and items you've gathered in-game makes for an incredibly immersive world experience.   i got sucked in and played 33 hours the first two days i had this game. i am almost dreading the final release as the alphas scope only encompasses a small portion of the world so far an approximate 40km square area that i have as yet not found the end of.   support this game, get the alpha!

content:
21, 2014
Early Access Review
								this game is so far, very nice. graphics are pretty good and controls, though a little bit strange at first (switching between mouse and crosshair controls mid battle because you ran out of 1 type of heals and need to use another can sometimes be fatal), eventually become familiar and you get the hang of what it is you're supposed to do...some things which may or may not be to your taste:-build mode and adventure mode are at the point of goodness where it's almost better to start with one of those and learn how to play rather than learn in story mode-combat with swords seems a bit pointless in almost every situation after you obtain guns, which is fair enough considering they're guns but it'd be nice for there to be a point to these higher tiers of swords and if it is gun-orientated then guns need more tiers. so yeah, using guns is much easier on you and your med packs, just remember to have bullets...-speaking of combat, there's not really much to it, if you use swords you walk in and click like mad until stuff is dead and normally it's you who dies first. theres no blocking or evasion (yet??) so you take every hit, your only chance not to get hit is to hide behind a tree and use guns to kill them while they run into it-for a rpg, apart from quests it has very few traits that one would expect to find in a rpg-i, personally, have found almost no point in actually gathering resources to make things. you can mine and collect stuff yes, but not to make things, only to sell it to npcs so you can buy the thing you were supposed to and save yourself a huge amount of time. however, if mining and collecting is something you enjoy get yourself a nice shovel and dig til your hearts content-if you do choose to do the storyline quests then prepare to spend upwards of 10 minutes running between campsites when you get a quest where you cant fast travel (or you lose the quest)-jumping feels a little bit slow to start, you press the key to jump and it takes a second to actually commence jumping because of crouching. pffft realismlil' bit extra:-i know its completely unrealistic but i think the jetpack should be able to fly me around forever. to hell with realism.-if rpg is one of the ways this game is going, stats, skills and levels may be something to consider??theres a hell of a lot to this game so far and i definitely think it has potential, i haven't yet experienced everything (i played build mode, got a jetpack and just flew around a bit then played some story) but most of what i have has been enjoyable and completely recommendable.not much else to say really, it's pretty simple, if you like sandbox, open world, crafting and understand the phrase "early access" then this game is awesome, it does a very good job of being pretty much what its tags say it is. though if rpg is what you desire most, then lower your expectations a little bit.

content:
4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Craft/sandbox games are popping up everywhere since the success of Mincecraft.Many of them arn't bad, but are nothing more then "meh" MC clones (I have tried alot of them, and most couldn't keep me interested for very long.)Then there is this beauty.You can mine, chop, and dig, but the landscape isn't "cubed" but adapts dynamically.And ofcourseyou can craft a vast amount of items, build tools, houses, bases, vehicles, etc...But wait ! There is more ! you also have a spore-style editor in-game to craft blueprints for your own custom <any item>.When you are finished building your blueprint (in the game called an "ISO") the game calculates what parts and materials you need to build it, and you can create and use it in-game.Exploration is encouraged, and is much more fun then most MC-style games, because the landscape actually is pretty. You spot alien creatures are ripe for the hunting, but carefull, some might just hunt you. Or work in packs.It looks good, it plays good, and it even has story mode ! (also, adventure, build, ...)If you enjoy Crafting/sandbox/survival games, this one is a must-try.

Early Access Review
								Everything Minecraft should have been, and more! For an Alpha game, this already has a ton of content and stuff to do. Building, resource gathering, EQ upgrades, colony establishment and maintenance, INTELLIGENT Colonists, tons of building materials, tons of recipes and more. Add to that very modern, almost state-of-the-art, graphics and this is a game that I know I will play for a very long time. Oh, it has a built-in 3D modeler you can build your own objects, like guns, vehicles and dwellings, and export them to play in your games, or to share online! The creators of Planet Explorers have truly done great work, and like I said, it is in Alpha, so there is so much more to come!10/10
